Entry.1:
1914
Goodbye to "Joyous Gard" - Last look round "Camelot" - last instructions - on "Kyarra" about 12 - tug ordered for 5.45. but crowd kept in ignorance - long wait for wives, sweet-hearts, mothers, fathers, sisters and friends - "Auld Lang Syne" - Streamers - so - off to the War.

Dec. 9.
Boat 1200 ton measurement - on board, 1st and 2nd A.G.H. 1st and 2nd Stat." H., and
Entry.2: Cass. Clearing H 66 M.0's, 161 Nurses, 62 sergeants and 503 men. Equipment (beyond R.A.M.C. requirements) for 3 months' work - (delayed in Melbourne, because carrying contraband of war, which had to be unshipped as we were travelling under Geneva Convention.) (Our Australian Medical "Mayflower" said to the first boat purely medical, and on such a scale.)
Entry.4:
Routine of Ship
as per Regulations - Physical Drill (optional for Officers and Nurses). Amusements- Army Medical Requirements and procedure (well supplied with official Books) Discipline - excellent lecture by Captain Lowrie, (afterwards typed and circulated at my suggestion). Courses of lectures and instruction to the men. Shaking down to Seniority and King's Regulations - Find "Hints to Young Officers" useful.
Entry.5:
At Fremantle.
P.M.O..- also Acting P.M.O. - Germans - neither paid us an official visit - but the Governor interested and attentive.
Entry.6: Gradually acquiring a knowledge of the working of the machine - decent realization of service, under a Central Organiser (unfortunately the duty of the Subordinates simply to do their Regulation "Job", not to go outside, to send on and not act - so differing from the Navy, where it is the duty "to do at once anything one's qualified to do, if no superior is present"- hence (with Efficiency also placed before Seniority,) the better work of the Navy.)
Entry.8: A.G.H.- some antecedent Army Medical Knowledge - No. 1 apparently nil (hence subsequently some of the dissatisfaction at Heliopolis). 2 A.G.H. mostly G.P.s with less Hospital status. Col. Nye Padre. says "more frills and less real reason" than 1 A.G.H.- remains to see how they will rise to the situation. Two Victorian Captains, and myself as Senior Physician, had been switched on to 2 A.G.H. because of the failure of Sydney Hospital physicians to enlist. (Said also that our two Senior Surgeons (Nash & Grey) were similarly not representative of Sydney Surgical Hospital Staffs, and that their selection had been the cause of the more experienced not enlisting.)
Entry.9: Visit of Inspection round the ship - clean, but might be better Ventilated, Lit, and less crowded.
Entry.10:
Neptune on board - great sport -
but
the main "ducker" got cerebral concussion - (A N.Z.Surgeon on the Fleet is said to have had his spine fractured).
Entry.12: Ptomaine poisoning- 12 in saloon and 2 on deck. Curry and Rice - Capt. Mattei reports "Ship structurally unsuitable, insufficient space, dark and ill ventilated- not adapted to long voyage" (probably difficult to have got another boat, but, not adapted as well as might have been).
Entry.13: Red Sea - guardian Cruisers by day, and searchlights by night.
Entry.17:
In a £5. per day room at Mena House; close by where the great "subsist in bones, and are pyramidally extant"- Martin and House pick our Hospital Camp - H. quick, decided - impressive:- but site 
under water
each November
 went in Nov and saw it for myself) 
and afterwards condemned) - round the hospital, - mostly Pneumonia. Why so much? - said to be "weakened by influenza" - "not give in, and not treated" "standing in cold mornings out in cold trenches" - "dust in air passages" - "Returning in cold nights from Cairo, without overcoats, and with drink" - 20,000 men in Camp - 7000 horses - built roads, railway etc. I draw up "CaseTaking" Scheme - unpacking equipment (with part staff, only). All ready in
72 hours.

Inf. Brigade, H.Q. "M.O.'s same story "men overcrowded", "insufficient relaxation" "Sunday like week days, with parades - worked too soon" (even horses a spell) - Packs 90 lbs instead of 60 "take them off, get chilled"- "not back till 6 p.m." instead of 4 p.m."

General dissatisfaction at Heliopolis 1 A.G.H. (ending finally in D.G.M.S. Eng. recommending "return to Australia" of O/C Registrar and Matron. Causes - (1) Faulty selection, (2) Selfish ambition, (3) Lack of military knowledge by the staff. (So resentful)
Entry.26: Tell staff Officer "too much illness - twice that of the trenches" - "Men said to be overworked." In the afternoon General orders by General Birdwood "one day a week Holiday-nil on Sunday after church parade - better rations" - Best news since we came here."

(characteristic official procedure)

Entry.59:
I beg to report as follows :
(1) 
From Jan. 24th to date 
I have had charge of all medical sick amongst officers and nurses, and such proportion of the medically "serious and special cases" as could be treated in my proportion of the Hospital beds. The cases of Measles, Influenza, and Pneumonia thus under treatment have been as follows:-

Ontreatment before our arrival.

(2) Far the majority of the cases of 
Measles
 were 
German Measles
. 
The Pneumonias
 were all Lobar Pneumonias, many double, and attended with an amount of Throat trouble, Diaphragmatic Pleurisy and other unusual symptoms, such as are unique in my experience. I would 
draw special attention to the fact that not one officer has been admitted under me with Pneumonia.

In the cases classed as Influenza
 - there has been, in addition to the classical signs of that disease, an extreme amount of Inflammation of the Tonsils and the Pharynx.
Entry.63:
The number of Cases in which Pneumonia has follows Measles 
has been nil. The number of cases in which Pneumonia has in my opinion followed directly upon an attack of Influenza has been less than half a dozen. Though there may have been more, I am satisfied that the great majority were independent of Influenza, except in so far as a previous attack of Influenza may have facilitated the attack of Pneumonia by lowering the vitality and resisting power.
Entry.64:
The Number of Fatal cases has been 8.
 They have all been cases of Pneumonia.
Entry.65:
As regards Complications and Results:
The cases of Rotheln were trivial and required no medicine. Two had also true Measles.

a) As regards Morbilli, 2 had antecedent Influenza, one had Purpura Haemorrhagica (seen in consultation and not counted in the Table).
Three had Bronchitis, one Bronch-Pneumonia, and one a Submaxillary Abscess.
 
I was the Historian of the great endemic - afterwards pandemic of Influenza from 1887 onwards

(b) As regards Influenza, the diagnosis was clinical, not bacteriological - but to me quite satisfactory. The special feature, Tonsilitis, Pharyngitis and Bronchitis or Bronchial irritation - with frequent Laryngitis, was probably due to the almost ubiquitous dust in which the men have spent so much of their time. In addition to the Respira-





tory type, there have been a few apyrexial cases, several gastro-intestinal, at least one Cardiac, - but no marked Nervous or Typhoidal cases.

At least 12 had definite Bronchitis, but only 3 or 4 had Broncho pneumonia, unless, as is possible, some ofthe influenzal pneumonias were not rather Broncho-Pneumonia. There have been many cases of slight and few of severe Pulmonary Haemorrhage, one of the Abscess, six of Empyaema - 6 with Otitis Media, two with Neurathenia, and at least half a dozen with Pleurisy. One had Myelitis - two had Rotheln, one Morbilli and quite a number more or less Psychoses. What had been called a "Pyramid Cough" and a unique amount of Diaphragmatic Pleurisy have characterised the serious pneumonic cases. The latter has been mainly due probably to chill when sweating and carrying the "Pack" on the back.

(6) 
I would draw special attention
 to the Amount, Severity and incidence of the Pneumonia, occurring as has done, amongst picked healthy adults in a winter Sanitarium. In two months, there has occurred more and more distressing cases than I have ever seen during 30 years experience in the Melbourne Hospital, in six times the period. Far the majority have occurred amongst the infantry and none amongst the Officers.

(7) 
To complete the picture
 of the Disease in Mena Camp must be added the cases other than the above, which have been under Treatment simply by me; the Series of Cases treated in Camp Hospital and Tents by other members of the Hospital Unit - at times amounting to some hundred cases at a time - the 1,000 Gonococcic and Venereal cases treated in No. 2 Stationary Hospitaland elsewhere; the number treated in the various Field Ambulances, and the number treated on Sick Parade, before the different R.M.Os - amounting, I am informed at times to 10% of the Unit. In addition I have, as Chairman of a Permanent Board, had to recommend to be sent home as "permanently unfit" a large number of young Patriots, who have broken down in health through no fault of their own.
As Senior Physician to this Hospital Unit I regard it as my duty to draw official attention to this serious state of affairs
.

Mch. 30

I have already - on Feb. 18 - reported upon this matter,
 and 
asked for investigation "with a view to ascertain if possible whether some of the factors might not be removable." but have received no official reply.

In view of the seriousness of the issues
, the fact that the other troops are being sent to the camp, and the fact that Colitis is already making its appearance, whilst Pneumonia, Measles, and Influenza, continue to be sent in for treatment, I venture to repeat my request, and to ask that my request be forwarded to the proper authorities. If desired, I should be pleased to give any information or assistance in my power. Meantime the questions that strike me as important are:-

(a) The Drainage and Dampness of the Site.

(b) The Latrine and Bathing Facility and their Utilisation.

(c) The Amount and Character of the work done by the men.

(d) The Amount and Character of Food, especially as regards Breakfast and Lunch.

(e) The influence of the almost ubiquitous Dust.

(f) The Bell tent as a factor in the Extention of disease.

(g) The Effects of Exposure when sweating, fatigued or underclad.

(h The need of isolation and Convalescent Camps.

I have already obtained some information on these and other points which seem to show that certain of the factors are avoidable, which if required I should be pleased to place at official disposal.

Signed - J.W.SPRINGTHORPE Lt. COL.





(It disclosed a serious state of affairs - already drawn attention to on Feb. 18, - again asked for an investigation specially re site, sanitation, work, food, dust, bell tents, influence, and exposure whilst sweating, fatigue or underclad. mentioning that already I had some information showing some factors where avoidable and placing at official disposal. Apparently this report, also, was never forwarded, and no action was taken)

(
Re Official Statistics
 - These were then, and, I believe for long afterwards, based upon the Introductory Diagnoses from F.A. or by the Admission Officer (generally a junior with but little experience). As a rule they disclosed simply the then local condition. Hence the frequency of "Tonsilitis" etc. Even when more extended Examination and Subsequent Events show that it was only a Partial Diagnosis and failed to mention the serious underlying Cause, or serious complication - no alteration was made.
Official statistics are thus misleading
, and, I am sorry to add, that official records, even to the end of the War, wereusually so fragmentary and imperfect, that they were similarly misleading, e.g. 
as regards the Pneumonia
, the Official Figures from 
Feb. 1
 to 
Sept. 20
 give 
233 cases
, and yet by the time we left Mena, Major Campbell and I alone, had between 
us over 200 cases
 - Graphs etc. showing the condition are given in my paper "Medical Journal of Australia Apr. 29th 1916."

After dinner introduced to Gen. F.
1½ hours talk - tell him all - number of sick, landed with Influenza and Measles - perpetuated by Bell Tents, Insufficient Breakfast and Lunch, Overwork from the jump (even the horses had 3 weeks off) All officers under me - not one Pneumonia- and - except onecase each of Typhus and Meningitis, not one even seriously ill.

Mena 
- the Sanatorium for the 

Amongst the men, as much pneumoniain 2½ months as in Melbourne Hospital in 12, andthis amongst picked men in a Sanatorium - the Diaphragmatic Pleurisy and its Cause. The Throats and their cause - fine young 19 year olds - Broken Down - the Boarded cases - the Damp soil - the Continued manufacture of Disease Colitis setting in - Plague in near villages. My two requests for Investigations (neither "received by him")
Mirabile Diet
he agreed practically in toto- inferentially blamed House. Said he would "remove the Light Horse and condemn Mena" - also supported the idea of a Central Place - "The Savoy" he mentioned - as RendezVous for the men. Thanked me for what I told him - wondered why, he had not been told before (comment is superfluous - nothing was done - most say because F. did not remember promises or intentions).

The want of consideration by the authorities!
No attempt to bring Pleasure Recreation, or Interest into the camp - make Mena the Attraction, and Cairo largely "out of bounds" as well as "unnecessary". Work the men like machines, provide nil officially for mental and physical needs - let them line up outside brothels, and loll about drinking poison - and yet "in loco parentis" to Australia's best (how different it might have been.!)

Entry.90:
Brigade and all that followed - how cheerful they are - how glad - how anxious to get back - what a ring of pride will go through Australia when they get the details - just as now they have received congratulations from the King, War Office, etc. - how the Navy joins in admiring them - 3000 they say wounded - some 600 killed. The outstanding fact,sunny Australians, careless in language & many other things including discipline, have unflinchingly undergone a strenuous preparation, faced its ordeal more than courageously, and fighting against fearful odds, come out with a "victor's and a hero's crown."

Entry.92:
O/C at Mena
 - my first Command - put my ideas into practice - inter alia - Obtained from Matron a list of necessaries for dressings etc in each ward - put her on the track of obtaining sufficient cigaretts, papers, card, games, tooth brushes and other comforts, whilst we are "in Loco parentis". Notify all that they can cable home at¼ rates (cost deducted from pay) - post up eulogistic communications from Com in Chief, from King, Admiralty, and Fleet. Take a number of photos - to be reproduced at cost price in time for the mail - asked Mrs McNamara 
one of our visitors - always helpful
. to give each man a copy of the King's message - send for Kits left behind at Alexandria, and arrange X Ray exams to be made at Ghezireh.
Entry.93:
Recommend Memos from M/Os to accompany patients, no case of wound to be discharged without XRay, no Major operation without consultation and report from consulting Surgeon to O/C. - and no serious or dangerous case to be treated without consultation with the Senior Surgeon or Physician (all badly needed)
 
would have saved much if done from the first.
Major J. to Ghezireh - (180 beds up now) - 500 copies of King's message ready - obtained 10/- per fortnight for each patient from his pay - Rearrange Hospital, - sign many forms for comforts at Paymasters deduction - Matron responsible for Papers, Donations etc. - clear out the lounge and nurses old sittingroom - bad cases to have the the best lit and ventilated beds. Prepare Lists for Base Details - Convalescence at Alexandria, and Boarding - Concert in evening - "Knowles' company" - worth much else.

 .. one of the outsiderswho could if given the chance.

Put up List of Articles to be obtained as per sample, and prices to be charged. Meantime - 12 razors, one for each sister, and a few 
X Ray

"A visitor call at irregular intervals, but that was about all - When I tookcontrol, I hurried up the YMCA for games etc. - got thing through benevolent ladies like Mrs. McN., but by establishing the system of the local canteen and payment of the men, they got almost all they wanted without any intermediary or delay -) Hurry up convalescent cases to light. Try to rouse them. Over to Heliopolis - 11 nurses sick, 93+12, also 17 (+ 6 to Alex) reinforcements.
Entry.107:
Barrell intercepted even those for us! ordered there by D.M.S. Now 1500 patients in Heliopolis Palace, and 1300 at Luna Park 800 in one shed under Matron Graham - "70 infectious" in nearby Casino under Sister Tramlett. (Complain of insufficient attention and food - also 680 at Helwan under R.A.M.C. and QM Sabine Lang after complaining, and from non-military behaviouralmost under arrest. 
JohnLang - came from Melb to help - made a Captain or thought so) GB. So upset at Consideration that he became mutinous"almost mental
B "800 Eye Cases", - all but 120 treated by Capt Morlet though B took credit withO/C's) B himself away - disputed by F. "to select another C.Home at Alix - tireless energy, boundless "butting in", "all off his own bat" but "regardless of others, their claims and their "Jobs". . even so not content - arranging "for cholera - though "dangerous proximity and ones elsewhere "also Home for Nurses - (All must be under one command)" - theirs - though Ghezireh half empty - Palaces and Colleges available elsewhere, far more suitable - certainly met the while M. did not - Val how? - those like Treves who are "personally conducted" and only know the magnitude are impressed - and praise.

Weather hot - sweating all day, 3 undershirts - sunstrokes at Zeitoun. Horses ill, though hosed all day - yet fresh troops her & in Flanders Winter clothes) - no practical provision for V.D. diminution. by alter interests, supervision, out bounds, etc

True! British soldiers Club. Known to how Ye gods, what attention to detail and neglect of fundamentals! - incredible if not experienced.

Still they come - splendid food for powder -the Australian resourceful - probably beginning to think "not given the best chance" - German success against Russia - mainly of guns - are we also "Lions let by asses" - would one believe it, this Hospital opened since May 1st - yet no K1,no Lin: Opii. no P.H.L. no chalk. Phenazone - or the like - for even my little requirements. - (Salterland says "no splints when the wounded arrived at Heliopolis" - and he one of their MO's)

Entry.108:
Mena closed - some to Alix, the rest to Ghezirah and Reiach "to report on its sanitary conditions and fitness for convalescent Home - He condemned it - (and so did Purdy later on) yet the British still sent there!
More and more evidence from Read, Tebbult, House, Archdeacon Richards etc - as to the absence of foresight,
commonsense and evenhumanity at the front.
And here at Ghezireh! - No chits - no pay - no orders forpay - no permits to city - no clothes from pack store (all pyjamas) no seats in grounds, none in my ward - no photos taken or for sale - no refreshments, cigarettes etc. - except out of ourown money, - not allowed to buy.
Rheumatic Gout cases must walk up, and down staircase - just seen one man lying down to recover himself after walking up to the
Entry.109:
floor.!

Lift forbidden to Nurses (top floor) (to save expense) - In my Ward - six Rheumatics - find two Enteric - too shock - one pyopneumothorax and one Haemo-Thorax (junior's diagnoses!) Self senior physician - yet given chronic Rheumatics (à là Charcolal Salpetriere - work up family history, previous attacks etc showing how stupid to send sick to the Trenches! Vide med Journal of Australia April
Entry.110:
1916).

O.M.G. Saw Sellleum. Just received cable "2 Australian Hospital Ships next September".What to think of our medical Arrangements! Dumbfounded - R.S.& B. have rushed the situation regardless of all except magnification, and meeting the situation (give them that credit) - apparently careless and insufficient consideration of all below - of comfort - efficiency and all outside the KR - put energy and brains into it, - but poaching on everyone else. and glory at all .
Entry.111:
Our Master O/S kindly. Constant attention to details - run by little minds - no great thought - no attempt outside routine - opportunities lost, mainly because not seen - practically no use of his power as S.M.O. - drifting to leaward - might make things much better if only he thought them - if only we had some proper head - with power- considerate as well as experienced - what a difference!

Here and throughout Cairo thousands of young horses treated just as "wounds el praetorea nil" - Knowles, and this artists worth all the "treatment" - and yet his violinist got 8days C.B. for being out after 10.30 pm without a Late Pass, when playing for the boys at our Hospital! Would not have believed the absence of common kindly feeling and sympathy, if not forced on me from all sides - must find out my own responsibility when the O.C away, as he is half his time as A.D.M.S. - if he is so? Seems some doubt as to his position (Have seen him - our O.C wait nearly an hour outside F's door - waiting for an Interview - what a position for our Australian S.M.B.! Why, myself when kept waiting (less than half the time, sent in a Memo saying "Am busy, can you let me know when you can see me?" - and, I got attended to with the minimum of delay) - I may be landed with blame, not my own - Registrar, swelled head - good and active, Col "K.R. - no consideration, no manners and no discipline.

All this may seem as if I am querulous, even ill - but not so - not even dissatisfied ambition- simply regret -so easily so much better - and evidence I have not poked my nose into other people's business - indeed, so hemmed in, so impossible to do anything without misconception and even then, with success that "do your own job as well as possible" (even wrote Schuler ("The Age") privately "Not to start a crusade against incompetency and inconsideration) for the sake of Patriotism - as exposure now would simply excite indignation without sufficient results - preventative or curative
(Wrote Featherstone also, much to the same effect - ) 

As Stevenson says - "To sit still and contemplate - to remember the faces of women without desire - to be pleased with the great deeds of men without envy - to be everything and everywhere in sympathy - and yet content to remain where and what you are - is not this to know both Wisdom and Virtue and to dwell with happiness." (Stevenson's Walking Tours)
Entry.112:
Two qualified Dentists - with dental mechanic - now at work and always busy - 78 patients, made 36 plates - 16 amalgam and 20 gold fillings - 2 bridges, 5 crowns, 31 extractions - (What amongst such need - and yet Featherston declined them at the start, when I offered him fifty - and there have been both difficulty and delay since in getting O/C's to transfer any who enlisted as privates - only one out of many instances of the mistake of calling for enlistment instead of Service. F. did the same with some 80 qualified masseuses when I offered their services - "No place on the Establishment" - "hence, no place in the War. - But what a place there was fount on bitter experience as against K.R.!)

June 16
Hot as blazes - no cool relief as in Australia - probably no thunder storm since Sinai:- Too hot for sleep - even out of doors on the roof, And the flies begin at 4.30 a.m. - no keeping them off without netting. Afternoon too hot for siesta - even naked in one's room - Nurses quarters worse than ours - Arrange for patients to go out before 9.30 and after 6.30 - rest of time in rooms - Got a gramaphone from some friends - the .
Entry.113:
About this time Gen Spens in charge of Training Troops - being an old Indian fighter, introduced very necessary reforms re Hours of Training, Summer Clothing etc. - yet subordinates often upset his plans. Men 
did
 faint - "machine guns etc" - "in tightfitting thick tunics in the broiling heat."Thin canvas tents still the only protection against the sun, - and even after khaki-drill was available, came 70 miles
from Tel el Kebir
at T.104° degrees and over in the shade to Cairo, still clad in thick winter suits of Flanders. (I met some scores in the streets and no where to go to)
Entry.114:
Still hot - said to be Khamseen-120° degrees at Luna Park - 20 sunstrokes at Zietoun (? 2 deaths) - no place for soldiers, horses, much less patients. At night, meet General Legge just from Australia, - Tell him all re Gallipoli to Cairo - medical arrangements, want of Soldiers' Club etc. (Argyle transferred by B. and Co. to the Citadel (just fancy our Melbourne X Ray Electric Specialist sent away from thousands of Australians at 2 AGH to a few in a British Hospital in such a time of need)!) Our 3 AGH double Hospital, now at Port Said on its way to the front. (What management - first here - then England - now again here but too late - and without equipment (handwritten 
equipment came on on another boat!)
 and McCormack, Sydney's greatest surgeon treating cases of Dysentery, - and the O/C, Col Fiaschi, ignoring the advise of such men as Prof Martin, Stawell etc)!!

(Page missing).
Entry.115:
Tea with Gen. Baptie- (had inspected Ghezireh the day before). He says "Nurses made no complaints, things not so bad" (The nurses were badly overcrowded, had few conveniences, and their flat was almost unbearable from the heat, but when General Baptie (after my telling him) made a special visit and asked, they were too loyal to complain, so he never knew the facts - and must have thought me exaggerating.!) The way of truth is hard.

22.
Gen W returns from London sees Baptie to his surprise - thinks hard on seeing him. Afternoon Mayo Robson comes as Consultant Surgeon - says B told him "No.1 A.G.H. not require him". he found 1 A.G.H. "too crowded and some of the theatres unsuitable" (Why should we the AAMC not have had our own Consulting Surgeon - in fact Surgeons - and Physicians? Later on Ryan appointed Consulting Surgeon - & Maudsley Consulting Physician - Though I was M's senior, I was never asked, or knew till it was done

23.
(Find from Records thatthe 2nd lot of Red X Goods were received at Ghezireh, - pillows, pyjamas, sheets, towels, face washers, handkerchiefs etc. - No general knowledge of their arrival - C/C. too busy or to thoughtless to do anything, andno scheme of distribution, even if patients and sisters had known that such as they were, they were available.)

24
Gen. W. brought out 1600 cases Red X Goods - but F. orders him "back to London" to supervise transport of Australian wounded to England, - and to stay there". What a position for our Chief Medical Officer.!B. said to be ADMS - return for doing F's work and making himself indispensable go-between, between F. and every thing Australian. (always some doubt about B's appointment - but heacted so).

Legge said to have cabled Aust. "condemning Cairo as garrison, and hospital town". Baptie reducing Luna Park from 1300 to 500 - and splitting up R.S. and D's 6 hospital coalition into 2 separate units - The swollen frog bisected. Arranging for the first Meeting of Board of Enquiry, appointed by F. as draw a rough draft of "Recommendations for future guidance", and send copies to Heliopolis for Maudsley Watson & Barrett through McLean - show them also to Sellheim.







Part of page

To follow "Martin Stewell etc" - on marked missing.

June 18 - 1915
Naked as born at 7 a.m. in my room - well again after the hot spell - said to have been the worst for years - felt near something perilous - written no letter for a fortnight, scarcely smoked, but eaten well and drank gallons of tea, lime juice etc. - better after a good dinner.

Mrs Macnamara one of our Comfort Funds Visitors
Another comfort Funds visitor
Major Campbell knocked up - if it had gone on much longer, more of us would have knocked up - Mrs MacNamara give one secret to B's rise "made Mrs. F. a "Lady Bountiful" in distributing out Red Cross Funds and then repaid by position on the staff" - Campbell calls Luna Park a "chaos" Mrs Hornblower goes there "because so much wanted" Mrs MacN found them "Acutely hungry" 120 degrees in new galvanized roof building, B said to boast "of having started 14 hospitals", all under the one contol of R.S. & B. Is there one satisfactory or efficient??

Said goodbye to Legge on way to front - met General Baptienow new DMS Mediterranean Vice Gen. Barrett, (admittedly unequal to the post, and responsible head for Anzac scandal).
Tell him all - sympathetic and operative - has already commandeered some of the 3 AGH for Troopship Duty - Argyle gets away from the Citadel to us, apparently through Martin our O/C - Fancy the management that got rid of its XRay specialist at the present juncture - 2400 Australian patients! Quos Deus Valt perdere priusquamdemental.

A cable from Schuler Editor "The Age" "Want frank informative articleManagement Red Cross" - "just so". (1st hint of dissatisfaction in Australia)
Entry.116:
Major Read now at Ghezireh - now appointed (offd. Sanitary Officer) - finds 4 openings from the kitchen into the main sewer with a backwash from the sewer pit (and the Assistance Cooks using the Roles as W.Cs!

Mayo Robson 
Well known English Surgeon consultant RAMS
 - to mess - Give him our Field Dressing "to improve" - and point out that our authorities had directed 
"to apply the cotton wool and not the dressing next to the wound!"
(not aware if anyone had already pointed out the mistake - surgical - not my job)
 
 men in the field a taught about it.- often used their own ona pal - & had none left for themselves -
See C/C. re Schuler's cable - Sir George Reid cables "What do you want". Hear (for the first time although date of appointment far back as April 15th). that Gen F. DMS Egypt had appointed

Board - Maudeley, Watson, Summers and Self, with Barrett as Secretary, "to enquire into and Report upon the health of Australian troops in Egypt (vide appendix)
(We heard nothing of General F's action up till now, when all the troops had left, and the Anzac wounded and sick were filling their place). (F"thought M was Presidenl" was surprised to find me Senior - and so - automatically President)
Entry.117: day with a shirt on for a fortnight! C. ill in bed - (Campbell: probably 14 hospitals opened in Alix since we were told "no proper place for one more" - and still ' good sites such as the Palace of the Ex-Khedive at Montazah - the Palace' of the Khedive's mother near San Stephano etc) all for English and French - none for Australians! (Montazah became a Convalescent Home - for half English half Australian, - but under English staff, and no General Australian Hospital was ever put in Alix. Later on, all facilities were granted for English "furlough", - but none for Australian. Was this necessary? Was it fair? Was all possible done in our behalf?

Entry.120:
Re the "Age Red X. Enquiry)
O/C. showed me his Red X Balance Sheet, (nothing but£500 advanced for Equipment - and not all spent) - Gen. w. "better not mix myself up in it" - "Can only be done through Sir George Reid". B's statement My Report senttoday to Lady H.M-Fwill serve your purpose" - The Age can obtain it through her Minister of Defence." (The frank informative article they want!) - evidence all round the Red X. not given satisfaction - write Schuler preliminary - Phil Schuler recalled - takes letter with him - attending Sellheim as patient - he approves my recommendations 
Rough Draft for Board of Enquiry

Entry.121:
Sent to Lady Helen Munro-Ferguson through Minister (à la B,)Report re B's monopoly and Results - only 3 suits of clothes for all the patients in my ward - all the rest elsewhere - (Kits Alix front . etc)
The War seems far away - don't understand - but understand our "muddling along" as never before.
Re Work - no new cases for weeks, except 3 dysentery, 3 head cases and 1 epilepsy - all "Chronic Rheumatism" (afterwards find quite a number of Paratyphoid kept in Surgical wards for "Sepsis" - (illustrating what occures in a Military Hospital run Regulationally like ours). In the doldrums - all seem in it - sized up O/C Martin - good natured - knows the ropes - but no grasp on main points, no gripon principles never thinks above 5 feet high, - dances attendance on superiors.
Entry.122: At HQ our O/C SMO and ADMS - but never strikes - no foresight, 2 a good Lieutenant under directions, - but no leader - why he's talking about "barbed wire" (in addition to "guard") to keep the men in because they have only pyjamas. What! the devils, still want to go out - even to Cairo! even without money! (their own money! What next! (The appearance of the Convalescents in pyjamas, - and such pyjamas - had become such a scandal the issued an Order against it - our official answer was "Keep them in" not "Get them clothes" The Crusade - which I headed and which lasted 3 months - is described elsewhere, mainly in correspondence with Red Cross). Sollheim whom as a patient, I poured my indignation into, tells me he was Staff Officer when Col. (now Gen.) French tried by trusting and kindness, did away with restraint and guards, when put over the Aldershot Division, - why oh why not the custom now!) Party of men leaving for Mena as convalescents - not one any clothes except pyjamas, and one without boots, - and one tells me he has£80 in the Bank - and cannot get a£ - shameful, - but only an example of the general condition.
Entry.123:
As "member of Central Australian Council Red Cross "write B. for "copy of Operations in Egypt with Balance Sheet as recently forwarded by him to Lady H. - and suggest copies to be sent Matron Ball as member of Victorian Council - and Matron Gould as member of the New South Wales Council (B. declined to do so without orders) Am now Acting O/C. (Martin away in Alix.)

Information from Officers and Visitors re Red Cross Maldistribution Mrs Fletcher re Luna Park - Reiach re Troopships.
Capt. Campbell Red Cross - nil - "plenty going to the front - nil for those coming back sick and wounded" - Board - (Baptic's doing) now preparing drugs &c. for Dardanelles. (now
Entry.124:
As O/C find 53 going back to Australia, - their clothes - hard porkpie hat w pairs thick woolen shirts, 2 thick socks, 1 thick riding pants, - and what they brought back from the front - their kits - (They had left their kits at Alix, - generally the best part was stolen, - the rest - only came back in a small percentage (vide correspondence with H.Q. and our Q.M.'s report - no Red X distribution (vide Moody and Read on other boats), no shorts from Zeitoun - no soft hats, no slippers, no mufflers, handkerchiefs etc. Obtain shirts from store (the first order of such) for 100 - ordered hats - pounded a number of small things that came from



1915
Entry.125:
Red Cross accidentally, - saw Miss D. - a Comforts Visitor -(vide list) "hats tomorrow" - no summer suits, - requisition for a lot - Reply "here next September" - This time our men from 2 AGH will go with hats, shirts, handkerchiefs, pyjamas, mufflers, toothbrushes, shaving etc. - So much for B. managerial and monopoly (believe he 
claimed
 all this afterwards as his doing!)
Write Lady H. - am sending more factsreMena, Ghezireh, Helwan, Troopships etc. - arranged Red Cross requisitions - British Red Cross methods by contrast
Entry.126: More evidence re Red Cross - "goodye to Mrs. MacNamara - off to England - give letter and correspondence "Recommendations for Future Guidance" for Sir George Reid - wrote Sellhein re men coming without their kits following - and wholesale robberies from kits when left behind at Alix - arranged for 300 suitable Hospital suits for convalescent patients.
Entry.127: Ordered 300 more convalescent suits (order not completed by O/C on return from Alix.)
Entry.128:
At 
Barrage

wonderfulGardens - Mr. Draper
- one of my patients McKechnie (shock case, sent for change) much better, but only pyjama, one duty tunic for coat - no decent shirt etc. "ashamed to have meals with us" - send complete suit next day by Sisters. (just an illustration)
The O/C returned last night - Thus myself O/C for a week - Registrar only to see me when sent for - no discrimination as to whom cases put under - Shock cases - and worse - under Subalterns - no attention to necessities of patients and the invalided beyond complete uniform and warm things - no proper Red Cross distribution - no one responsible - our Hospital ignored when new patients arrive in Cairo, - simply an extra receptacle - now almost as many Staff as patients - the last lot simply convalescents - why come up! (illustrating our secondary Australian position) and No.1 A.G.H. overflowing into such places as Luna Park, Les Ateliers and the like - whilst No.2 AGH was only half full).

The O/C's account of Alix
. - even he dissatisfied - Visited ten hospitals - Australians in all - even a Greek hospital - sent there by Col. Maher - so ADMS Egypt responsible that we did not get our own, - plenty of nurses and doctors now in Alix - falling over one another - simply conducted round as a tame exhibit, "any complaint?" "All right!" - to call such a Visit! And even yet we have no Australian hospital there - with our equipment- our job - ten hospitals started since told "no room". Here taking British away from Australian hospitals but not reciprocating (practically all our bad cases kept in Alix under British surgeons - what came we all for?)
The R.A.M.C. - they rule - we follow - do what we are asked to - fight, if only they were better - but not so - (if more suited to our men - not so - & if necessary - not so (does not blame rest upon us??)

July 13.
Letter from Sellheim
 (in answer to Request for information re arrangements for patients clothes). "(1) on entry, list of names nos.and Units to H.Q.- sent on to Zeitoun - then to Alex - where kits are kept when men go to the front.
"Alex should send them immediately to Zeitoun Base Details, who delivers to Hospital - if not containing one complete change of clothing and underclothing and boots, the Hospital places indents Q.M. at Zeitoun, who provides what is necessary"
But
 the kits are unprotected soon after the men leave, and everything of value often stolen, and - our QM tells me only a very small percentage get what is left whilst in hospital.
"Re patients discharged to Training Camp, G.O.C. had specially delegated Major Rastick (N.Z.) to see that no one entered the Camp unless clothed, and the A O/C Training Camp gave instructions as to obtaining supplies. "Everything here is working quite smoothly"

That might be so
 - but my complaint was that the men in hospital

July 13 '15
had no clothes
to go out in except pyjamas, dirty or borrowed uniforms, or, in rare cases, new winter suits - and General Spens would not let healthy training troops use same in hot weather.

15th
Except for mess dress, wear no shirt - 2 or 3 undershirts a day - sweating all the time - dry in no time - scorching in the sun - pants damp on sitting - celluloid collar washed twice a day - thick fogin the morning, soon dissipated into space by the strong sun - would you believe it "undissimus" in my room after a bath and cup of tea at 4.30p.m. (Such the climate in which we have to treat patients - even with dysentery, - and convalescents of all sorts - whose fault?)

Here are place at G.H. - 2 Convalescent Hospitals (Mena and Helwan) - with Australians at Luna Park and Les Atelliers in the Sand, hot sand - (we afterwards cooked and egg at Abbassia in the Quadrangle) - Add overcrowding etc. - only Ras el Tin (and afterwards Montazeh) - and Ras el Tin (abandoned by the British) at Alix - difficult to 
Keep Well
 - certainly to 
test Vigor
 - but not fit - to recuperate, unless heaps of reserve fund to draw on.

At our 2. A.G.H says "Wounds won't heal" - at 2.A.G.H McLean "won't do big operations" - patients can't - like Troops - go out between 9 to 5 Certainly much of our Hospital 
Ghezereh
 has cool corridors and wards but others facing W. like ours - have not - sweating uncomfortable - can't take siesta - must be terrible at Luna Park (so I found it on visiting) - Zeitoun etc.
Still many of the men in winter clothing, - though Sellheim wortking overtime to give them shirts - He could promise me only 1/3 the rest of the troops)
During my O/C ship I got away 53 "Ballarat" patients properly clad - with comforts and such like things, in addition to Ford's "winter suits".

Red Cross at Heliopolis Depot
- apparently nil by way of personal comforts - working on the question of clothing for patients - Write the High Commissioner (Copies of letter to Lady H.M.F.) See Lord E. Cecil - 1 hour - promises a Depot at Lemnos - Working the case up Re Neglect - several interviews with 
Mrs Chisholmmain agent in the Comforts Fund
- our Matron "see a Red Cross Requisition "for the first time" - my suggestions- approved by O/C to Lord E. Cecil.
New paper controversy re B's giving£750 for building in Alix, - whilst giving none here - In our hospital nil since February 15th£150, March 5th£200 and 15th£150 =£500 in all - and of that O/C "a balance of£136/13/2 - (and none of it spent on personal comforts)
just used for extra equipment
Order 300 "Hospital Suits", (Khaki drill soft shirts, hats shirts, puttees and shoes, ties etc.

Baptie pays us a visit from the Front - galvanises Ford - we (a "clear all our patients out."- 10 days before needed this time - send 7 M.Os, 15 nurses and 45 orderlies for Transport Ships (this is what I advised
before Anzac
) - no irreparable muddle this time -believe I can take some of the credit - will get none - Apply to go to the front "to see diseases first hand" "and bring Red Cross stuff to the front" (House and Archdeacon Richards say "there is nil" - But Capt le Mesurier sent in charge - 
F. would not let me go
. -would not I have been of more use?
Small Hospital Box of Red Cross Comforts arrives -
the first
- (Poor B's name
twice
on it). (Note the Date, Articles, Number and and company with Lisb soon after - through us)
Entry.129:
Apart from all this - plenty of work Board President - Charge of Isolation Ward (Typhus, Enteric, Dysentery, Cerebro-Spinal) also in other ward, 3 shell shock mutes - all recover (our first experience of such - cured, as in Melbourne, by
Papers from Australia - my account of Anzac praised as "
the best
" don't see it - r
eally the papers contributed by my patients at Mena 
- Now for my next letter to Lady H.M.F.

20th
Col. Stokes
 (ADMS at Anzac) tells me that "about the middle of July there was not an ounce of Red Cross stuff at Anzac - except 45 cases containing cholera Belts and face washes with a few Tobacco and hair brushes - though a boat was going daily to Lemnos". (and comforts from British Red X to Hellas &private comforts to Anzac)

24th
Still the same sustained heat - apparently dry, but must be humid - writing now naked at 5.30 p.m. on quite a number of things
(1) Reply to Lady H.involving a lot of work
(2) Application to go to Lemnos - not entertained - 3 A.G.H. going - we fixed here for some time
(3) Ghezireh emptying into Mena as convalescents.
(4) Baptie's visit in time this time?? 3 weeks too soon.
(5) My deafness - repeated post nasal catarrh not serious.

but progressive. becoming bad before I left England. now requires
Entry.130: Red Cross work with Mrs Chisholm
Entry.131:
AskedO/C to take charge ofMena - decline- work at Ghezirah more important & suitable .

Since interview with Lord Cecil appointed by McMahon (High Commissioner) with Ryan and Martin on Executive of Red Cross - only now though it was on my motion in Victoria the £10,000 was voted . - though I was on the Executive and President of St. Johns Amb.in Melb -and though the Matron of 1 AGH was asked by Lady Stanley "to look after distribution" & the Matron of 2 AGH had been prominent as the Sydney Branch - None of us had any say or position - W. left it to B. B. undertook it alone - as Executive Officer, he and Gen W alone represented Australia on the local British Branch and when Australia asked the High Commissioner to reorganise the Australian Executive, the money had been spent almost entirely in hospital, equipment and the like, not confined to Australians or even to hospital patients and almost nothing was left when Anzac came, - thus leaving personal comforts to be provided through local benevolence. - The Comforts Fund (thus called into existence) the YMCA and the Local British Society. B. "made each O/C the local Administrator", - though it was nothis job, and not necessarily in his line - he had also enough to do officially and practically never bothered about it - There was only one Depot - not in the City as the British, but at Heliopolis - and this was insufficiently stocked and staffed and all execution the monopoly of one man, already more than overworking and overworked in too many other directions. Between Hospitals and Executive no organised nexus - only a few volunteers doing something somehow. Outside we were dependent upon the goodwill and essential help of the British Red Cross much better organised and locally effective, but with more than enough to do for themselves, and simply helping when specifically asked - but never foraging for us - we were "connected" similarly with the YMCA - they did what their limited means enabled them under circumstances of permission, not official co-operation, as if this were enough, and relieved him of all the responsibility - B. added all their work to the list of his doings!! Was it any wonder our men "fell in" like myself.?


"....... not regretted. ... promotions show it was ...nationally against me. I saw ...wards that, though it would have ...ad my special for which I ... sent out I might have perhaps wielded more general influence - along lines of , supervision & consideration and come back at least a full Colonel"

every passed through his office & every paper awaited his rubber stamp

Our Major Read, Campbell and others on the War Path re many things, Mrs Fletcher, wife of Captain on our staff, sees Gen. F. re clothes - (at my suggestion) Meetings of Gen Ford's Enquiry Board - Boarding cases for Australia - lot of my recommendations now under way eg Hospital Ship - one AGH to the Front - Soldiers Club in Cairo - more Convalescent Homes for both men and nurses - at seaside etc) - Must draw up campaign for Red Cross work - Fancy! our Ambulances 
while none for our patients
take our Turkish Officer prisoners for drives, 
by Gen. F. order
 (he himself commandeered Bryant's car, took off the sign, and sent in a bill for petrol!! Sir John Rogers told me he had told the High Commissioner they ought to be ashamed of sponging on the Australians for Ambulance - without us - they had none!)

(? how far all this was one of B's methods of making himself useful to F. at Australia's expense)
Entry.132:
'15
Summer hats given out - "too thin in the crown" - Visitthe Pavilion with Mrs. C. - shocking want of personal comforts - send in Account to Lord E. Cecil as member of the Executive& Austr. Red X(careful not to implicate the Military though how they could be held (free from some responsibility)?
Still no shirt in the day time, See_on others - Convalescents - suitable hospital suits(khaki drill, shorts, belts, ??pultoos and soft hats - (our only official suits - outside pyjamas - being a long thickblue with thick blue trousers turned up white at the bottom - making the wearers look like travelling circus performers - saw a trap full of such outsides "Shepheard's" ).

 
... in hospitals under certain circumstances but not outside ... Mental Patients out at front ......Post. ... Melbourne's feelings if they saw them in Collins St even now ... has .....face off

Illustration of Patient'sweek-end in pyjamas

(a) Young man McK. (McKechnie)temporarily speechless, motionless, and deprived of intelligence by Shell Shock - taken for a fortnight to a beautiful garden home by two charming well wishers - on arriving, had only pyjamas and soiled stained tunic and breeches from the trenches, with very heavy boots and a forage cap. His hostess was ashamed to let hime be seen by any visitors - refused to let him wear the tunic, and lent himsome of her husband's things, until he was sent down by special messenger a linen hat - a soft khaki shirt - some socks - slippers and a handkerchief - she considered his clothing disgraceful (already mentioned
Entry.133:
Draper's Barrage

(b) Another patient - refused to go out for a trip on the Nile because the costume was so ridiculous that his mates laughed at him.

(c) A Brittish Tommy refused to put on the brown stripped suit of pyjamas reserved for special occasions - because, as he said, it was "a "convict's dress - I made the same remark myself, when I saw half a dozen starting out in the same costume to have afternoon tea with a lady. (Australian Anzac's!)

(d) Before the General Order forbidding patients to go in pyjamaspatients went into Cairo for Treatment by Cairo Specialists - in pyjamas. (I have seen them going. there. & returning)

(e) One patient left the hospital for a Convalescent Home without boots socks, shirt or hat - simply pyjamas - he was entitled to£78 according to his pay book. but could get not a penny

(f) Illustrations might be multiplied a hundredfold. (No Space)
Entry.134: First meeting of newly constituted Red Cross Executive - in Col Ryan's (sick) (at Heliopolis) room "to discuss accounts and future policy." (it was suggested "say nil about the past")
Entry.135:
Letter from High Commissioner - "Glad you have joined the Executive - No.3 AGH to the front - we here - In Gazette "Dardanelles Casualties 42,000 (ours 10,000). War Office-appointed Medical Board (Hunter, Balfour, Buchanan and Dudgeon - none of us on it). (None of them Seniors to ?? Maudsley or self - we have 20000 men there - with frightful casualities and increasing sickness - But, no re-presentatives - Little short of callous neglect - who responsible? any oneblamed?)Mentioned about it at the time but nothing done. None of us appointed. Second fiddle and disrgarded as usual. Was this fair to our men ourselves and Australia. ?

Aug. 8th
Mrs. C shows me letter from Brig. Gen. Antill (at Anzac)- "this place is red with the young warm blood of our splendid men - every yard has a wooden cross fashioned from a biscuit box - Regularly the Hosital Ship comes empty, and goes away fullof their maimed bodies - Nothing but ordinary rough rations. The medical arrange-ments and particularly the absence of intelligent procedure is the talk of everyone. Why don't you cable to the most influential

1915.
Aug. 8
you know or see Sellheim and tell him that unless something is done, you will make it 'a public matter'. I suppose
Entry.136:
of our men are suffering from stomach and bowel troubles and there is nothing for them - not even any canteen where they could buy a pound of arrowroot or a tin of milk. Col. Ryan knows this as well as others - the thing is atrocious. This vitiated diet cannot be fought without disinfectants - to get a lb. of Quicklime here is as easy as a bottle of iced beer (within 12 hours notice, I took action.
)
Yes - but why not the authorities months before.?)
A further letter from Mrs. C. 
re Luna Park
 (a) is it a proper thing for our Sick and Wounded to have to pay to be shaved out of the 2/- per week allowed them in the Hospital! (b) should they have to spend some or all of their money on Cigarettes when the A. Red X sent out large quantities of the same" (c) ought they to have to buy soap?. (Afterwards brought it before Knox and Co. - and put a stop to it).
(all this just a stone's throw from B's Depot - and in the hospitalof whichhe wasRegistrar -

Aug.10.

Yesterday a Red Letter Day
 - Red Cross Comforts fo the Front - At British Depot - meet 
Sir John Rogers
. Mrs.C. and Major Onslow -invalided from Anzac - turn up - Arrange meeting Shepheard's 3.30 with Manager of two wholesale houses - pick things there and from warehouse in , to the value of£750.. Arrange with Seltheim and Capt. Leane re hospital patients - they supply shirts, shorts and putties, We supply hats, belts and slippers. With Manager and Lieut. Haig to our Depot, (Heliopolis,) Arrange 3 Requisition Forms to be sent to each Hospital - See 3 Requisitions for Lemnos - Arrange another for Friday - Coming back, meet Sir John accidently on tram - B. at Alix - Sir J. agrees with me to act once 
if Martin willing
 - SeeM. at mess - he agrees - so arrange all ready for to-morrow's afternoon train - at Shepheard's write Onslow (who waited for the purpose) a letter to High Commissioner for full powers and also authorise the expense - All right - And so Comforts to The Front£750 for all (These were the first except private packets through Mrs. S. etc. (In Appendix is the Despatch an interesting document.

The need was awful - Almost one out of three sick with dysentery - senior officers writing "For God's sake do something - if Australia only knew -scarcely enough men to man the trenches - Nothing but Bully Beef and Biscuits - (Vide account to Red X in Australia etc." (Australia did know - later on and thoughEgypt whitewashed, Australia remembered)
My full of sufferers telling the same tale of gastritis, diarrhoea - dysentery - Typhoid and debility.

Same day 1st Cook's Excursion by Boat) arranged personally through their manager (when found) "Nile boats all idle"
The men still in pyjamas - went to barrage in Cook's Boat, not home till 12 pm No harm - Also
Entry.137: day Croquet for patients on Sports Club Ground (similarly arranged, as soon as asked by me). As for the fortnight's routine - In Charge of Medical Side (Officers included). Many cases of Colitis and Para Typhoid - culled from Surgical Wards where treated for weeksas surgical "sepsis"- many Boards -.
Entry.138:
meeting of New Red X Executive
 - Sir John Rogers helps - arange about Sec. weekly meeting etc. (none before). - Meeting at Lady Maxwell's (following Barrett) re Eskebelah Garden and Club for the Men - She wants to run it too regulationally I get admission for "Lady Friends one day a week", and "soft drinks if paying" - three months trial. In it all too much YMCA and paying a large sum of money where no need - also meals too expensive - Obtain modifications. - Almost sunstruck in cabin on Dahabeih - Boats for the Nile just now impossible owing to painting - so got smaller ones. Mrs. Read and Gen. P. re clothes for convalescents - conditions still shameful.

Letter from Mrs. C (testing B's statement that "at this date all requisitions through the matrons were promptly executed") "Requisitioned on the
Entry.139:
per Matron Graham for things 
as per list
 - After waiting over a week - got myself what I thought most necessary, through the Comforts Fund - the rest have not yet arrived - The men who want crutches are still without - what am I to do?. I suppose supply them, as I am in the habit of supplying all I want - although I cannot get a pair of crutches, or a cake of soap from the Red X. I am solely responsible for the£5000 Cabled to Sir H. McMahon a couple of months ago, - also for the£1000 the Sydney Show people gave - I have applied in the way Col. B. told me to do, but unsuccessfully. The people in Sydney think I can do wonders now for the wounded buttheylittle know yet!" --

(ADRIAN KNOX, NORMAN BROOKS and ANOTHER sent out by Australian Red Cross, because of what had become known in Australia re neglect)
Entry.140:
Red Coss Committee Meeting at Shephards - Adrian Knox there - "B" claims credit for what he did not send, as well as what he had sent -- to the "Themistocles." The meeting arranges:-

Paid Secretary

Weekly Meetings
(c)Pass my£750 for payment without even looking at it

Agree patients not to pay for shave, cigarettes, and few razors.

£500 for games - quoits, etc - to be made in Egypt.

Re- clothing - Selheim to be at next meeting. 
With his£150, Reed buys 10,000 bottles of beer! 
B says - Maxwell "military impossibility to have hadthings at the front sooner"
(The callousness and untruth of this remark shewn up later on.)

e.g. In addition to Troops and Reinforcements, every article of food and munitions had to be got ashore, 18 lb. guns and battery the first two days: 6 inch howitzers within a few days: 60 lbs guns by the end of May: 2 -300 mules and all feed about the middle of May: horses by thebeginning of June: 4.9 guns by the middle of July; and thousands of sick and wounded being continuously taken off. The Gascon alone making 12-13 trips with Sister Porter on board, who reports that "the boat never took up anything to the front", though she had all requirements for patients, "no Red Cross stuff was ever put on shore, and most of the while, there was no scarcity at Cape Hellas under the British Red Cross"!!)

In the "Egyptian Gazette" appears B's "manifesto re Soldiers' Club "
given much valuable thought and time to the subject. Red Cross, at his instigation seeing what Y.M.C.A were doing for the men - arranged for it to carry on, giving funds etc"





a matter of fact, I had brought the matter before Gen.Ford so far back as April the
Entry.141:
- it was then quite new. He approved and suggested the "Savoy" - said he would do it; I also put it on my list of Recommendations to Board of Enquiry. B. now also sign-ing A.D.M.S. A.I.F. (? as to his right at any time). Let us hope he exits, but ? -

See Selheim re Clothing; already shirts shorts puttees shoes for Convalescents at Mena and Helwan. Snow undertakes to extend to approved hospital patients, with hats belts and ties - A number of men call to see me re prices and samples - Sellheim's secretary to be at our next Red Cross meeting - Still men in Ghezereh without proper clothes to go out in - Sister R. (of my Ward - one of the best) gives me two names of men without clothes who had to borrow to go out this morning - also still insufficient distribution of comforts - get a list prepared, tell the Sister to send in Requisitions (never done before, never seen, even by Matron, none yet from Depot (although arranged) - at Headquarters find four Mena men well clad, (but all kinds of hats and belts) wanting money; but Major Grey o/s of Mena would not give order (overbearing manner spoils good attempts - act as sponsor for them - get pay from Col Farr - find 80 or 90 waiting below address them - get them money - also from Farr - (almost a mutiny at Pay office) Send for Adrian Knox for "object lesson" - but away at Alex. Two cases from Helwan Board (papers lost) also well clad - tell me "shorts and shorts now given to most there."

New Red Cross box sent around - the double naming of B removed - better contents - but "all have to sign for them" including officers - still no tooth brushes, very poor nail brushes, still advertising card Martin's, Ryan's, and my name added - (bombastic and little)
Entry.142: - sarcastic command all around (my name at least without my sanction). Hospital full, but not too full of wounded (apparently our worst cases always intercepted at Alex and treated by the British). At Lemnos No 3 A.G.H. not ready!! Porter (Admiralty) has the right to upset Army (Baptie) .. result, disorganization - ships ordered to wait - when full, to unload patients for ammunition - not to take on board patients waiting on beach &c -- sad news of errors at the front, great losses
Entry.143: Light Horse all gone - earlier troops to be given a spell.
Entry.144:
Red Cross Meeting Shephards 5 p.m. (1) Clothing - Knox evidently prepared and hostile though polite. Leane gives no help - No letter from Sellheim - B. silent and depressed. Know "not interfere with the military" - wants written statement from G. O/C. I explain. Martin jumps on my "men out today without clothes. Says 50 suits kept ready in stock". I quote Sister, point out "suits in stock" - those General Spens wont have on healthy trainees - already suitable suits at Mena and Helwan - Belt, hat and shoes - want Spens suits extended to approved patients, and Red Cross to supply what is wanting. Knox says "O/C can requisition leave it to him" - point out O/C may see men out in streets, gardens, etc, still in pyjamas - requisitions may be dilatory, or hostile. Finally decided if O.C. requisitioned, we could get convalescent suits like Spens, and Red Cross would add what was still necessary - Still - about hats. Leane says - can supply helmets - we want soft ones (2) Re B's Red Cross Box, show the box with advertising cards - B's name twice on it - poor contents - suggest better. Knox strongly support Souvenir



(The Comforts Fund was established to supply comforts, and financed from Australia - It supplied 2AGH (our hospital) with all its cigarettes and tobacco, until the Red Cross Boxes with Card appeared about mid July (250 boxes for 600 patients,) and 300 hats etc - Luna Park with Chairs etc, and provincial hospitals with many comforts. Besides leading Cairo people, it had 4 Australians - Mrs Chisholm Mrs and Miss Christian and Miss Towndey on its Committee.)
Further letter to Australia, and to the High Commissioner showing conditions at the Front, in Hospitals and on Transports.

Allmy letters to Lady Helen -sent also to High Commissioner"


Red Cross
 -£164. for Major Read on Themistocles. B. had sent him 700 kitbags and heavy clothes. - regarding me asthe live wire Read telephone me through Mrs. R. (the O/C why not through me). Went to depot as urgent (the boat being at Suez ready to depart) I add 700 slippers, 2000 pkts of cigarettes, buy 700 suits, 50 pipes, 50 desk chairs etc.

MISSING PAGES.
Vide a.b.c. appended

Knox strongly supports 
SouvenirPost Card and handkerchief
 - decided to omit B's Advertising Card and add to Contents (3) Pay Accounts, including my£750 - but in future "only after Knox's approval" (4) Secretary - "All time stenographer and typist". 
Office
 at Headquarters with Central Depot. (B. away early as he dined Maxwell, Ford, Williams) - but arranged "to dine with Knox" (5) Knox gives a list of what he was buying for Luna Park and Les Ateliers - "
after consulting with O/C
." (the routine way, regulationally correct but hitherto never actively taken up - left to taste, fancy and efforts of O/C.). (The List was just what Mrs. "C" had been calling for, and was already part providing) - now done, thus late - But if Knox buys on his own, will fall in (as our men did in Mess Hospital Rations etc.) - despite the desire of competent local gentlemen, like Mr. Delaney (manager of Anglo-Egyptian Bank) to give expert assistance etc - aggregating to the tune of ? Hundreds of Thousands of Pounds) - Had just told our O/C (jealous of Grey's new popularity) - that " he should get Mena suits. - if not he would be left behind" - Now send enteric patient boarded fro Australia into O/C's office to ask for "Convalescent uniform as at Mena" - As result O/C rushes to requisition: Then send a dozen others for the same, - with same result! Sicitur ad astra!

n addition

RESUME (contd.)

first to give comforts to sick and wounded, and send food and comforts to the front, and to give proper clothes to patients, outings on the Nile – croquet etc. Set going Club for the men. With Mrs C., helped individual soldiers to comforts etc. – Not a bad record. What is left? Nurses train fares and Nurses interchange (left the first to Colonel R. – always "going to do", but never done – until later – I took it in hand again – 
As regards the latter
 – no power, apparently nothing could be done – And yet they say M. is to be made Consulting Physician to the Forces – with a trip home! what has he done? – Efficiently, only his work as a senior physician to No. 1 A.G.H.and a weeks temporary O/C. Yet what matter – wants influence – he offends none – and attempts nil. I had rather do, than, non-doing – be promoted. I have my reward – everyone is telling me, I am looking years younger) "touch wood" Certainly I feel so.

Sep.14.

now
and
then
 – Add new departure for the British Army, our attempts – satisfactory through Waite – of special Ration to meet special need – if done great thing – what matter whether recognised or not through whom it came. Once 
a
 I used to think Recognition should follow, or even accompany good work, Now, – thanks to Egypt, – and advancing age – recognition may go to the devil. Thank the Lord, I am strong enough, and wise enough, to see it so. If only good results, what matters the channel – so may it ever be, so was it not always, alas! in the past; though never, so far as I can judge myself, (a difficult problem) never have I tried to take another's credit, either tacitly or openly. M. goes to England deservedly, as not well, officially and otherwise fit; But – no effort outside routine work, – good routine, – and no one's feathers ruffled. Ah! old Cheops, what matters a little later on!

Sep. 21 (ctd)
man of Medical Commission – just from the Front). He tells me his Commission has come to the same conclusion as I had viz. that the Health Question at the Firing Line is a question of Food, not Germs or Environment. Tell him what we had concluded, and what we had done, bring Waite and Sellheim to hear – and be strengthened – Promise Sellheim to give him a List of Suitable Foods – discuss them with Hunter – Give him a copy of my 
Text Book
, 
the only one I have with me

... !! if I had had a real chance! – 
Final result
 - Sellheim to establish a Dry Canteen at Anzac – pay the men once a fortnight – send special foods along with supplies Budden assisting (a) officially from and for the Commonwealth and (b) locally, as a keen impartial agent – Probably the most important thing I have helped in the War! The Prelude to Specialising in Preventative Medicine at the front from the Dietetic side. Some day there will be men selected for such special job and specialising also in Clothing Equipment, etc. Why not now!? Why not before now!? (ask Ford, Barrett and KR)

Entry.180:
Ask constructively, why not know "exactly if & when the depot at Lemnos had been really established etc. – All showing that , if they can they will make out the best possible Case for B – not for the tired soldier – I tell them I am proud of the men, not the opponent of B., and so on, showing my contention is correct – this Enquiry is to sub-ordinate the general issue to the personal, and going into the general only as far as the personal will permit and decide on the personal, and not on the general grounds – the cables show, Australia wants the general issue determined -– Was there Neglect, – if so, how much, and in what direction? and only quite secondarily, by Whom – Australia would not care if B and I. were both dead or unknown in the matter, Further showing the position remarkable, the President of an Executive, granting an Enquiry by its Secretary to examine a limited number of Charges against himself

1915.
and appointing a C to do it, whilst doing nothing to investigate the Unsatisfactory Conditions Generally

not

the

Tomorrow at nine, we enter on the last letter – Then the Charge "no time" owing to other duties" – Then witnesses Mrs C., Ward Boyce, Knox, Christian and Norris, Matrons, Gould, & Graham, Majors Zwar, Campbell, Blackney, Captains Tait, Loughman, McKenzie, Goldstein, Colonels Martin, Sir John Rogers, Ruffer, Hopkins, Moodie, Newmarch, Kennedy Tebbett. says "not know you" B. reply "but you might recognise my voice – throwing responsibility of disputed things on others – Even then "why didn't you come to me" resenting statistics, "no other medico available" – did it at tremendous cost to himself" and of the C – And finally – refusing to let me call Matron Graham to show Brown had lied or to recall Mrs C. to rebut so many pains had been taken, So nothing done by me since the 19th – no Hospital work – no rides before breakfast – daily preparation of case (and my own lawyer against a Judge)

 where asked "could B do it all satisfactorily"

Nov. 12.
The Enquiry ended with a short Summary from each of us (for mine vide Appendix). 
B. self sought, and stayed
, "regretting the trouble he had caused them" I – "thanking them for the extended hearing – the short-hand notes will not be ready for ten days – the judge – capped all.

and Conterato

Sent letter to Lady H by Argyle re the Enquiry – "personal not general, (B's not Australia's) – evidence, not on oath, limited to my letters, but including the unpublished ones – material subjects and witnesses left out – proceedings unusual – instead of my writing to Australia, asked, "Why not ask him" (i.e., do his job – and that, after it had been neglected) - "laying a trap", when he was not doing what he said he always did – declining to call material witnesses until forced by the threat of going out – the Judge going round two Hospitals with the chief witness for the defence – refusing to let Mrs. C. be other than my witness. " B. sending 30 page summary of his version to Australia beforehand, and me forbidden – and evidence with-held per contra. – (such when fighting authority) also note praising the Red Cross Commissioners and their work – administration and results now satisfactory to Australia. B. flouting the Minister of Defence – ("come to Australia and justice done") – boarded to England by Manifold and C.Ryan (?) – further typed copies of evidence stopped (now B. has gone and his 30 page Summary in Australia) (I did not see the rest until the following August in Alix.) With Budden – to see Sellheim re getting to Anzac as export Food Adviser – ask O/C for leave – he is willing, but Selheim (agreed afterwards)

 22
Under me at Ghezireh Gen Legge a patient – Fetherston arrives – Howse says he will not accept D.M.S. unless he has sufficient powers. (could afterwards find no evidence he ever used them)

 29
