1915
Entry.189:
2.
Vide Letter 30 with Colonel Laing to Leeson, from Maxwell through Ford – Selheim and Martin re newspaper articles – As before, suspected and accused, without justification.
Entry.190:
Reply to D.M.S. "contents noted". There must be some misunderstanding – have always been familiar with amended. Paragraph referred to, and have always been careful not to infringe the Regulation am at a loss therefore to understand, why the memo has been passed to me for "information and further guidance" (delayed answer – until the "Age" and "Argus" reporters returning to Australia get away, – as they might be stopped and lose their boat.

Dec.6.
Arrange to go home as S.M.O. Cable "leaving end of December" – 2 Convoys from Anzac sentry frozen to death. Millard Johnson buried to the neck and dies of Asphyxia – Said it would "cost 1,500 and all the guns" to get away – Sutherland invalided – Embling on transport dutyand Nash our Senior Surgeon in the last ship. General Wallack Col Hearne. Huxtable etc. patients – House agreeable to my making a Report when I get back – Fetherston says "I may be useful re R.S." O/C says the same "re Nash" – ...
 M.L.C. ... threatened him
. Mrs Brookes says I will have a warm welcome – Budden sails from Alex without a convoy with his "Xmas Billies" and gifts – Canteen at Lemnos doing well – "to start one at Anzac" -- Fetherston says B. is doomed at the 
War Office
 – wanted to get there first – "see his face" when F told him that he was going that day". Legge and Bryant boarded for Australia.
Entry.191:
Go through the Museum for the last time – What a memory of Amenophis "the Magnificent" and Queen Thy of Hatasou and DahrielBahri – Ramases and Seti of Akhnaton and the Pyramid builders, Temples, Tombs and Mummies ancient Jewelry, and the Sacred Boat Hathor and the Gods, of all the endless efforts after immortality and works of art over 6000 years old, What a place and What a memory! Afternoon tea at the Continental, where the Orchestra plays perfect music (often I gave them a Benedictine) – to Mormaracchis – Artemes engaged to "S. of Snowy River". plans for house and store for the Canteen at Mudros – then to Groppis, where nurses, officers, men, Syrians, Greeks and Gippies sit sipping coffee and tea and talking soft nothings – with Hell outside – Back to the Dahabeyah with old Nile flowing magnetically past Eugenie's Palace, and under the Boulak Bridge. – And soon Home! after a years absence – What a time – ¼ of a century seems crowded into 12 months. – 12 months of the greatest, the most damnable war, our Planet has ever known. – Australia's entry into the Company of Nations – no finer entry in all history, But at what cost, past present, and to come Perhaps, worst of all, utterly undeserved and unnecessary in many ways – yet to have leapt into Nationhood, Brotherhood and Sacrafice at one bound. The "little Australian" of the football ground, the cricket field, the Melbourne Cup, 
and
 who thinks of them now, except to pity and scorn. Henceforth, the first families, the people who count, the people apart, are those who have thought, aided in the great war – worked in some way, – with the usual army of rotters amonst them, placing ease, and security and selfishness before even humanity, And what varieties of service what unexpected signs of Australian resource, determination, pluck and imperial kinship! Only one thing remains – to see it through, for all sakes – personal up to common humanity. To all who have helped – leaders who have led, those who have subscribed of their abundance, the multitude of wives, mothers and sisters, who have slaved so hard and continuously, in almost every home from Leeuwin to Cape York – above all with boundless gratitude. sympathy and pity to the fallen, numbered by the thousands – the pick of Australia in their prime – to the sick and wounded, numbered by the ten thousands, and the innumerable hearts and homes desolate but sanctified by a grief too deep for workds – What a year. Never can Australia see its like again.

 12.
To Barrage Gardens – Mr. and Mrs. Draper at home for the last time – have been Host and Hostess to 600 Australians – from Birdwood to Private McKechnie – (with letters from both). Final dinners Mrs. Brooks, Mrs. C. Mrs. Hans Clover etc. – To Budden's Depot – he got away with 2000 cases – 3000 more to follow – A returned M.O. (re the English) "the aristocracy pouring out blood like water – the working men coming in splendidly, but the middle class self satisfied "not good enough for officers dissatisfied to be privates" It is the Australians that are the advanced British – "Britishers living in a bet-

Dec.12.
ter climate". from the adventurous and the courageous developing in the purest of atmospheres, and most helpful of surroundings – Rather interesting – Draper of the Barrage – Mrs. B. (of Melbourne) Sisters returning, and quite a lot of others speak more highly of what I have attempted to do, and have done, than I had imagined – can honestly say this phase has never been before me, much less influenced me – Thank Heaven for it, I go back satisfied, and prepared to say that anyone that comes out with recognition in his mind, should never be put into very responsible positions. At a crisis, even in ordinary operations he may follow a course of action, for self not for the Commonwealth, and that way may, and after does, lie disaster. Once I regarded ambition as a regal attribute. Milton was far keener and truer in penning "By which sin fell the Angels" – and if Angels, how much more men! Do! work's the thing – the doing is its own reward, its true reward. Disconnect the two – and "what price, effort?" How few have any real say in status, place, opportunity, surroundings, result? One is killed, another, with no further desert, gains a V.C. how many deserve the D.S.O., yet never get it, – The only sound thing is – to do as Carlyle said "the job nearest to you", and to your best ability" If reward comes, take it thankfully, humbly and remembering how unlucky many, at least equallly deserving, have been. Do.! Your own memory of the act will remain, the effects will remain – even others may recognise – what bother if they don't. Did you do it for that?.

Dec.15
Lady Allen writes from Melbourne "grateful for the account of the way the men received the Xmas Red Cross presents being sent out" (interesting when Lady Helen calls me outsider etc etc)

Dec.17.
Sisters Samsing and Kitchen at Groppis, (Mudros, Malta, England Salonika,) corroborate the tale of muddle and neglect – at the landing on Sulva thousands lying on beach and inlandeven when on board, 48 hours waiting for sailing orders, "behind the Arragon's typewriter" Kent Hughes v. Sir G Porter, K.H. telling him what he thought of him, and promising to bring it under the notice of the War Office (Porter soon afterwards removed) – Also men in London "foodless on the embankment" until Grace Watson to the rescue. At Salonika only one line of railway for communication. "£800 in cash each trip before use!" General W met at Alexandria "no place for you" – cabled for "Surgeon General" and got exit Ford always one higher in rank – R.A.M.C. versus us – in same position – always fought I.M.S. and beat them – Evacuating Anzac – Legge anxious – no news from the front for 10 days.

Dec.19.
..
. Sun to the Nile wonders of Egypt
.
Looking from Dahabeyah over the Nile – the Turneresque Symphony in silver – through glasses the definition of details and appearance of yellow and browns high up – a number of clouds touched at the top with snow, awaiting the sun – lower down, the mist fleeing, and, on the horizon, above Mokatram Hills a reddening coppery plaque where Ra is to rise, – gradually His Majesty – gives notice – peeps, and appears, the rim suggestive of the glory that follows – until in orbed splendour – effusing a golden air all round, Ra is there, - and it is Day.
Mrs. Hornblower gives me one of the Comfort Fund Anzac Marches
Entry.192:
– design a title page – profits to the Red Cross. (Both sound well, but Allan's of Melbourne did not care to publish)

Dec.21
No boat for 10 days – that means Christmas here. Arrange to decorate my Ward "J" – Brown and I give£3. Statts Prince Egyptian£7.10/- for sports. Letter from Budden – heart-broken, held up for fortnight at Mudros – taken over 2385 cases – repacks 250. (held up for Evacuation – gives them – at Mudros) 
Best news since Anzac April 25t
h – at 6 p.m.Legge "We've pulled out, from Anzac and Suvla, without any loss of men or guns" – instead of 20,000 men and allowed guns" – Thank Heaven – and good generalship or good luck – or both – so ends Anzac. Manhood for Empire when threatened – What a record for a young Nation – the youngest on entry into the war, – pluck, resource, endurance without boast, without complaint, ending in failure? No.! an object lesson to the world, a standard for Australia – an almost impossible position, taken and held for eight months, against 20,000 better armed, better equipped Turks, saving Egypt from attack and helping Russia – twice, at least, despite all, succeeding, had their
Entry.193: efforts been supported as promised – asked to do the impossible – and done again, and again – the initial dash more than equalled by succeeding attacks, against machine guns and modern entrenchments – culminating in the "Lone Pine" and the "Charge of the Light Horse" – decimated by disease, under constant shell fire, grenades, shrapnel and light explosives, – and pulled out because they would be practically annilated by the Austrian big guns, and in winter – such winter – transport could notgo forward – out, not because they wanted to ("evacuation impossible" said Ian Hamilton, yet the impossible happened). But the effect? Who cares – the memory of the performance rings on – they can be more useful elsewhere.
Entry.194:
The news in the papers – the best – the only Xmas present worth thanking, for the troops, for us, for Australia.
Buddens goods (which he cried over –) will now reach them – at Mudros not Anzac. The men regretful, until told our opinion, then glad, yet sad. In Australia, thousands of mothers, wives, fathers, sisters and friends will eat their Xmas dinner thankfully, will bend the knee, because of this – All devised, planned and executed in Australia's heart. Thank Heaven for our pulling out.
Entry.195:
Round the wards, viewing decorations prepared by the men under the Sisters. Hospital Red Cross Depot under Mrs Fletcher (one of our fighters manageress in each Hospital) prepares gifts. Knox and Brookes come with Xmas cards – ladies preparing gifts for neglected units.
Actually rained hard this afternoon
(? the first since last Xmas when the troops arrived)
Entry.196: Xmas at Ghezireh – Draper sent a van load of flowers and foliage. The boys ransacked the gardens. All Wards were decorated; now we have the heart for it. Lots of visitors; prizes for the best – Ghezireh placed first, Les Ateliers second, our "J" ward, first of all. Take notes for Lady Allen, and flashlight photos.Present the sisters with present from men and orderlies – cut the cake etc. All Officers, Staff and Patients receive Red Cross Box. Xmas Tree in Hall – Evening – dine at Shepheards - Hall and piazza crowded with Khaki - many fresh from Anzac. Table to ourselves, "like Brussels before Waterloo". All Australian Officers called on by General Spens (car on fire, and ? disturbance) "Auld Lang Syne" upstairs, – and end of a Perfect Day).
Entry.197:
After Xmas and a real Xmas feeling – Funeral of LieutMacArthur – in old Cairo – his brother Officers from Maadi – the two lines of firing party, with reversed arms, as stern and motionless as statues. "The Last Post" – the Last Salute – and exit. Sheila Chisholm's wedding – at Shepheards – under crossed swords – as a contrast. Give 
our
 over wards and officers to Gordon (
full Surgeon in the Melbourne
; on the beach at Anzac almost all the time and far from well. (no furlough. further work in France & England – one of the best)
 ..
. McCormack ... medical duty
Entry.198:
Goodbye to Abdul-Hussein-Pootoomut – talks with Pope, Williams, Legge, Howse, Quick, Wallack, Newmarch, Tait and Hurley. Afternoon tea on Dahabeyah with Mrs. C. Mrs. Monas, Haran, Garside, Brooks etc. "Queen Alexandra" nurses give us a dinner at Continental (as we had done them in Melbourne)

 30th
Lunch with Antill – get his account of the withdrawal.

 31.
First and last New Year's Eve in Cairo the wonderful. Dine with Watson and Cudmore. A few words with Sellhein and Chandos "brief for the men every time" – pickets everywhere in the streets – in both – 3000 men in the gardens – said "fear of the men attacking Shepheard's" – Dance at Shepheards, worthy of its reputation – at 11.50 welcome the New Year in, in the Mess..

1916
Entry.199: Round saying Goodbye – see Monash – get his account of the flitting – whilst he is having his bath. Tea with nurses at Groppu's – after dinner to Continental and Shepheards – Waite, Legge, Caruthers etc. So, Goodbye to Cairo.
Entry.200: Leave Ghezireh soon after 9 – final cheer from nurses and men. Poor arrangements at Station – Suez about dusk – last night in Egypt – on S.S."Ulysses".
Entry.201: Face Australiawards. RETROSPECT. After 12 months Active Service – feel like a soldier – nothing to equal a real soldier in War Time – no one, if good, can do more good, no-one more harm, if inefficient – feel that there has been no sufficiently organising brain – no sufficient nexus between parts – execution frequently ineffective, even utterly inadequate – few fired with the spirit of instant thorough self-sacrifice – few with heart and brain attuned to the great issue – few getting out of routine, even if keen – whole sections making a profession of it, looking askance, even hostile at all outsiders; even kindred brothers in arms – as a result 12 months chaos – much ineffable loss – signs of improvement – we win, largely because we cannot lose – not because we deserve to win. And yet, many stand out, individually – almost all the rank and file are heroes, all the Sisters Florence Nightingales, some of the Officers fine – what an epic – from
Entry.202:
to Dec. 20th – what places – Egypt, Anzac.

Personally, what has it not all taught me – what have not I attempted, in and out of "my job" – with what glorious reward in the minds and hearts of patients, nurses, leaders. What associations formed – problems seen open – men of all kinds meeting problems of all kinds – in different ways; men overcoming, defying, crushed by destiny – what vistas now military from Cheops to Mehemet Ali; Pasha, from Abu Roash to Karnac; how forget Ra, Ramses, Akhanaton, Hatasou, Old Father Nile, Saladin, the Mosques, the our "Sabiha" and Hussein – overcoat-piercing cold on the road to Mena to 3½ months shirtless – stay at Ghezireh - the of Cairo – the beauty of Egyptian skies - the placid green of the fields and the Old Testament everywhere – the simple inhabitants run to seed – the majestic Nile – the smiling sky – the glorious Sun – Egypt the unforgetable.

Appointed to 
charge of Red Cross
 on the "Ullysses". Splendid assistant – Inventory – Arrange the work. (evidently Red X here trusted me)
Entry.203:
Certified within 48 hours of leaving Suez – "every patient on board was fully supplied with pyjamas, shoes, tobacco, cigarettes, pipes, tooth paste, brush, games, lounge suits etc (Compare with Storey, Moodie, Read etc. accounts as to their ships)

Jan.6.
Prizes for Comic Recitation, Serious Recitation, Song, Piano, best short incident, best short poem, further distribution of handkerchiefs,
Entry.204: of cigarettes. Begin repurchases by the men at Colombo (their own money)
Entry.205:
Red Cross going on all right – system of Prizes for various Games.

Jan.11
Sister says "never seen Red Cross so well distributed" (praise my Executive Officer). (different views & methods to B)

Jan.14.
 Officers and Sisters Reports – Draw up Reports – re Red Cross with 5 suggestions – not having sufficient Red Cross Goods, arrange through O/C and Matron to replenish at Colombo. (do so – all official, yet afterwards in London, called on for explanation!)

Jan.5.
 Get£25. through the Transport Officer (also Red Cross representative) one of the best. so good/useful that retained in Colombo. though a Combatant Officer, and lost his chances of "own job", promotion etc Give guarantee for£7.12s to one firm and the rest to Smith Campbell and Co.
Entry.206: Last night the officers left the men outside, not inside, the wharf gates- (just a little neglect) a few got off and got drunk (nothing is a trifle!) O.C. annoyed and dis-appointed, yet, simultaneous arrival of crowd from the "Demosthenes" upset the arrangements, and explicit instructions "in charge until on the boat" had not been given - So being a good fellow- he read them a homily, then tore up the crime sheet.
Entry.207: During the week busy writing account of the Evacuation, writing most of each day - read Bean's account- quite unworthy- hope to get mine in first- will telegraph from Fremantle. Wondering if extra action is of any value - surely progress depends upon it, even though it is one sided, wrong and personal. No praise to me (my nature - and follow my line of least resistance) has only good come of my extra effort? Surely- in lunacy, in nursing, in dentistry, in massage, and many other minor points, before the war,andin the war? Most say so, though the authorities regard me as dangerous and officious.
Entry.208: Time will show. I have ideas Which I hope to bring before those who can do. If I were only in the position of the man who could! What a scheme all round I would draft, with the help of others - and what a messif I had no power! Yet after what I HAVE done in the past I might be able to make something good.
Entry.209:
Having my article typed.

Jan.27.
To be censored. The ship's Censor - Major MacDonald wont take the responsibility. The W.A.Censor to decide.

Jan.28.
Australia through the glasses, about 10 a.m.- alongside soon after lunch -- up to Perth to see Censor - not at home - leave article with Deputy- have to motor back - news by papers- Martin C.M.G.- B."completely exonerated" by Committee - Red Cross Brigadiers under 45.

Jan.30
Seen Bean's account- no thrill- no fire, no enthusiasm - looking back- Lord Roberts re unpreparedness justified- voluntary enlistment wonderful, but somecompulsion needed to bring in those who should come but would not. Absence of public spirit - not unnatural - when neither education, nor custom attempts to train a sense of public duty. Citizenship should be one of the fundamentals of public education, Muddle flamed out, patent to all inefficiency in high places -- staff incompetent,careless,selfish, want of organizatien of pre-vision, flexibility appalling- incredible- if not experienced
Entry.210: Sight Victorian land - throat cold - sign that Melbourne is nigh - read my account of Anzac-- great success. several copying it - wonder how much the censor sent on.
Entry.211:
Everything packed up early - pass Lorne - Queenscliff - up S. channel - alongside - four hours waiting - 8 hours disinfecting (how different to the other side!) Brodie tells me "The Age" sold out by eleven a.m.- great coup" off in car - Home. Back in Victoria





1916
Entry.212:
Reported to P.M.O. – "A fortnight's leave" – Find the women everywhere enthusiastic - the "Fathers' Association" full of the true spirit – but too many eligible young men at the theatres, in flannels going for Sunday outings, motor drives with girls in trams, on St. Kilda's Beach. etc. – Receive, personally, an extraordinary welcome – told by many of returned men coming up to "Salute my House" – able to tell, again and again, of what Australia has done at the Front – 28 different meetings and gatherings etc.
Paper before the Medical Society on Twelve Months' Service at the Front." – See the Minister of Defence – to Report through D.G.M.S. "on anything I want to say of conditions" – Takes me three weeks – 19 pages – with Addenda, Reports Memos etc. – Finished
Entry.214: Send in Report to Minister through D.G.M.S. – See P.M.O. – my name just struck off as "Finished Service" and "Discharged" – Memo recalled – See D.G.M.S. – In less than ¼ of an hour offered S.M.O. in H.T.S. "Orsova" – returning on
Entry.215:
with 1500 men – my future, to be in hands of our D.M.S. Egypt – D.G.M.S. "no objection to his making me a Consulting Physician," but "not wise to push it from Melbourne – Write the Minister – Reply on morning of sailing "thanking, and good wishes".
 
(Hoax)
Entry.216: In the papers "Argus" – Official account of Receipt from Sir Henry McMahon of the "Satisfactory result of the Egyptian Enquiry" wrote the Argus – was at B's request into charges against himself, that no enquiry had been held into actual conditions, that Knox had declined to make
Entry.217:
investigation of facts – "that all our Suggestons had been adopted, and our Supporters were acting in all Red Cross Depots" – Then motor to the wharf – Goodbyes, Farewells and Au Revoirs – and out once more into the world of action.
(having been married the previous evening) 
... 
time it was established ... left the same day.
Entry.218:
Getting under way – call the 26 M.O.'s together (only two on the boat ahead (the "Anchises") – with 1600 aboard and none but the ships doctor on the one following (the "Malwa") with 400 troops and 1000 passengers) – strange distribution. Got names, Dates of qualifications, Hospital Service and Special Fitness – appoint Ferguson, Rynhar, and McIntosh assistants, draw up Syllabus of Work – appoint for Duties (1) Orderly Officers (2) officers for Hospital work, Medical Surgical, Infectious, V.D., Sanitary – Vaccination – (3) Instructional in Hygiene – 
Use of Field Dressings
, V.D. etc. – Find Cases of Diphtheria and Mumps – isolate – arrange Hospital Duties Matron and Nurses – appoint Officer in Charge of Red Cross – Y.M.C.A. and two Chaplains in charge of Circulating Library – and appoint Sports Committee – Round with O/C, Troops, and Captain on Visit of Inspection – No Dentist on board – one Aviation man – a dentist, – but the O/C will not permit using him.
...
 as I knew first time ... taught the use of Field dressings etc though plenty ... time – of great value
Entry.219: Establishing our Routine – Duties of Sanitary Officer – Reports General and Specific, Daily – 20 M.O.'s to give instruction to 1400 men on Field Dressings and immediate Treatment of wounds, Fractures, Insensibility, etc. as per Ambulance Syllabus 1st time I believe on Record on any boat – First ship's Concert – what a sight of youth, adventurous, patriotic, brave and hopeful.
Entry.220: Address the M.O's on Condition in Egypt "not ready" "prove fitness" "Regulations not Facts" "Red Tab go betweens" etc. –getting our machine going – Vaccinating all contacts – Stripping all to the waist – List of Men not inoculated against Typhoid etc. – No time, so far, to think, except when in bed – Feel as if beginning my career again – can eliminate self – be broader and fairer in judgements and, Thank Heaven – no physical incapacity – What the coming year has in store, I cannot tell – if only I can do something worth that is all.
Entry.221:
Routine begins – M.O.'s first Physical Drill – then to examine every man stripped to the waist for rash or notable sickness (so to Sick Parade) – and twice a week half an hour's instruction to 70 each in Field Dressing, First Aid, Personal Health, – by V.D. Another instructs the Orderlies, and the 20 stretcher bearers – Sanitary Officer draws up one General Report – then to make a Daily Report on Ventilation and maximum Air Space – Lower deck to be quite free for

1916
Entry.222:
a specified time daily –Y.M.C.A – and chaplains at work as Lending Library – Red Cross Officer and man, getting ready – Matron and M.O.'s to have List of things available – (confined to the sick, as we have a dry canteen on board) – Men drilling attending instruction, etc. – Wire Perth "Case of Small-pox or Syphilis – uncertain – landing Freemantle, certain in Diagnosis
(Turns out to be Tertiary Syphilis)
Entry.223:
Freemantle – outside the breakwater – Officer takes off our three cases.

 22
 Clean Ship for Colombo –
Entry.224:
Sports Meeting in the afternoon.

 23
 Our twenty make a start at Lecturing at 3 – Groups of men all over the deck – yet word of mouth only the sign post to knowledge – each must not only hear, but apprehend, store, recall and utilise.

 24
 Hose bath for all in the morning – No fresh illness – all activities in full swing – first Boxing Contest – huge excited gathering.

 25
 Hose bath at 6, 7.45a.m. not utilised – to be compulsory bathing – "skins clean as knives and forks" – three cases of Pediculosis – Isolation – cleaning of closet seats – Evening Concert – memorable night.

 27
 Give the "Evacuation of Anzac" to the men – sea of attentive faces."

 31

Entry.225:
Indian Ocean -–calm as a millpond.

 4
 Number of throat cases – some 30 Mumps – no Measles.

 8
 Once again in the Red Sea.

 11
 Writing Reports on the voyage for D.M.S., A.I.F. Egypt.

 12
 Suez – Khamsoon blowing.

 15
 Report myself to D.M.S. – all in a tale of flux – bases not fixed – no special duty for me – "to No. 3 A.G.H. at Abbassia as "Supernumerary" meantime

 20
 See Sollhein – place my case before D.M.S.in writing – he is off to England – Birdwood and White ahead of time to intercept Prime Minister – seek of K re "total removal of our men from Egypt" – Monash and Antill still on Canal with
Entry.227: Division and L.H. (4th and 5th leaving June). A new Cairo! Ford gone, Maxwell gone, B. exit from us, but "consulting Aurist to the British" –
Entry.229: Div and N.Z. gone – No. 1 and 2 A.G.H. gone, doctors, nurses and all – Cairo denuded of soldiers after dark – camp 70 miles away – only 10% off at a time, procuresses warned off – mounted patrol preventing entrance to "Out of bounds" streets – shops shutting up – some gone away – Santi "no business doing" – lot of women gone – Cairo generally feeling the loss of the Australians. – Soldiers' Club remodelled, costing£14 a month, instead of B's£30 a week – self-supporting under the Y.M.C.A. and ladies (mostly N.Z.) fair attendance of the men – and very grateful – Buffet enlarged (Santi's not used) – Both Nurses and Soldiers admitted – new Anzac Hostel opened at the Bourse – under H.Q.and Col McAnderson and Baillieu – just the thing – meet trains from Ismalia about 12 p.m. – 400 beds, baths, cafe etc. – an Imperial Nurses Club ( Pasha's Palace) Abbassia, also capital – more Summer treatment – ? any more Summer Troops (unfortunately not so) – evacuating Hospitals as fast as possible – What a change! Almost all we fought for, now carried out – But – 12 months after we tried to do it – Luna Park (much improved) still open under Lt. Col Lindsay Webb – Antill getting an awning in 24 hours – now getting everything (owing to Adrian Knox and our efforts) – no pyjama clad crowds – Maudsley, Millard, Newmarch, full Colonels; Gray, Summons, Gordon and other Lt.Cols.
Entry.230:
McLean, Hurley, McKenzie, Bond, Tait, etc. Majors; and 
my place
 in No. 2 A.G.H. (away in France) filled by Dick (ordered home, but – never gone). O/C Martin's brother in law, and all interests conserved, O/Cat Rouen.

 Thus, through my trip home, I have lost my place and preferment, if not promotion – struck off here, though I wrote to D.G.M.S. and told the C/C I was coming back if I could, and would have been back within the three months had I not been three weeks Reporting to the Minister – Hard - but the fortunes of War – still, had I known, I would have gone – and I am glad I went – Re the future? Who knows? Have told D.M.S. that I can do more preventatively consultantly or in organising and D.G.M.S. had sent me out knowing I had lost my place – Apparently there is nothing – But there may be when things settle – Well!I'm out for Service – not recognition & I think I have deserved favourable consideration, but the Inner Circle have the inside running, and swing together. ... Home ever give fair consideration? It seems not. – I suppose most of my work for the men was outside officialdom – so as "extramural" not recognised – even perhaps antagonistic. So be it – I should have preferred to have greater official chances of good work – If that is denied me – I must do my Routine as well as I can, and, any outside good I can – the past is buried, but here will almost certainly be new things, new situations, and new need for good work. This is the penalty of outside work – I accept it – Per contra I may "Subtend too great an angle as Moloney once said – By way of compensation – whether or no. I know what I have tried to do, what those working with me will think of it, and how the men concerned appreciate it. If only I can, in new ways, help similarly, I shall be more than satisfied. Just now it is rather a lonely position – perhaps it may be less so when I join the No. 2 A.G.H. as a "supernumerary" – again an 
outsider
 as I was 
to
 at start with 
at
 No. 2 A.G.H.

Monash, Antill and Mrs. C. appreciated my article on Anzac very much Five little scraps by Anthill's men – 80 miles out – wants me to go out – get the local colour, and write it up (has to be postponed, and never came off).

 21
Out to Haswell's at Maadi – he reminds me how Cairo is "notorious for white washing" – so frequent that they think nothing of it – also that the British Officials are frightfully jealous of the Australians, – so much so that he despairs of their reputation for justice. Surely we must have struck a bad patch.

 22
 To No. 3 A.G.H. – Abbassia – new Hospital – just got ready – 
O/C
 tells me I was credited with blackguarding his management of No. 2 A.G.H – of which I had never even heard before – I enlightened him.

 24
To Anzac Hostel – preparing for Anzac Day – have written article for the"AAC" "The New Cairo" – left it with Anderson to censor and forward as he thought fit – met Ovens – now a General – he touched my shoulder and said "There is room for something more here". So there is – but I expect nothing – Note men in from Ismalia clad in old heavy Winter suits – they have khaki drill in the desert, but are not permitted to wear it in Cairo – though over 100 deg in the shade!!! Also 50 remounts with 6 officers returning to Australia on
Entry.231:
– yet 25% are "fit for the firing line, perhaps 50% of the rest for Lines of Communication". So, releasing fit men – yet back they go, regulationally "to Australia" though men are wanted and recruiting slack! (Whose fault?) (just routine way & routine job)
.
.. Mrs Samuels successful transferred to Horseferry Road

Anzac day in Cairo – to the Hostel – Welsh Fusileers Band play to Old Cairo – 700 wreaths placed on A & N.Z. graves, one on each – continuous Concert in the afternoon – and in the Evening Band, Boxing etc.

Major Gray – now O/C of Sporting Club, – gives me the results of his Investigations re Mess Contracts – our 15 piastres (20 at Mena) have been reduced by the British to 11½ and 8 (Officers) a loss to us of some ("have given Executive our loss on horse food, on loose

1916
Entry.232:
Contracts with Ras el Tin and Heliopolis – and the regret of leading Cairo business men that they were never utilised though they would gladly have helped). (The total waste known only to a few ? ever divulged)

 27
Write Judge Kershaw,
for third time
, for Copy of Evidence of Enquiry – Lunch at No. 3 A.G.H. – Stawell wants to return to Australia and me to take his place. – glad of the chance.

 28
First day at No. 3 A.G.H. – apparently good Hospital Wards – but – the surroundings!! 
Quite unsuited for treatment and Convalescence. 
N. O/Cself-opinioned and difficult manner – both Stawell and Morton getting away. N blackguards "The Age" and authorities equally, and supports Matrons Bell and Knowles equally – My room clean – but dark – opening into kitchen annex, and windows away from the wind – Hospital doing little – nothing but sand all round! Are there no places pleasant like the British Red Cross Hospital at Gizereh. N. said " selected it – buildings will do, but water supply defective" – Environment sand, and they say £30000 for alterations – simply damnable how expense multiplies. (Officials placed in positions, because of seniority, not fitness – may administer – anything!

 30
Still sick & many upset by the Mess food.
Entry.233:
Boarding case with Stawell – round Warnock's Asylum – 1300 cases – see cases of Pellagra – free use of Hashish and Datura amongst Gippies.

 3
Ryan and Maudsley off to London (our new base). Howse also gone – Col Gray ordered to report to D.M.S. Egypt (Sexton) through English A.D.M.S. – ignoring our A.D.M.S. Millard – Gray says "we have only power of internals, – none re policy or externals" (and yet it was to secure this that we fought for Howse!) Largely our own fault, we've let ourselves be thrown into any corner – Matron says "at Lemnos our nurses second fiddle in everything, tents not huts, dirty Tommies for us, our clean Australians for them – all ready for them – nil for us" – sick of such British "Fairplay" and Australian subservience – (keep well in with those above "the axiom" of Officialdom)

...
 the carcase is ... eagles & other birds gather
Millard also off to London -–These the times I feel sorry I haven't a better position (a) Massage - still let slide (b) Dentistry – still quite insufficient (c) our men still in Flander's Winter suits – "go as you like" in Hospitals, (d) Instructions to approach British D.M.S. through British A.D.M.S., (e) 30 nurses to go back – simply because not wanted here – and not enough in France. (f) quite inadequate Transport supply – Patients waiting 6 weeks to months before they get away – Expenses, irritation unfairness, finally becomes unnecessary (g) Loss of Contracts – no action taken, – (h) Still many in Egypt for 12 months – But who cares – "Red Tabs" have no complaints to make".

 5
I can see what an infinitely strong wise man is wanted here, what a serried defence and selfish intent is behind those who know – why a leader wants his own man – as "Kitcheners men" – how one fails, after sporadic successes – and the poor pawn! the fighting man! – God help them! For me one half an hour's work and then free to do nil – into Cairo to see McAnderson – tell him about Millard - see Millard – tell him about difficulties and delays – meet British Major - Consulting Aurist – his yarn of Lady McMahon and B. "is that the man we helped!" (B had blocked return of one well known to Lady McM – he alters his opinion – when she tackles him)

 6
Mc Anderson also going – looks as if we've won the War Office – as we would have won here, if only we had stuck up for our rights – Still only our men in thick clothing – no Convalescent Home for our officers (save a few allowed us, at Ras El Tin) – we pay at Montazah but the British rule and they fire out anyone able to walk – McAndersons successful fight for Anzac Hostel a shining example of how to win.

 7
Since Mena and Cape Hellas, little but defeats! now – "The Yeomanry" – Middlesex – so called by one of our men – caught in the desert in featherbeds, Brussels Carpets and golf sticks – and no outposts! Looks as if many British officers pride themselves on not knowing their job, regard girl-play as their ideal, have no initiative or resource and are so self-satisfied that nothing can pierce their
Entry.234:
hide – yet, courageous to a 
sense
 degree but too often, towards inferiors, justice and courtesy don't exist – So are the many, yet many others act very differently. Unfortunately, many of ours follow the British Official lead – Had I only the opportunity I could place massage and dentistry on a proper footing of efficiency, properly clothe our men, have transports enough and adequately supplied, our own Convalescent Hospitals for our officers and men, see we were not pushed everywhere into second place, place our Contracts in business hands, by a system of best service for each, and not monotonous sameness for all. But – there is no place for such with us – supply "Regulationally carried on". If world makers are conducted with no more foresight or Commonsense, one can understand the intolerably slow uplift of the world; Evening-time at Shepheards with Gen Irving (off home, he thinks for "next Division", but really because of the desert Route March in which two-thirds of the men fall gasping on the sand from the heat, marching and absence of water – some say "his fault" - others Roth, others Mclay), – complaining Mclay's treatment – Matron Conyers also returning for a spell. She tells me (1) no more training in Egypt, (2) large hospitals for us in France (3) ? England for No. 3 A.G.H., (4) Staff "not off for ten days" – Maudsley cautious and canny – says nil – not even answers to my letter re my replacing him 
t
here he is – Stawell off in a few weeks – wants me to take his work.

 9
Says Weigall "The price Egypt paid for the ideals of Akhnaton was no less than complete loss of his dominions". Poor idealists! Yes, – but is Egypt any the worse to-day? And though Akhnaton died a complete failure, what a glory now attached to his name! Where is the measuring rod in Time, Space or perceived result with which to measure effort and attempt? Add limitations, Deficiencies, and the Personal Equation, and – poor idealist, where art thou? Thou, and thy puny imperfectly conceived, often misdirected ideas! Better, one would say, see only a little, and hit hard against that one enemy. Is that after all why so many good men attempt so little? Are they right? Even now Akhnaton eludes our criticism and but raises once more the eternal question which as yet has no answer". So says Weigall – but I place myself on the side of those who say "Yes" to making the attempt – Mine also perhaps, – longo intervallo – to go down, still attempting (apparently as I have officially) and listen to the other side! Is it nothing that so many as Draper reminded me yesterday, from Australian sources that so many of all ranks thank me for my little Egyptian attempts, nothing that I have in myself the knowledge that I did help, I gained sympathy, comfort, recognition and treatment – 
for them
 – For me it has been worth it all a thousand times over.
Entry.235:
Entertainer in Cairo - from England. 
Knowles
 off next week – between May and November of last year organised some 200 Concerts and Recitals with his party – did more by his singing in an hour than many of us did in a month – Men slept better and felt better – taken out of themselves – When will H.Q. learn the value of such recreational methods (The answer came later in France, – but why delayed so long?)

 11
 A Padre gives me the true history of the Lone Pine – The Artillery fire ineffective (that on the Right – not firing at all –) and ceased before the time, Col "boys, you've ten minutes to live I'll lead you" – Being killed, no one to stop the second line, so it also went to its death. Brazier, lending the third rushed to H.Q., was ordered to "go on" - but countermanded the fourth line, – and was sent back, or resigned, (Is it true? Again, was anyone punished?)

C.Ryan made C.B. – so much for Distinction – P.M.O. in Melbourne left, – instead of staying (either he or General W?) – no status in Egypt – so appointed M.O. to Birdwood – all to do – Anzac for a few days photographing the armistice – week on transport with dubious status – very ill in Cairo – England and back – Consulting Surgeon – Besides work, on board with Col Manifold – ask anyone, how it was performed – to the detriment of how many! So C.B. and he says the Sultan promises him another – and he is after my poor Ambulance Ribb and also, Such is recognition in the Army. (Is it fair? is it worth while?).

1916
Entry.236:
12
Both Consultants, and Chief Matron off on
Entry.237: - Stawell in the Ballarat - ? 14 days - Said to be 1000 deserters at large - ? how much due to continued training in the sand, the heat and the flies, and no consideration - to catch them, "all leave stopped for a week" - very hot day 108 degs. in shade - Alix- where we should be - 82o.
Entry.238: Khamseen day T.116 deg. in the corridor - but good enough for patients and convalescents.
Entry.239:
...years Lee F...therapeutics in Melb . I would have.... a 4th years ....really supported such

Another scorcher T.116 deg.in the sun in the central square - cook an egg in the sand - Fancy a hospital in such a place - and sand all around - and dysentery and similar cases sent in to treatment - difficult enough for healthy people, taking care, to keep well - but no place for treatment and almost impossible to C
onvalesce
 - Letter from 'Summons (No.1.A.G.H. in South of France) lamenting - "nothing to do - same want of provision and co-ordination - blames the same R.A.M.C." - One almost despairs of officialdom - give me the free criticism of Australia every time, before the inherited grab and governance of the average British Official - we are restive, only beginners - we would break out now, if we only knew how. They don't think of breaking, and, apparently, have not learnt how, even after centuries - Truly real leaders of big things are scarce - in Army matters, at any rate - governing has been almost a perquisite of the upper classes, - and where has it got to.? (If the "under dog" only knew, as we do!)
Entry.240:
108o deg. on the verandah - still sweltering - in bed all afternoon, in a singlet - Cinema 
"Privates not admitted
" - Padre tells me of little lapses of discipline in many direction of saluting (recent order out). As one said, "tired of saluting Junior Officers who pay no attention" - if only officers showed the proper spirit - the matter rightly explained to the men, and judiciously but firmly carried out, and provision made for recreational needs, we would have a fine disciplined and happy army.
Entry.241:
Nothing to do but one hour's Boarding - the place simply goes on of its own momentum - the Wards (outside Routine Visits) left to their own devices - no Psycho-therapy attempted - environment, sand - no push no go, or uplift - no excitement or interest - atmosphere of "scientific stagnation" - Yet authorities quite satisfied - under "skilled routine run in blinkers" - making Reports on Reports, but ignoring the humanities as scientific poison - I, - poor unscientific I, - feel the reaction, all the more since I, "a supernumerary" - can do nothing.

C.B. ceased - To 11.0 - Red Cross - Comforts Fund - Budden back - Sister Green (acting for Matron Conyers) - comments on the unfairness - "only Transport Sisters decorated - sent to R.A.M.C. as "juniors and less needed in our Hospitals", whilst the best Sister, such as we had at Mona received nothing (our Authorities don't mind. but the sisters' relatives wonder - and object)
Entry.242: Instances of Chaos, etc., accumulating - Millard's going leaves us without even an A.D.M.S. - Capt. now Major McKenzie acts - without status - yet there are 30,000Troops, and six to seven hospitals - Maudsley and Ryan also go - and no, even acting, Consultants - either there are duties for such, or there are not. - Again entirely under the R.A.M.C. - and a Ship's Captain - noA.D.M.S. or D.M.S., or Consultant - is the one who "objects to taking really sick men through the Red Sea and Indian Ocean, in the monsoons "- Apparently we don't - Too sick for words. Failing to get satisfaction from Judge Keishaw, after three letters send a registered letter to Sir Henry McMahon re my Copy of the evidence in the B. enquiry. (never yet seen)
Entry.243:
To V.D. Hospital - see Arthur Morris - 5300 patients since January 26th, - 1100 in at present - up to 2000, when less urgency in sending out physically - fit but half cured cases - said to be double the British amount. Causes? (1) more money, (2) more virile, (3) more enterprising (4) more in Cairo. Many quite ignorant - authorities no consideration - for so long, no Hostel, bad Liquor, open brothels - even, when "out of bounds", only so to 
troops
, not to 
patients
 - (the same old story).





1916
Entry.244: Hard at it Boarding - congenial worker in Stawell - get him to join me in to o/c re (a) Delay in acting on Board decisions, (b) advisability of extending findings, so as to include Change to Alix and England as well as to Australia, (c) Improved Board Papers - our own, and not simply British - easy to frame, better. - Shorter and more economical, (d) Better Provision forConvalescence of our own Officers and Men - Yes - but why not done by proper authorities, and where are the D.M.S., A.D.M.S. Consultants, etc., who have let things go, and said nothing - Article of Phillip Gibbs in "The Daily Chronicle" on the humane influence of surroundings bears out unconsciously the whole of my contention - our men could have had, and should have had, more of the humanities, and Nature (why not, until towards the end, Was no one sufficiently intelligent, or farseeing or interested?). (I can see no explanation other than leaving all to Seniors who did not know - or even think along such lines)
Entry.245: V.D. Hospital - According to Bray, 46 per cent gonococcic, 46 per centChancroid, syphilis,
Entry.246: Stationary Tel.El.Kebir, the Registrar tells me that of 30 000troops, there had been 7 000 treated as patients (many slight cases, sent in by inexperienced MO's) 130 heatstroke on the hot day and 120 a day later (grave comment on selection of such a place as Camp and Training Ground).
Entry.247: At Shepheards, No. 2NZ MO's share my views, - but think that NZ worse than us.
Entry.248: Hard at it with Boards - clearing all out - But no strong man insisting on Transport - 1200 waiting since February - We simply don't count - except to fight - but - who cares - who even have we in authority here? Everyone I speak to, sick of it - Who is not?
Entry.249:
A British Q.M. here as patient from Tel el Kebir, with Insolatiasaid re the way the men were treated "atrocious" - no British would be asked to do it - Worked 6-9, 10-12, 2-4 like horses - the same thing, over and over again - simply march out, dig a few trenches - and march back - on a sand hill all the time - the M.O.'s mind to Claire - It was at time 123 deg. in the shade and 180 deg. in the sun - In 1889 the British troopswere in Abbassia (our present hospital), but confined to barracks all day, and no training in the summer" - and where in the name of Heaven are our leaders - Humanity is dead in the Army - brains, where they exist, seem paralysed - Asked why am I finding out, and talking of those things? Because - I am interested - no one else does it - it ought to be done - the men deserve it - Interesting to sum up psychologically the different attitudes(a) the Ryan type, (b) the Maudsley type, (c) the Ross, McKenzie type (d) ourPathologists' typesatisfied with his own job, its utility and novelty, doing it splendidly, but leaving all to others, and my
own type
.
Entry.250:
Q.M. SabineLuna Park tells me there were 1300 in Luna Park last December - there are today 983. - 50/ fit and running about - yet, all "to return to Australia" - at Alix yesterday, there were 7 Hospital ships, and one had been there for four months. Many cases - such as - Enteric and Gonococcic - need never have been "boarded for Australia" - many others became practically well whilst waiting - but on they were sent.
 
(Good old Routine)

... fall a victim
Acute chill causing inflammation of Pelvis of Left Kidney, with partial blockage of water, and Acure Hydronephrosis - in Hospital until
Entry.251: - weather very hot, up to 100 degrees in the shade. - find, in myself, how unsuitable such a place for acute illness and convalescence, despite ideal treatment from Stawell, Martin and Sisters. (only saved from Australia by Martin's diagnosis)
Entry.253: Narrow escape of Boarding to Australia, recurrence of symptoms, from surf bathing too soon. Finally boarded "for England for two months" - will be glad to leave Egypt, sustained summer heat. Last month every day above 94 degs. 19 above 100 degrees, 9 above 104 degs. and 6 above 110 degrees, - tired, also, of want of consideration of our men.
Entry.254: Back to Ras el Tin "for the next boat".
Entry.255: The first day really enjoyed lunch. Since I was taken ill.
Entry.256: O/C tells me "to go to England tomorrow". Countermanded the same afternoon by D.D.M.S., Cairo "not to go or leave pending furter directions."
Entry.257: Gray off with 1601 reinforcements - would have swum after them if I could have got a place - not well, and idle - so, worried and depressed but much more, not only from my own position and environment, but the way the boys have been treated, the muddle, the inefficiency, the absence of consideration, plan, provision preventative and human supervision - Candidly I only envy others in command, because, on routine, they do so little, practically nothing. If all had been going well, I would have rejoiced, and never minded how small my part - but so much going ill, and I could do nothing - that's perhapsmy vulnerability yielded - for the first time.
Entry.258: Great news of our boys at Pozieres
Entry.259:
2, 3, 4,
At Residency - making extracts from the High Commissioner's copy of Kershaw's Enquiry - the only copy in Egypt - See it myself for the first time - make a Summary to send to Australia.
Entry.260: First Responsible Work for Two Months - "acting O/C during B's absence." to just a handful of Convalescents.
Entry.261: Ras el Tin deserted, 92 to Montazeh - just a few officers left.
Entry.262: News - I am to "go back to Abbassia - To Cairo. See D.D.M.S. "knows nil". "no definite information" - who and why directing my movements unknown - probably Howse - apparently answer to McKenzie "if well, keep him". Back to Ras el Tin.
Entry.263:
Off Home
 - how the miracle occurred I do not know, - but O/C gave me in writing "from A.D.M.S. A.I.F."off by Kanowna" - perhaps from D.M.S. Egypt, in answer to my letter (asking if I get to England) of
Entry.264: However it is, glad and grateful.
Entry.268: Gib. in sight about 12.30 under the lee of Isle of Wight, Southampton, London, to No.1 London General. Very kind, attentive. with me. A pleasant time
Entry.269: Boarded on my birthday - To H.O. - See Howse, Giblin, Sellhein, Budden etc. - given "Leave till the 25th."
Entry.271: Visit to Scotland and North of England - 14 - 25 in and around London
Entry.273:
- Leave address meantime " - Visit Monash at Salisbury Plain - witness review by the King. (who says "when I think of all the boys have gone through my heart is in my mouth and I can scarcely speak")

30

Introduction to 
General Keogh
 - very cordially received - given special introductions to Special Cardiac Orthopaedic, Neurological and Rheumatoid Hospitals. 
(
able, courteous, broad views, advise I successful) one of my best "finds" of the War
Entry.275:
To Denmark Hill - (4th London General) - the new
 
Maudsley for Neurological Cases - 160beds under Mott. - round with him, and hear his Views - ? ? too many - good for observers, and visitors
 
- bad for patients.





1916
Entry.276: To Shepherd's Bush. (Orthopaedic - Massage - Electrical, Orthopaedic.) splendid work. - pioneer under Robert Jones etc - East London
Entry.277: To Rheumatic and Rheumatoid - cases at Hill End. - afternoon, Cardiac cases, at Hampstead under Osler, Allbutt, McKenzie, etc. go through their Methods with Captain Inger, - Excellent, commonsense and effective.
Entry.278: To Queen's Square. Paralytic Epileptic - most of Staff away at the war. so little doing from my point of view
Entry.279: Again to Hampstead - leave my Text Book for McKenzie to see my cardiac graphic recording - get Scheme of Graduated Exercises and Method of using - no drugs, except as last resort - practically no Cardiographs - Afternoon to Roehampton Hospital for the Limbless - get their Scheme of Educational Reconstruction - 550 In-patients - 4,000 waiting - 4,000 gone through - 1,000 in good situations - splendid - Suggest aluminium and pulpedwood. (to lessen the weight of artificial limbs)
Entry.280:
Letter from D.M.S. - "Report at Dartford". - Report same afternoon. O/C wants me to organise electrical massage, and orthopaedic Departments - not wanted for a few days.

Col.Powell SI
Entry.281: Second visit to Shepherds Bush - shown the new development of utilising Work as Incentive and Curative as well as Educational, etc. - already using tailoring, Bootmaking, Gardening, Clerical, Carpentry, Painters, Machinery, Surface Cleansing, Batmen, Orderlies, - more repairing than making. Modus, Volunteers given privileges (Khaki, passes, etc). Results - more cheerful, reliant, obedient, quicker boarded, socially great improvement- Most of credit due to Captan Hill - See Electrician - got List for Dartford - also Scheme of Record.
Entry.282: With introduction from Keogh - to Lt. Col.Webb - Sanitary and Statistical Division of Hospital Accommodation for information re "The Treatment of our Sick and Wounded". well received.
Entry.283: Spend the whole day writing article thereon.
Entry.284: To Dartford to begin work - Find Hospital - cost 168,000 pounds - splendidly equipped and furnished - should make it quite good if given what we want - draw up Temporary Suggestions on general lines.
Entry.285:
Examining re Equipment - Suggestions - (a) Massage - prepare form of work, (b) Gymnasium under trained instructor Fitzgerald - (left by the R.A.M.C.) - arrange General Exercise, Special for Heart Cases. List of Apparatus and Requirements, (c) Electrical - under our 
Captain Murray
 - 
Murray
 .. Electrician Melbourne Hospital ....now.....ordinary duties in Camps -
go through Requirements - prepare Form of Work, (d) Utilisation of patients for Work - sending actualities and modus as at Roehampton and Hammersmith - see our possibilities with carpenter, engineer, Q.M. Office, Barrack warder, (e) Psychical - give O/C copy of Begbie's article on Canadian Performances - also ask for 15-30 Masseurs - return from M.O.'s "man wanting (a), (b), and (c)" - suggest Murray and I visit Roehampton, Hammersmith and Mt Vernon - and Carpenter to go with us to Hammersmith to make a few gymnastic extra, or a fair start - M.O. 3 say 90 per cent of patients require such treatment - O/C more than sympathetic, but more than busy with the General Organisation (I do not think our other Auxiliary Hospitals had any such Scheme - if not, why not?). Letter from D.M.S. "Defence Department find you wrote "The New Cairo" article - calls attention to Regulation 453. - forbidden to write any more under pain of severe penalties - "initial and return".
(The article was sent through General McAnderson and, I suppose, further censored in Melbourne. It was true - but such is the official way of dealing with authorised correspondence. I protested - was told to "send anything further through the War Office" Thus ended my writing as Special Correspondent.)
​
inCairo







1916
Entry.286: Quite cold - find the value of the Radiators (next year the new O/C (Sutherland)cut them off, because of Expense) - getting things going - planning Exercise Generally.
Entry.287:
Arrange for our two Masseurs to visit to gain Knowledg
e
 Shepherd's Bush. Our Returns Massage 144. Electricity 18. Heart Exercises 67.
Entry.288: Settled (a) Murray in charge of Massage and Electrical Department with some beds. (b) Self in charge and M.O. of Neurological, Cardiac and Special Exercise Departments (the last "sent by the M.O.'s with weekly revisions by the Specialist". (c) Records, as at Shelpherd's Bush Etc. Afternoon - with Murray to Shepherd's Bush - most interesting - going the whole day - can go far on these lines.
Entry.289:

my two wards

Bryant & Maudsley -only 2
Consultants down - 50 cot &lower berth cases - (Physician's ) painstaking but slow, and not utilising available evidence

- good routine - no more - the world will never progress if only such - yet "Consultant and C.M.G." - what more do you want!
Entry.313: Tenting up Boarded Cases - also g 10 - Board down - 27 of mine - R. "off with Birdwood" before half done. (characteristic)
Entry.314:
from the front - quite knocked out - for the men every time. (as in Egypt where he sent back from camp cases R. had sent from hospital

to Mr Felstead to start action
Entry.315: Still Boarding - bad news from our men sent to Weymouth "conditions wretched".
Entry.316: Board - again down - 27 more were from A10 - B27, a mournful and unsuitable Sister - get her removed (the first time any such step by me).
Entry.317: Take quite a lot "at the front" - over 40 done.
Entry.318:
Some 40 of mine off on "Furlough" - As "only one furlough a man" - give "Sick Leave" instead, regarding both as Therapeutic Procedures, and trusting the men - explaining advising and suspending on his return. - Have not had a case requiring censure, - except one (Murphy amnestic - too risky). The more I see of the Regulational Treatment of the men, the less it seems just, necessary or advisable - it is shocking to men who have volunteered, and given up so much, if not all. And the cruel unnecessary difference made between Officers and Men - justifiable, only if they were a different and superior class of beings, and as if the Men did not deserve and could not be trusted. The result is they are denied justice, treated inconsiderately, harshly and unfairly and so almost induced to return badness for injustice and go to the devil. The cruelty, the irreparable loss of it, and the calm careless injurious way in which they are Boarded, the disability, often only half stated, at times not stated at all, e.g., one "Gastritis" Yes, but also shell shock 12 months ago knowing nil for a week, no memory of Home, sent "back to the front", another shell shock and burial without a note on his Board Paper and R. as final surgical Board running off for a trip, 
to Cobham Hall -
when only half through. even M. unless all the pertinent facts brought forward and how seldom they are, useless his finding, which further information might completely upset. Fancy Papers so and M.O.'s, if asked, not knowing, because never investigated, and even no regard to Diagnosis - who suffers? - Only the man who risked his all - And on goes H.Q. filling up Papers and carrying out Routine, well clad, well paid, in no danger, enjoying agood time
 
in the World's Capital and promoted and decorated!
Entry.319:
No. 2 A.G.H. have had a frightful time at Boulogne - in tents, no shelter, little comfort - piercing cold - No. 3 A.G.H. at Brighton - many complaints and 
M
. instead of P.R. no mean judge, - says we (Dartford) are the best off of all.

Entry.323:
We

(he and I) arrange (a) Red Cross Rooms near
 
Railway Station with waiting room, fire, coffee, etc. (nil before - simply stand and wait transport to Camp
 
in the cold at railway station after long journey) - he had alrady arranged for a Library 30 x 42, with books, etc. Store and Silence Room under Visiting Ladies Committee, and whatever we wanted to make dull huts attractive. (no wonder he is a success in business - as at the War)
Entry.324:
Consult with Murdoch, O/C (Betts) etc. - plan arranged - add myself, Sick Leave Extension Department, under Ladies and everything to make "the worst camp" like Home - see Betts S.M.O., sympathetic and ready for reform - already reported strongly - even visiting General Birrell (our Anzac Failure here in Command!!) Betts admits all 
my men

They had written to Sisters in my Wards - who gave me their letters -
had said re "Kept standing in the cold during examination" (being put right) "insufficient care in allotting duties." "need of more special treatment for special cases" we pointed out they had been there only a short time, found that they were becoming a 
Convalescent Hospital
 
Whose doing?
-

rather than a Depot, situation unsatisfactory - more anxious for the best way out - I told him of Shepherd's Bush, Roehampton, Mt Vernon and Dermark Hill - provided him with notes re? shell shock, and our cases would bring down 
different 
sufficient Notes for Continuity of Treatment - He would make special accommodation and Special Staff to carry on - Told him of Sick Leave and Furlough as Therapeutic Procedures - the Red Cross Offer of help - the Value and Way of making the two week's stay useful to his patients - Exercise for all - with Motive, Interest and Utility, so far as possible - to send him our Graduated Cardiac Exercises and Mode of Recording Results (more head fit) He had Massage Department and Competent physical instrucor - Good day work - back Dartford midnight (an illustration of how H.Q. let an Hospital "run itself".)
Entry.325:
Draw up Private Report to O/C re Weymouth - "visited to asertainthe facts owing to reports and statements affecting the future of our patients" - expanding and altering - now really a Convalescent Hospital - 2000 there "for months" - not "a camp for a few days prior to embarkation" - Betts reported against it - Spencer Brown Murdoch etc dissatisfied.

Complaints

Entry.336:
Thus we can now send on our Cases with confidence. (Yes - but why not all for'seen and done from H.Q.?).

Now D.M.S. a K.C.B. - told on all sides that the cases little for Hospitals and all for the Front - Remember advocating him in Egypt, but on my return found he let us get again under the R.A.M.C. and had not improved Hospital Conditions - simply replaced men - did



1917. 
notstand up for Australian interests where standing up was imperative - Here the same drifting - no general plan nor calling together, no proper inspection with recommendations, simply routine - the Consultants apparently simply final Boarders - Find our men of July last in British Hospitals everywhere, unvisited, coming here surgically after almost neglect (accompanied to Sutherland) and neurologically after no special treatment for months - (as I know myself) - Some waiting for months for transport - dissatisfied, forgotten, untreated to their own detriment and great cost, whilst others are sent back to the front with insufficient regard to their interests. Had we had the strong man we hoped for, he would have insisted and obtained ships - even our own boats taken and used beween Salonika and Alix! - H.Q. and so D.M.S. must be held responsible.
Entry.337: Said to be the coldest January for 36 years - never above freezing for days - not cold in our War Quarters - but in the Wards - yet muffler, Army overcoat, jacket, short cardigan, two undershirts, two underpants, with lined gloves keep me warm except ears and nose (Fancy patients without pyjamas, etc.)
Entry.338: Very cold - letter from Pte. E. Smith, No. 30 Hut, No. 4 company - 2 Command Depot Monte Video Camp (near Weymouth) "arrived back from furlough and to our surprise found things much better - We are now nice and comfortable - plenty of blankets, plenty to eat and nothing to do. - So Col. I think we got you to thank for that - all we have to do now is to wait for the boat".
Entry.339: Real snow, and snow bathing - collect , Exercise, Cardiac, Duties, etc. for Major Betts. (Weymouth)

Hut for tips re variations in Diet - get a number of good suggestions.
Entry.343: Try turned Salmon Rissoles one day - fried dripping Bread and Bacon.

Still they come - in mental Hell - What, when the big Offensive starts!

19
Preparing to get away batch of Shell Shocks - 9 x14 (long ago Boarded) a number last week to Weymouth - Boarding others, now chance of getting away without waiting months.

20
At it from 9 to 5.30 - see my 25 off - with proper histories, recommendations for Betts, etc. - some go ready for trip back - O/C worthily assisting - telegraphing for Howse on Sick Leave and Furlough.

Waterloo 
- Tea, cigarettes and fire at Red Cross Room Weymouth - Examined in warm rooms at Camp with tea after - Something like this time - why not always?

26
Letter from one at Camp

"no towel, no soap, etc." The same old want of consideration - No. 3 A.G.H. leaving Brighton for France - Owen following Pitcher, Chambers, etc. Sisters wanting to go - Certainly more here than needed - six British, ten French Armies straining at the leash - Was England ever greater? Was her danger ever greater? And glorious France behind 250 miles of front (British 123) - Our boys, ready to go in - our daily round and common task trivial in comparison.



1917

Skylarks rising from the bare earth - Fancy Dress Ball by Sisters - Glen Knight from the front, - nearly done - why not replaced long before! (Not as if exceptional - in my experience, the reverse)

To Denmark Hill - Mott's present view of Shell Shocks not capillary haemorrhage but more allied to acute traumatic neurasthenia, with hysteroid symptoms - quite a lot of the fallen combed in from various County Hospitals (Generally accepted such follow the confusional and so are more noticed after being invalided - 
at the front -

Entry.372: Perfect weather - saw my men off on "furlough" - 145 leave in all - how grateful for how little - appreciated - how much - for being humane - considerate and brotherly - Mrs. Osborne (of Goulburn) out with Y.M.C.A. to see for herself - with me to Pitts who had taken some of the boys out last week in drag (four) asked specifications for daily trips at hiring intervals, charge 1d. per head and they will make up the difference - Eureka - the Transport problem to and from the Hut solved - also probably daily trips to London paid for, etc. - What an advance and the boys are worth it - but fancy getting it.
Entry.373: Twenty of the unit paraded for "France via PerhamDowns - all this time of ease whilst others nearly done at the front - no Roster here either - Quite summer - almond and cherry blossoms and cuckoos! At lunch a Major

Entry.375:
Horse Transport for sick to Dartford and back arranged with Pitt - (a sort of unofficial party myself into it a Liaison officer I - with both Y.M.C.A. and Red Cross - to say nothing of other societies and workers - So far as I can discover, no such official with us - though recognised by the British - and much better nexus - if not official, with the Canadians, New Zealanders and South Africans than with us where - perhaps well for my reputation. I've been under orders - yet as this Diary can show, there are many things I know, would have tried, and might have done well worth doing - how many similarly placed). After all "the last resort of noble minds"

1917
Entry.376:
is not the highest thing. Service is the better part, and, in my little sphere, I really can claim to have done well - no doubt with limitations - but I have done my best.

(page seems to be missing here)
Entry.377: it was simply left to the outsiders to do a routine at the taste and fancy of an O/C who never regarded it as a duty - Our O/C was always sympathetic (and even initiative to some extent). Archdeacon Ward down to Lecture re V.D. to men going on furlough - well put - why not thus long ago (apparently V.D. singled out because it lessens Army efficiency - what is equally good from the man's point of view ignored).
Entry.378: Two more of our young men promoted - Browning and Meldrum - worthily - but? if more so, than many others, even with chance thrown in. Apparently I am one of the few, if not the only senior who came over in the Kyarra, and have stuck it since, that remains in statu quo aute - have I done less or some ill? No, but I've worked for the men and for their comfort, have "counted myself out" - What a man sows, that shall he reap, with time, luck, influence and push - and I know what I have sown and how.

1917
Entry.387: Third Medical talk with the Archdeacon "to the men on furlough" - going over to France on
Entry.389: AirRaid - all pass over our heads coming & going, but we are too little to notice - 15 machines - killed over 100 - One of our boys shot through the head - Sutherland (on the R.A.M.C.) "don't know - don't do - Won't try" - "trying to get on to France." himself.
Entry.390: S. all against the boys, - on unsupported private statements, against reliable evidence - obsessed - always, daily - Such one of the causes of the men's dissatisfaction - never believed - always suspect - We have our Baths now going - write O/C. re Contract - also Murdoch re Clothing - (something like Boy Scouts in place of thick Winter Flannel and serge.)
Entry.391:
Collecting Statistics on Head Cases -
Final Statistics for Paper on Heart Cases - O/C Powell promoted to No.1 A.G.H. Boulogne vice McLean returning - we will miss him - always considerate for Staff and obliging to patients - only wants initiative - yet so, less dangerous, and more acceptable to H.Q. - not told successor - Some expect me, but prefer 1st hand Work for 100 selected patients and "not the sort" to suit House and Co. - two sufficient reasons, even if no others - Apart from a position of initiative and foresight which I am not likely to get, more useful where I am - I've given up almost wishing to be a power in the War - perhaps well for my reputation that I've been under orders yet, as this Diary can show, there are many things I know, would have tried, and might have done, worth the doing. How many others similarly placed - after all "the last resort of noble minds is not the highest thing - Work is the thing - Service is "that better part which has not been taken from me."
Entry.392:
On with Statistics - Sending 20 to Weymouth - Tired of waiting for Maudsley "no sick leave" - call on Murdoch - "spending 7,000 pounds a month on our "prisoners - 3 weeks and no answer to his offer of a Motor for us - now Lady Chauffeur gone elsewhere - will furnish my Silence Room when an Inventory - will stick to his work so long as doing it, and not interfered with - told Birdwood and House so" - To Comfort 
Funds
Depot
Budden
) - agree with us - re want of consideration excessive call on our men - obey orders as re Petrol - use better - want a spell - get what you want, if you are firm - Mc Anderson an illustration - our men 8 times that of he Tommy - 5,000 casualties at one time last year - not fully disclosed - On to Anzac Buffet - the original - superseded by McAnderson - 2000,000 meals given.

Entry.396:
..had stated that ...% were "sent back to the front" ... authorities thought I was not doing ..what? was necessary in treating them. So I wanted to see 
what sort

(and Australia and home the best for them)

Missing pages -

25
Archdeacon Hare at the front - all Furlough and Weymouth men in theatre at 8.15 but no lecture (our O/C lacks initiative) - 17 of nine off, but 2 cots too hysteroid, and 2 others break down - write to Editor of Daily Mail to support Delmer's bona fides (at his suggestion). He had written re the Hun and Melbourne
Entry.397: Left with wards half empty - Registrar unnecessarily rough on men going for Passes (he has frontal sinus headache).
Entry.398:
Report of Commission on Mesopotamia - all round inconsideration the same want of prevision, insufficiency, callousness, &c., with the same absence of justification - when, if ever, ours comes out, it will be the same old tale - Amid the splendour of endurance and courage of the men, it makes one sick of the over-dog - much of the same old spirit still rules amidst considerable all round improvement - want of consideration dominant, personal injustice frequent, unnecessary sacrifice almost the rule - And yet the men obey and do - what greater euconium could they get - as ever, it is the common that is sublime.

28.Sick leave for our Cot cases
Entry.399:
days "till boat call". I get it altered to Furlough (gives ration allowance, and a
pull at their money) "if I guarantee their return on dates specified on their passes" (Just a few had overstayed or fallen sick) Exit O/C - off to new work - full of honors, and more to come - as he deserves.
Entry.400: All aghast at Mesopotamia Report - one "meddlesome and interfering faddist (Major Carter) apparently alone in protesting, against all opposition, at a cost and risk that I know so well - Deserved honor comes to him, now and for all time. What a story ours will be, writ as it should be - in sorrow and indignation - almost despair. Thank God I've tried to play a fair part in it. I too have paid the price - been refused the work I asked - and my second request - in writing - "to go to France and see the cases I am treating" - so far, without any reply - alone of all who came out in the Kyarra in statu in quo ante even technically lower - condemned by the whitewashing Egyptian Commission, and muzzled by the authorities - but with my recompense from the men.
Entry.401:
B 27 empty, and only 17 in A-10 - news that "Anzacs and all not going back to France" are "to return to Australia" - commonsense and humane - more considerate than H.Q. I fancy after the war, there will be an Enquiry into the treatment of our men here, and deservedly so - the want of Consideration, the Difficulty of getting money - the Surroundings of H.Q. even its dirt - the Dumping of men down - the methods of Boarding, the unjust Decisions, the useless Records, the absence of Supervision, the Delay in Transporting the detention at Weymouth for so long - the attitude of H.Q. towards the patient.

1917
Missing pages here
 –Take in 2 as pinned here
 
No such Enquiry – When I asked the Minister of Defence ... was to be readjustment not Reform (vide Correspondence)
As distinct from the fighter – the sending of Unfit men back from C.C.S. – back from Base, – from England, – its Cost financial and personal – the keeping the men so long there, and others continuously here – the unfairness, unnecessity and inhumanity of it all. I have written little and said nil re H.Q. but for serious omissions and Commissions in the above, they must be held responsible.
Entry.402:
Have placed my action re Gallipoli and Cairo in parallel columns with Carters in Mesopotamia – it differs only in local color and details. As a result of my work in Egypt, and reporting thereon I was sent downwards, not upwards – given a free hand by the O/C in my own position here – the present state is mine in toto – no thanks, no communications from H.Q. – except to cease Press Correspondence and explain Red Cross purchases at Colombo – never been to the office, except for pay – no Reply to request to further study in France (as refused permission for Special duty at Anzac) – all my work here, and for the men, without any official suggestion, or apparently knowledge – and without any recognition. I write this, as simply between me and the Department, – not of prime importance, but unfair and misleading – part of what thousands have suffered, are suffering and will suffer in this, as in every War – Mars and Venus here, as in Cairo – there – they burnt the Wazr, became doped and robbed – here – said to be 50 cases of doping – and Australians taking punishment into their own hands. Ye Gods! What a comment – contrast the more effective work of Munitions, other war workers, Y.M.C.A., Red Cross, etc. Against our Juggernaut, one is almost helpless, – except as doing his little bit, and keeping up the general spirit.
