1917
Entry.403:
A week since wrote re visit to France – no reply – Yet has any one in the A.I.F. more right to expect compliance, if no one there, why not? – if we have, why not??

 3
Little doing – Wards almost empty – patients still at Weymouth – better here. –

 5
Only one ward full.

 6
To National Baby week Exhibition – meeting on Midwives question give them out RVTNA procedures – many enquiries after.

 7
 
Aerodrome next our Hospital – at first – training ... fighting
.
Air Raid - some 50 planes – poor Salmon goes up, son of Dr Salmon – Ballarat – Just one against many Just a boy. Who let him go up? – and crashes to his death – Down to Great Bardfield to see one of my patients – in a Country Home – excellent.

 9.
Writing D.G.M.S. Australia – suggest a position like Sir John Collier's "Director of Neurasthenic Institutions".(No answer – never got a chance though, unofficially, I helped Minister of Repat and received his thanks.)

 10
Again apply "to go to France".

 11
Entry.404:
patients in B27 last night – out this morning – Is this the best possible? Keogh's orders to "rope in" – carried out, – but unsatisfactorily and no guarantee on patients are sent on to, or used on approved lines – Unsatisfactory all round. Our H.Q.had let some 12000 Australians accumulate in hundreds of Bristol Hospitals, until it passed all bounds –

 13
Evidence of Unsatisfactoriness and Unfairness of British Medical Boards (just as bad with us) accumulates on every side, the talk of the daily press – 2 Payment give outstanding reasons – secondary to Army aim – (more men) – and Army Procedure of the way to personal advance for all – But – the men! Afternoon – Mesopotamia debate in H of Commons – front row – L George v Asquith.

Sutherland "O/C" – intent on rapid move on of patients – Acting on Instructions – They say his billet depends on it – at lunch says "absurd, only sent a few today" – Reduces the Hospital to Clearing Station. the M.O.s to Clerks – and Patients to – Compulsory Travellers – like "no Sick Leave", indefensible.
H.Q.s reply to by request a curt "
not approved
" – write House unofficially to know why – My first request since I came here – Antill says "some one behind it all, – the penalty of trying to play the game and tell the truth" Almost incredible is it not? – Afternoon – to Southall to find out the position there – Only 550 beds, few medical, mainly surgical – amputation cases – send all else to Weymouth 3 times a week – at Weymouth up to 4000, and "only 7 medicos". (almost incredible – is it not ? – and yet all decorated!)

 17
At last decent Procedure re Medical Examinations – "authorised now go into whole Medical History – forced upon the R.A.M.C. but not followed by us – evidence before latest British Committee – what a Juggernaut the military machine becomes when in full swing – Capt Browning 
gives
 took part on the day of the Great Tel el Kebir March – kicked out for sticking up for the men – again before Pozieres – defied O/C for "frogmarching the unfit" and"if sick, no pay" – sent away – lots of men thus treated – but "not one in 20 M.O.s thus act."

 19
"Move on" Clause in operation – 
its good side
 – nears the man to his finality – specially valuable, – where the end is – "Australia" – and, now there are Transports in numbers (? from Australian insistance ?) – 
Larkin they say not H.Q
. What excuse for months of delay with Weymouth – under snow poorly furnished, and poorly provided with medicos!)the bad side – removes us (? the best A.A.H. ) – from much of its treatment value and efficiency – little Treatment for Senior Staff – best place replaced by worse – needed alterations in every direction possible – men "
glad to be once more in their own Hospital
" – after many months in British of all sorts – out next morning – as they say "change here for Waterloo, Weymouth and Woolloomooloo" – no sick leave granted – other leave minimised – less personal consideration in place of more.

 20
A10 – 7 vacant beds – "no sick leave" – B27 empty – to be used as "overflow Ward" – Reiach's View of things – "Since Egypt, bad management – almost incredible – when we think of what it was equal to doing.

1917
Entry.405:
always second place – Canada fought for, and gained hers – we, still secondary at the front, our Ambulances, Reiach ? in our Ambulance all the time he was in France, only receive the overflow, not their steady quota – and are split up, whenever such required, – over here House power, only over personal – selfish – unforgiving – aim Parliament and Minister for Defence – proceeds with this end in view – 8000 of our men now scattered through various British Hospitals – "must be got out" for the great casualties to come, and before the end of the year. 
Prophetic!
 We have the boot – so "all to Weymouth as fast as possible".
What matter "if we are scrapped as a Hospital, though best in buildings and second to none in Massage, electricity, Physiotherapy, etc., a good Staff, excellent Record for Work, and our Cardiac and Neurological cases treated on the best lines – Powell so instructed – not altogether agreeable – too influential to be made an enemy. 
What an indictment and what an amount of truth in it!
Entry.406:
after C.M.G. – long delayed – promoted full Colonel and sent to France. O/C No.1 A.G.H. Boulogne – 900 the week before he goes – part of the policy -–(including my unfit cases "for Australia" Sake "sent weeks before their time) Sutherland in his place, tho' others senior – only final, after interview with House, and accepting orders "clear out 1000 a week – Keep nothing beyond a few weeks, and only those, if absolutely necessary" – if he cannot, he goes: if the unit cannot, it is for S Plain – and another sent here". So R whose information is generally first-hand and straight. If so, Goodbye, apparently to my "congenial work", and the amount of efficiency that I have organised and promoted, Goodbye to the Hospital as a Hospital, only a Receiving Station, – and to be officered by men wanting a rest – Goodbye to the consideration we have been building up for the man – I must consider the situation and my future. R "thinks Ryan is also bought by position, and fear of influence – otherwise he must have gone – 
Housewas for sending him back – but he didn't 
– Maudsley is "no force" – Hurley "has all he wants" – promotion, F.R.C.S., Senior Surgeon, and full Colonel – Millard – from £500 a year, and vegetables "at Coast Hospital, "better pay and position than ever in his life, "and no good outside the marching" – the Rest don't count – says I can expect nothing from House – saw that from the way he spoke when we had an argument at Ghezireh, explains, why I am here, and in statu quo ante – R himself simply wants to complete his 3 years – such is official life in the Army! (as a good straight observer describes it)

 21
Entry.407:
at Cafe Monico – new Industrial League "to improve Relations between Employer and Employee – Hodge, Stanley, Roberts, etc – fine speeches (real attempt by both sides to get to bed rock)

 24
Maudsley down boarding – tell him re French visit "not approved" – ask him to support – will write him also, and keep a copy. 
never did anything no reply
 – Ryan not down – away "at a function". (one may fairly say – as usual – if there was a function to be at)

 25
Drastic change in Recruiting system "all taken out of Military hands and placed under Civilian authority" – 
AnotherEnglish Reform forced on the authorities
 – what a comment on Military Officialdom – and how deserved – its views of the soldier – no psychology no consideration, – a lower being – their treatment of him – their aloofness – their subservience to those above – their limited and movable responsibility – a tremendous indictment – proved by results. In this war, it has been, with few exceptions, the civilian and the outsider that has done things, and the official, that has botched them. Spowers just arrived – says "Karoola" sunk by the Huns with nurses – and patients – How hold any truck with such? – Browning,– 
turns out untrue.
 Stephens, and Fenwick to go to-morrow.

 26
"Karoola" safe – whose were the bodies of Nurses and Men? – Wrote again – unofficially – to House so as to get 
a written answer
. "Endurance advocated all round as the key of success.

 29
Matron Graham, 
formerly of Luna Park
, as Matron at Dartford arrives – one of the so few clean successful fighters since the days of the Adelaide Hospital dispute – one of my best witnesses in Egypt – left behind there – then to Australia – no recognition from us, but one from the French.

1917
Entry.408: The greatest push of all in the next few days – general confidence – 2 miles advance on 15 miles front – broke the last ridge and 5000 prisoners.
Entry.409:
When I am weak and foolish, I think of my seclusion here – the "Home of the tame dogs" from the number of Convalescing Medicos, – and my limited sphere – but when I remember the many who have given their lives, with no return, except the memory, – and what I have continuously tried to do, I am grateful at heart, and silent in action, – though it is unfair.

3
New Testament (according to Reiach) at the Front – "M.O's half time no work – our Hospitals, only the surplus, simply "pass on" – not one A.G.H.in England – Keogh made House "move on". "So many the next few months" – Powell had words and went. Sutherland (as Major) – clothes packed for the Front in P.A. - made O/C. - ordered "to keep up the stream" – "to go if he does not" – 1000 last week – 
Reiach again
 – went into wards, and struck off 35 himself – "no man to stay more than 3 weeks" – Dissatisfaction already with the M.O's Nurses, men – Reiach adds H. cunning and treacherous, all for money and advancement, no bowels, not a fresh brain – reads nothing outside Newspapers. Maudsley small official mind – no bowels, no vices. Ryan – simply does what he is told. Millard – weak, won't do anything. Morton – (one of Sydney's best surgeons went back after 12 months) utterly disgusted – the A.I.F.amateurs – mostly after self, don't know – R.A.M.C., (as I have stated elsewhere) – the greatest shame, the want of consideration and commonsense – not want of brains but consideration 
and
 no Napoleon – our hospital doomed – simply Clearing Station – no A.G.H. here - yet Golders 
Green offered
 – fine hospital – with this as Convalescent Home – no excuse! What a tale – and mostly true. – Am I doing all I can against it? I have opposed it all I can, and done the opposite in my own two Wards – have written Fetherston and Maudsley (unofficially) – have added what I could outside the hospital – put my hopes before House – in vain – galvanized Weymouth – been and optimist amongst pessimists, and supporter of Facts against Regulations? it is written suggestion and criticism that they fear – "Peace, – Silence – Routine" is all they want – Be busy there – Let Realities Justice and Reform go hang – What a tale!! (Will it ever be known? will it do any good if it is known – when all is over.)

 5
Afternoon to Golders Green – fine ideals – fine work. (Science / Humanity both)

 7
Run to Oxford – drive with Osler and Lady Osler – one of the best.

 11
To Stratford on Avon.

 14
Back again to Earth and Strife – Report of Committee of Public Accounts – "Eastern Command in the winter of 1915-1916 saved £416,000 in the cost of feeding by a Central Messing Scheme" – as against a loss of £140 000 in Egypt owing to lack of effective review – (corroborating what I told the Minister of Defence 18 months ago.)
Entry.410: Upjohn – now Lt Col here for F.R.C.S.– Padre Milne, Capt Spomers, and Capt Lemon gone – only Sutherland, Downing, Meldrum, Brown and self left of the old staff – new Matron Graham also, moving men rapidly from English Hospitals (mostly Keogh's insistence) – 21 of mine boarded – all "for Australia" – getting Statistics, Treating and Fixing Futures, – good if limited work – Morning with shell shocks – afternoon with Padre to Pitt re the Bus and Y.M.C.A. Hat re billiard table – Back I must go this year – the main need of staying gone – other claims insistent – never out of Khaki since
Entry.411:
– rejuvenated – better man now than I ever was – fit for better work – yet 62 in nine days.

 22
Millard down re shell shocks – never discussed on its merits – wants to minimise the value and necessity – had not read my Application – thought I wanted "a month there" – "not long enough to do good". Pointed out the delay in other Hospitals – now – not months ago – told him just what I thought – he said nothing – gave no indication as to what he would advise – no way to treat the subject, the men or me – typical second rate Official Treatment.

1917
Entry.412:
Fancy having to stand up for, and explain Request for Permission for Sick Leave for Special Shell Shock Cases and Special Private Houses: illustration the constant reflux of the official mind – vide Lumsten's Memo – The "Times" advocating such commonsense in suitable cases at suitable stage – meantime we are using our Pine Hospital and stafff as a Clearing Station – the splendid Australians that our neglect and lack of push and initiative have let accumulate in all sort of British Hospitals are not graded before leaving them, but shot here, then shot to Weymouth – which is not to compare with here – the usual senseless road to post-activity – Millard says "they are doing it – now" - Our staff is but an amateur imitating the British bureaucracy, and after Knocking out the Official Examination for entrance, a Commission is to forthwith proceed to France "to improve the use of Medical Men and Nurses – just as in Egypt! - round pegs in square holes, everywhere and to spare – Keogh has done magnificently + splendid Lieutenants, given or getting a chance (like Jones) have performed miracles, but, but, but we are the good old official step and men have been left stranded – chaos, inefficiency, inconsideration – till it smells too high, and some one – generally an outsider - makes them move – then, they move – usually halfpace wrong way – and claim all credit – no comprehensive Nexus at any time – perhaps too big for such – but surely not, if they had a big enough man or gave one the chance. I am dumbfounded at the Official Spirit and the Official Ways.

I should say that our H.Q. must be amongst the worst. Fancy the site of it – the surroundings of it – the unnecessary Congestion of it – the Hostel put in it – the absence of Cleansing, physical as well as moral – one board for all our men – no nexus between the places where the 6000 are – not me responsible for treatment – they doing it – Often not doing it – or doing it badly – no decent Records, when after up to 200 days, they do get under their own – no G.H. at all in England – rotten subterfuges most, no Visitation, no Control, Supervision, too large a Staff here – too small there – no permission for Local Initiative, blockage of the men in money and leave – no Official care of whereabouts of men or means allowed "in loco parentis" yet actually careless and inconsiderate gaolers – no roster of M.O.'s cable to replace the half dead at the front and "get the men back there", not "do your best for them here" – the letter of Obedience – not the Spirit of the forethought"! why, the word's out of place even to think. Do we wonder in what spirit they go back? All the moral sink, for which there is little official care, little for Comforts, pleasure, interest – bound in unnecessary fetters, and what wonder the more than dissatisfaction so prevalent and the bitter spirit in which they return. Something like a complete Revolution is wanted – a building up together – like the Organisation just started by the Service Members of the House of Commons when they got Home "Comrades of the Great War" (Unfortunately made political use of, but largely replaced by the Imperial League of the Returned Soldiers and Sailors by men themselves). Fancy a V.C. yesterday in London – his deed ringing everywhere – yet without a friend, and impatientlhy awaiting the end of his Leave! – the climax – Thank God. – of course there is another side – so great, so complex, so diffuse, that it makes us proud of our own race and confident of its future – But my contention is that the dark side has been so long, so unnecessarily, so expensively and so fatally dark – Compute it in terms of the bad and the unnecessary, and what a unavoidable, but individual discomfort neglect, and vice so unnecessary – and what can repay – ?

"Coming out" in full swing – the O/C Boards 30-40 a day himself – all that the Receiving Officer can bring himself to think (and he thinks officially of course) can be sent on after one night in this "Railway Station Rest House" of a Hospital, to go on without further ado – whilst Onions the 
Red Cross Enquiry Agent
, can scarcely keep pace with them, 
He told me so himself
, and out go the rest as fast as the M.O.'s can send them – speeded up by instructions, almost daily Memos and the active initiative, even interference of the O/C– our "1000 a week" (as per instructions) must be nearly kept up – And why all this? Past neglect – Is it best, even for the present? It seems impossible – but it shows activity, and numbers, and effort – the machine is running at high speed – What more do we want??

1917
Entry.413: In to Y.M.C.A. H.Q. - arrange for 500 of their cards specifying all the Huts, etc. in London open to our men - to be handed out to our patients by the Padre - Write Sargood re the continuance of our Motor Bus to station, and room for billiard table at Dartford Y.M.C.A. Hut.
Entry.414: Arrange my Silence Room for acute cases to rest in, away from ward noises, excitment, etc.
Entry.415: Off to Weymouth to have a look - Reach it in due course - find 3 - 4000 of our men spending 15/- to 40/- a week of our borrowed money- fine for convalescents in summer - Camp much improved - 10 Sisters 10 Masseurs, 10 wards of 20 beds each and Dressing Ward - Round with Betts - 2500 leaving - but rough crowded and unsatisfactory for less well cases than Dartford and Shell Shocks also better with us - O/C proud of reforms (till April - (end of winter) no lining to huts, - only one fireplace in each - water frozen - too cold - one "captain" in charge of Shell Shocks (undoing what we had been attempting) - Betts can give "sick leave" but "too risky" - and no arrangements made - See Mrs. Metcalfe - arrange for her to collaborate with Mrs. Spencer - Back to hotel - crowds of Australians in crowded cafes from a crowded camp- with few of the comforts even at the end of a year that the English start with - Yet the men, fine as paint, and every second man with a girl.!
Entry.416: Air raid at Chatham - easily heard overhead- 200 casualties - no harm to us (too insignificant) - but trouble to our Shell Shock cases (most raids with cotton wool in ears and quick hypnosis)
Entry.417:
Clark (Y.M.C.A.) out - explain (a) Motor Bus to station and proper use (b) Room at Hut for billiards (c) Silence Room - with him to local authorities - he will attend to (a) and (b), and furnish (c) - 
Matron Graham
 after Luna Park no place for her with us, no Enquiry and sent back - but given medal by the British for work at Shubra - Chief Matron Conyers going back for six months - her quarters at H.Q. disgraceful yet - she seems satisfied, and asks for nil.
 
Wonder if her attitude at ourEnquiry went against her
Entry.418: Cases from British Hospitals say, they (ie British Matrons) say "our Sisters not equal to looking after them" - hence sent on to us "only when sufficiently advanced to require no real nursing" (one other result of our neglect) - As a fact, we have more Sisters, generally better trained, with a better Staff, and at least an equal Hospital - many patients when they come show neglect in Records and Treatment and even bad results as stiff elbows, etc.
Entry.419: Write to D.M.S. re "sick leave for approved Shell Shock cases" - what will they do to find some departmental reason for maintaining their refusal? Case sent me from H.Q. for opinion (petit mal - post-epileptic automatism overstayed his leave) - the first ever sent me -? Is it remembrance or recognition - Munro of Sydney pays me a visit, admires our records and methods - more of my men get away to furlough.
Entry.420: Cable to Australia "after 10 months' charge Shell Shock and Cardiac cases willing return, organise department - have written" (believing that such cases would require special consideration when they get back, and no one might understand - with a wide opening for myself). (never any reply).
Entry.421: Geddes in Morning Post on "National Service" - recalls my plea in
Entry.422: "Serve - not Enlist" - another illustration of value of starting with a comprehensive plan - if we had done so, what had we not saved - why not done? Because bureaucracy rules - had its old antiquated precedent - no one else could move - all trusted it and with such failures as ever, up-to-date - That is why I said "Burn the Book of Regulations and start afresh - Facts v Regulations - but facts to win this time - Oh that I had a chance. Why not? Because I had not the prevision to go in for Defence earlier - HadI been second to the runaway - I might have been in Ps place.
Entry.423:
Getting on with Records and Statistics - full notes of some 300 Shell Shocks and some 200 Cardiacs. (House, later on said"would be very useful, after the war" but, no reply to my letter ... then use)

1917
Entry.424:
notyet diagnosed normal" so sent to special hospital for diagnosis treatedseriously. if + a wound - a ....stripe - and trip to Blighty. But worst cases were there without a wound.....Such misunderstood, neglected called "malingerers" a "mental" - when - neither
Tebbutt confirms my view of Front dealings with Shell Shocks "so many, that no time to diagnose even if able", M.O.'s not permitted to send back, except as "N.Y.D.N. (not? yet diagnosed normal) to special hospitals where, after from the front, they are diagnosed "Shell Shock - Sick", or "Shell Shock - Wounded" - or otherwise by experts (the difference being apparently because the wounded, and not the sick, were eligible for a "gold stripe" - strange discrimination - really however, the presence of a wound or even concussion minimised, even prevented the emotional phases of the true "Shell Shock" - to such an extent that for some time, the "Shell Shock" - Sick were considered and even dealt with as malingerers). (and at times, shot, but not in the .A.I.F.)
Entry.425:
Call in at Y.M.C.A. - also Overseas Club - the London map of the latter far superior - Asked Y.M.C.A. 
not
 overlap - Y.M.C.A. taking on Red Cross Transport preparation - In wards case of Shell Shock after Shell Shock - yet - kept at the front, emotional overthrow after overthrow - what will be the end? Also another at Netley two months - stammering, excitable, misunderstood, fighting against being considered "mad" - What a brain state, many - to my knowledge - have been diagnosed "mental" (and it takes months - even years - to get out of it). Another Air Raid.
...
 number such - in young ... (Ages 17-19) still under .... in Repat.Department
Entry.426:
Consultant Board down - too rapid work to be fair in all but slight cases - quite unequal to fair estimation of others - has to rely on what is told - then - where the authoritative action? M. makes Cot Cases of some of mine in three minutes - no time for others - so unfair - examines heart in non-heart case, through jacket - Rubbish! - altogether unworthy of the man and his position. Again, - no warning of visit - no fixed time - men away who should and would be seen, complain - no use - force no remedy - calling attention, no good - No answer yet re "Sick Leave to Shell Shocks" - no excuse for it - put up 15 pictures from Y.M.C.A. in Ward - sample games - Mars' danger from Venus even more than from Bellows and the cyclops - Canadian Major tells me he was accosted 23 times from Regent Street to Charing Cross in khaki - and not once in mufti - the Strand swarms with flappers - many diseased - and the usual British "do nothing" the treatment - the relationship of the sexes never so near bedrock - and never such need for recognition and wise guidance - instead - left to its own lines of progress.

what a contrast with Egypt!. Barrett .... do then. .. methods now ... Y.M.C.A. and Red Cross outvying each other. Just the antithesis!"
Entry.427:
Received from Y.M.C.A. - 1 set of bowls, 2 sets pictures, 1 Lounge, 1 Card Table, 2 Flats, 6 Cribbage - sample set of games - colour scheme in helping cure, A.D.M.S. (Millard) round in my absence to - looks at the time my cases are in - distrusts Sister re case of amnesia and finds his mistake; but no work about "Sick Leave" - simply an efficient regulationist in his light - no sympathy - no insight - Evening - another Air Raid.

Technically
 Red Cross work. But - the man wants - and deserves
Entry.428: Memo from D.M.A. - "charge against post-epileptic automatism case withdrawn - board for Australia". "Scored for once" says the Registrar - truthfully! (This man was up on a Crime Charge when - escapes - but how many punished and crime sheeted, without justification)
Entry.429: Another Air Raid - "defensive shrapnel" the danger in most - certainly for us.
Entry.430: Minister Hedge (civilian) says "No Shell Shock again to the Front" - what a time to learn the lesson! Another raid on in 4 lots - few shrapnel on the roof. (hide under a railway culvert until passed)
Entry.431:
Characteristic illustration of Army methods (1) Furlough - some (? how many) over in France 18 months before they got any - (left apparently largely to O/C and in local hands - often unjust, never scientific - on reaching London left to outside bodies to give information and assistance - no military clearing of whores and solicitants from railway stations, Strand, H.Q. etc. outside bodies take up the work - the authorities say that they"Provide fine lot of places " - Yes - but not officially - to the men - known. - "Provide fine maps" - Yes - but not found at the front or in the Hospitals - left to individual 
O/Cs to do what they like
 - no part of their regulational duty - many

..Bleft the Red X work in Egypt



1917
Entry.433: nil. To us, none sent, none utilised, until I looked it up. (1) offered to do this work when I cam here, but heard nothing more from the O/C – got Red Cross map – put up one in each Ward – got Padre to give them out at his addresses – got 1000 sent to our Registrar with nine to follow, – if asked for – slung into the wastepaper basket – O/C"knows nothing about it" Gives order "Padre to present them on Parade" – when men are sick of Official Orders of all kinds – So many still may leave the Hospital knowing nothing of where they are welcome, safe amongst friends, and made at home – and fall in with whores, etc (2) Much the same re Recreation and Amusement – now better at the Front (None at Mena) – Here – new orders "no Sick Leave" – why? "back by 4.30, if not a Special Privilege Pass" – thus, spoiling the work of the Y.M.C.A. Hut and stopping Visits like those to Stone Castle, where so many feel at home, – and, for no sufficient reason. (3) Still Rushing the Men Through – the average in Ward B27, 35 – out of 46 – going out for the past 7 weeks – And yet, the average stay in British Hospitals 50 days – in one 219 days! the "Rush" neglect go straight to Weymouth, but sent here without discrimination, the O/C cries "speed up" – where does treatment come in – and this perhaps the best Australian hospital in England:– Add the Consultants flying Visits like M's fast and R's almost "nil at all" – and where does Consideration for the men come in? It does not exist, officially – 14000 killed last month, 84000 casualties, Transport magnificent, Medical Convenience also: but all the rest as above – to be remedied? – Next Year, if the war goes on. But why not now and long before now?
Entry.434: Taking Histories and Boarding – find many fighting on where concussed, shell shocked and "scarce half the time themselves" So Reputations for Valour – and Condemnations for Disgrace – And yet I find many quite irresponsible – What must the Great Judge of All find with this omniscience and impartiality? Let Official Recognition be known for the poor half blind, half wrong thing it is – like the list of those who "refused to be vaccinated" at Gallipoli" getting French Decorations – by mistake! (The wrong list sent in – told me by Gen Monash)
Entry.435: Lots of Bowls come for patients – Wards look well with the pictures – "General Leave extended to 5.30" – result of my suggesting Y.M.C.A. Hut to write the O/C, Still "only 2 M.O.'s away each week end" – unnecessary and bad – Fancy 13 M.O's on Sunday on present sort of patients and no admissions -- No heaters at work – patients without pyjamas (because of expense of washing), no extra sheets, patients complaining and even we feel cold – what inconsideration. O/C up to H.Q. daily "getting orders certainly, curtailing all round. "H.Q.in a fearful state" says Major Reiach.
Entry.436: Consultants again down – the usual non-pioneer decisions – relying on others or insufficient warrant – R . a "Surgeon General" resigned given promotion – stays on as Surgeon General – of such is the Kingdom of – Officialdom! – Story of Dentist earning £3000 a year, trying in vain to serve as a Dentist – "no place" - but in 24 hours on 'Britiannia" place found by High Official, with teeth requiring attention – Such is Officialdom – Upjohn says "Australians are being cleared out of British Hospitals because they are too good an advertisement for men to go to Australia after the War." (Keogh's insistence more probable)
Entry.437:
Most of the men cold – very cold when at rest – O/C told Sister Keith "it cost £15 a day for heating – would put it on when he pleased" – In the neighouring Joyce Green Infectious Hospital 
British for smallpox
on eight months of the year! Still running patients through – 600 and over a week – O/C going in and picking them out – all M.O's dissatisfied – some asking for transfer – Powell's "Happy Family" gone. "He would listen to reason – S won't "says Sister K – and the patients suffer. British Commission returned from France – re "The Utilisation of Medical Men" ... to best English clinicians ... in France doing officially nil – No R.A.M.C. ... in Senior positions though only second raters at the start risen by Seniority – and "not to be employed again" on their record – For Kitchener's necessity. So ADMS told me. – usual chaotic condition (the same want of interchange with us, have always advocated a Roster but not heard of one. Reiach and Knight, – to quote only two – came to us nearly dead, nerves, heart, etc. from overlong work at the front. – Sutherland and heaps of others never got 
on way over
 away from England – the same with Nurses. tied in one place



1917
Entry.438:
when change would have been good and fair all round – One of my best sisters at Mena – Sister Robertson – sent to some small British Hospital in Lancashire, and, despite all appeals – from myself included – was kept there for ?18 months – favouritism, want of thought, or poor brains behind it all.

Col Hayward ceasing to be O/C of Wandsworth – (what a place in the winter!) (Ask the Nurses who had to work there) – going round speeding Australians out of British Hospitals – should like to know the real momentum? Keogh's insistence (it was he, apparently, not us, that sent back R Smith and Co. from Heliopolis)

When I called to see Keogh about permit to visit British Special Hospitals – whilst awaiting employment – August-November – I found there were pages of the Names of British Hospitals – all sorts from fine to bad – As invalids arrived from France at Southampton, a daily record of all Vacancies was automatically filled, regardless of anything, but a few Special cases, such as Neurological, Mental, Oral and Special Surgery, etc. progressively filled – our men were practically never sent to our Hospitals – even in France or England – we had no Hospital of our own for our Officers – though Canadians, New Zealanders, South Africans, and later on Americans had – And even my special attempts at treating War 'Neuroses' never received any official recognition, – to say nothing of sympathy – Why I have had cases from Denmark Hill sent there by Maudsley, – instead of direct to me, and when I saw D.M.S., he apparently knew nothing about such conditions. Still patients coming in often uncared for, and going out, just when they were hoping for a little Australian companionship and sympathy – After months and months of other Hospitals under Nurses in many cases, not too sympathetic, – and the patients are – our patriots.

 11
D.M.S. and A.D.M.S.down, simply to see, cases are run through as fast as possible -–in my Wards, simply asked "How long in" – "How long Boarded before sent out" – Saw only Boarded Cases! - Fine cause for only Visit for months! – and Sister's brother writes "Weymouth crowded, men in tents during cont wet weather, such insufficient housing that 500 sent on to 
Oxford
 Codford – Classified, simply by questioning, not examining, many "boarded for Australia" – sent on to Perham Downs by junior M.O's – What treatment for "our boys" – Frequent Examples in my Histories of men up to "38 months' Service" with only one Furlough – kept on until they break down, sent back again before they are fit, etc. – What can be done? Heater on for first time in Officer's Shack – if not on in the Ward, will formally ask for it.

 13
Heater on in the Wards – how different: Good old Australia – at Exam for "Officers Training at Oxford", our men head the list all through – whilst their work at the front speaks for itself.

 14
LtCol Anderson down from H.Q. – give him some idea of my work – show him Patients, Methods, Statistics, etc. "he" will bring them under D.M.S. notice" - Arrange to go in tomorrow re (a) 
Visit to France
 to see cases, (b) Sick Leave for Selected Cases, (c) Report on what may be improved – interesting to imagine the results – Afternoon, call in at Y.M.C.A Hut – the Extended Leave lets them keep open – Billiard Table to be soon started – Bus also for cripples. Meet a number such dragging the distance on foot with difficulty and discomfort.

 15
Saw D.M.S. – one hour's talk re Shell shocks – their Future – Response to Strain – amount of mental disturbance – Treatment – Home or Institutional – Diagnosis of Cowardice – Agrees that Neurasthenics and Rheumatics are no good at the front, and finally agrees to my going to the front. (Perhaps owe this to Anderson. probable Home. "never knew" the real situation.

 16
Call in at Horseferry Road Buffet (where at times 30 000 meals are served a day, under Mrs. S. brought from Cairo Buffet on account of her splendid work there). Mrs. S. gives me a Signed Photo "to the uncrowned King of Dartford" – getting on! –

1917
Entry.439:
In afternoon to B.M.A. Office re recent papers on shell shock - the best, apparently, on the same lines as myself, but more comprehensive - Afterwards see Mrs Jones at Buffet, selling cigarettes - sonenlisted at 17½ - she came to England to look after him - after-stretcher bearer in France from the first - waiting and trying in vain to get a visit from him - finally, goes to H.Q. - and now "to return at once to see you" - But why have to wait so long and for such an appeal - thousands of similar cases and no one here to speak for them. go so far as Charing Cross - the gate. sent back because name not on list there and killed shortly after.

 18
Under Secretary for War in the House "In June last 107,000 men in France who had had no leave for 18 months" - what a confession - and what a greater confession! "fallen to 36000 in August" - after public outcry - "knows of none two years without leave" - Lord Derby arranged a special report to all commanders - difficulty of transport" given as a reason - Rot! - Only one more illustration of Want of Consideration, and of Provision, want of broad outlook and even commonsense - one despairs of many such commanders as have full local control - and don't act. 
Now greatly reduced
Entry.440:
whin insisted on

 20
Boarded 13 cases - one from Cambridge with fracture of skull and left Hemianopsia - sent in as "G.S.W. of shoulder" - such is an army record - even from a university. (I could give hundreds if instances in which the main disability was never mentioned. Think what it means to the man. + Statistics)

 23
In to see House - leave my Cardiac Recommendations and Vol. 2 of my "Text Book" - also show him scope of my case taking and statistics - has sent over to France for my permit - to Red Cross - Murdoch away - arrange with Lamb to send in men on furlough wanting reasons to go to - overseas news for 30,000 Australian Casualties, 8 M.O's killed, - including Colonel Hearne, my patient at Ghezireh - all wonder "not before" in his case.

 24
Australian news - recruiting at low ebb. How much from bad reports from men here? - the machine counting for all, the man for so little - M.O.s at the front tell me how "many shell shocks return more than useless" (where do the consultant board come in!) - "want also more spells and a caterpillar round for all" - "consideration a matter of individual local authority" - "O/C practically absolute control - can, if he likes, does not if he does not want - may not even know, and subordinates can prevent personal appeal" - example at our own place -, Ex., patient sent to Weymouth want to parade before O/C (who knew nil about his being sent) - blocked in the office, - never got before him, though I personally asked - was told "pointing and must go" - possible, - but is that the way to prove it, or deal with it? - many other illustrations from the front. M.O's , e.g. Knight, Reiach, Fenwick, Browning, Ingram, - even from our little number - kept on till nearly dead! (Is there any brain in it? who is responsible?)

 29
Air raids - lights out 8 - 9.30 p.m. - more instances of Want of Consideration -just from Chatham
(a) leg-less men sent here, without crutches - had to hop
(b) bad cot cases roused at 6 a.m. - made put on khaki, breakfast at 7 - nil up to 11 when leaves, - and will us also
(c) Man here after journey from 4 till 8 - nil
(d) men at Weymouth each night for a walk in a different bit - Knight off tomorrow - O/C Hall - 8 months here - now much better

 31
Another Air Raid on Railway - carriages dark - shrapnel overhead - even at hospital.
Entry.441:
- 15
A fortnight at the Front (at last)
At Boulogne No. 2 A.G.H. - exposed site - 20 degrees frost - 1,507 patients in only one, third Australians - (easy to have all from neighbouring hospitals why not?) over 200 major operations a week - over 20,000 operations a months on L. of C. - fine cameraderie under Col. Powell and Matron Gray - On to Special British Neurological Hospital at Aire - 500 patients. 16 officers 3 padres and - nurses - good cameraderie, comfortable, make the best of it - received all the shell shocks on a form - facts verified by the Unit O/C
(a) Return to Unit,
(b) to Bare,
(c) Remain for Treatment - given full powers - but momentum "back to duty" - won't do it, unless satisfied - Much the same views as myself, - good, general staff, - but no specialist!' . Much appreciate my exposition of Methods, Statistics, etc. - Vist out No. 12 P.A. at Street, , - muddy, dirty and uncomfortable - doing good work, but pessimistic - know nothing about invitations in selected places - welcome recent research papers, Differential Nerve Diagnosis and



1917
Entry.442:
1-15(Ctd.)
and treatment (never any instructions advice or assistance from H.Q.) via Bethune and Vimy to . R.A.M.C. know how to be comfortable, - and why not? - with A.D.M.S. round the Front - nine trenches at "Oppy Wood". seeing and inspecting all Medical arrangments from trenches to casualty clearing hospitals. Arrangements now very complete - Visit our Australian Flying Corps - done fine work and very fit - Red Cross station hospital at Aubigny put up entirely by the British 94 F.A. with their own unit - really a C.C.5. - Trip to Arras - a desolation - everywhere the needs of the men - canteens, cinemas, concerts, games, etc. - now well met (what a difference to Mena!) - quite at home - could not have been better received - A.D.M.S. at letters fixed up everything splendidly - As my trip to this fighting area had been when there was no active fighting - arranged visit to Canadian C.C.5 at Wisques, and 15 C.C.5. near Eblingham - the former, 250 patients, - also without an expert Neurologist (Chief Physician an alienist) - unsuitable environment, insufficient facilities - at times under shellfire (the Huns send back to industrial camps at the rear - not near the front as here - no attempt at expert treatment - might send 10% more back to duty if given time - Corroborate my view re concussion antecedent, averting definite shell shock. - Next day with McCormack (Sydney) through St. Omer to 15 C.C.5. 8-1600 beds - now 500 with 6 M.Os and 8 sisters - more primitive arrangements - often under fire - again, no expert, surroundings quite unsuitable, no sufficient facilities for expert treatment, shell shock hospital only in name (How much of this also elsewhere, goodness only knows, but how it disguises the truth! - morale splendid - As the first part of my visit had been wasted, telegraph H.Q for seven days' extension. The 
Statistics in the 3 hospitals
 visited run as follows

Place Aire

Numbercases 357

Return to Duty 55%

To Base 45

Remaining--

Numbercases 1839 *

Return to Duty 13

To Base 77

Entry.443:
bearing out my view that such cases "require to be sent away from the Front" - and against what Myers had been saying that "80% were sent back to the front" - (the matter is fully dealt with in my reports) - Common talk our men "always march" - Tommies and others "frequently ride" - saw several instances myself even our men marching with full packs, when motor carriage for hay etc. was available - One of the causes for discontent - "Tommies' Joy Ride" - whose fault? - Receiving no reply to telegram off to Boulogne once more - no reply there - advised "better return to England and pay another visit here" - So go. (needless to say the reply comes - when I get back!)

(Handwritten margin note beside preceding paragraph:

 blamed Birdwood )
Entry.444:
Dartford again after morning's work, in to see D.M.S. - long talk - his aim to go back, and try to get over pensions - would welcome my helping from shell shock point of view - to give him my views and go into pensions in all bearings - perhaps two months' work - all men over 60 to go back soon - to send in my name if I want to go back, about next March.

(Handwritten margin note: .... H's good points)

Pensions to be the main after war work - 23,000 men sent back this year - the shell shocks probably the most difficult - wants expert conclusions, not opinions, on specific points from reliable man as I have written, any future usefulness of mine is thus and preventatively - (to keep off continued pension) - so will equip myself and further it - through H. if so most effective.
Entry.445: Investigate question of diet with Q.M. Dartford - find meat 9d. -½ if breakfast allowance, Rabbit 7d., fish 6d., soap 1d. Cocoa 1d. Egg 4½d each - Sisters tell me their outdoor dress costs £13 - rather stiff - O/C and Reiach on "unfair allocation of Honours - partiality of Howse Hurley, etc. - O/C power to recommend "C.M.G. and Mention in Despatches."
Entry.446:
Fixing up papers for 18 cot cases - writing draft of paper for Howse - Goodbye to the boys - Vance's son, McCulloch's (Sydney) son - men unconscious up to three weeks - fractured skulls, Jacksonian Epilepsy - mental, but notmental - Hemianopsia - thrice shocked - mutes, stammerers, lost memories, etc. - After such happenings, what do they not deserve - Give them Mrs address in Melbourne - felt as if parting with something personal - they give me photos, cigarettes, etc. - a nigger - Aboriginal - says "they'll come

1917
Entry.447:
24
hundreds of miles to see me" - my Mulvaney "keeps well" (put on his honor, trusted, helped and does well) - 20 telegrams to their friends - and "their hats and badge taken from them and stiff caps in place" - Truly the Army has no bowels or heart.
Entry.448: In to see Howse - to draw up "card for M.Os re shell shocks", for future pension usefulness - send memo re return next March - "quanto mutatus ab illo" - see Murdoch re better results of Red Cross - tells me "3000 men in Command Depots" out of control - gets them furnishings band, Silence Room, - Birdwood thanked him (instance of the want of official recognition and guidance of their needs). (next time, a combatant O/C - for regulational duties - but a civilian for all else)
Entry.449: Draw up card. It is believed majority will vote "No" - deplorable, but not to be wondered at - of all qualities selfishness the most persistent - natural - therefor to be met and transmuted unto altruism - a marvel to me I am such a persistent optimist - with what I have in front of me at 62! Why fight on? - for two reasons (a) one's own inner necessity, (b) its external reflex - "per aspera ad astra - is it worth it? Yes, its opposite cannot count - oh! to be caught never in the littleness of self, the momentary, the dissociated, the useless!
Entry.450: Leave shell shock card at H.Q. - meet Polack re pensions - see Andrew Fisher re "men always marching with packs" - Y.M.C.A. will cease to duplicate maps of London with Overseas (much better map).
Entry.451:
Murdoch down - but miss him - Major Chalkto dinner- looked well after our men's interests and amusements - but goes away without recognition - so much for recognition -
 
Previous British O/C Dartford - only the bestBritish type
Entry.452: Letter from Murdoch enclosing list of foods, etc., sent - but Mrs. Kennedy (M's local representative) list contains a number asked for, but not sent - write Murdoch also "are Red Cross to save Ordnance expense" - "can Mrs. Kennedy though sympathetic - run 3 hospitals?" as she was trying
Entry.453: Our casualties to date over 100,000 and deaths 31,000 - with grievances, legitimate as I have put down - and here 100,000 casualties a month for the last 16 months - ? necessary - ? the best way - ? blundering amidst such wonderful preparation and magnificent doing.
Entry.454:
Give men off on "furlough" letter to Y.M.C.A. for hospitality - Maud R down for boarding - R the "general" now - with his record in Egypt and here

5
Many of our men bring from the front tales of distortion, even untruth in our newspaper reports, - not unnaturally dwell on our deficiencies, not talk of anything else, with pessimistic, only half true, criticism, always of one sort - not to be wondered at, but to me - when from those in authority - unspeakable and distressing - The tug is at its height - will Australia forget harshness and inconsideration, the real for the ideal, themselves for their race! - What a strain to put on the young fibre of an untried nation! Will it hold? - Who can say? - Australia has done more than I, for one, ever expected - Will it do this greater thing still? (vote for conscription) - inconsidered and neglected as the men are - why so left? are the reasons sufficient? I think not - at least, let them know the real facts, the needs, the unfairness, the absolute necessity - recognition of what has been done - implied consideration in the future - the glory of the thing - Men, I salute you, wandering, proud, profoundly grateful, and hope even against hope that the greatest of all will come true - that you will help to see Australia see it through. What are our men like? Take one - volunteered for New Guinea - malaria, sandbagged in Sydney, with fracture of the base - not the man he was, yet re-enlisted - constantly if strained unequal to duty - carried on - four days continuous shelling in crater holes and trenches 3 - 4 high explosives close by - fought on, pulling himself together - men killed by the score - lay in crater waiting for zero, binding up wounds, helping others cut his arm with a knife - back to C.C.S. - confused "head like an earthquake" - lost his way - wanted to explain, wanted advice, called "mental" - sent from hospital to hospital - always wanting to do the



1917.
Entry.455: right thing - yet generally misunderstood - and what endurance, resolve, devotion - and mistreatment.
Entry.456:
Attempted air raid - 25 in various rushes - our Anti-Air gun alone for 10 minutes - and unusually heavy gun testing at - very upsetting to patients - one found dazed under the floor of the Shack - yet another - mute - spoke.
 
shell shock translates all sudden sounds in terms of danger!

Meet Polack re pensions - he will introduce me to Milner Boscawenand others
Entry.457: Told yesterday that V.D. Statistics are British 37%, Canadian 23% and Australian only 15% - If so, to our credit - Here 1700 patients a week, yet only now and then a man is reported to C/O, and only 4 found out of bed on two surprise night visits. (Trusting pays)
Entry.458: 33000 Australian casualties - and 22000 of them in British hospitals! - and the Referendum! - Has Australia undertaken too much? probably - performed it magnificently? - certainly - at a frightful cost? Only too true - who can order you young life into Hell, event (sic) to gain a Heaven? Will you order yourselves? Is the sacrifice really required? Do you think so? Will you make it? Will your hell of a time with legitimate complaint, fear of continued militarism, desire to save those dear from what you have gone through, prevail over high ideals and basal sense of justice to race? Must all this - at this stage - be left to - Voting, with little guidance, with no clear call? What a situation! (But such is life. War is simply its extreme!)
Entry.459:
How frequently the unexpected has happened and the anticipated been transformed into the opposite - why? Partly because we have under-estimated, partly because we have not made the best use of our resources. Our watchword has been not efficiency, but seniority, Red Tape, deliberation, and too often middling - why should the eternal powers crown such? They should not, and evidently they will not.
Memo sent round "to go out at once" - nice way of treating patients and M.O's.
Entry.460: Everywhere activity, apprehension, darkening gloom "The Twilight of the Gods" - the Huns' hardest blow expected - yet, at least 8 Divisions more than us on the W. Front - surely, unless we know what is behind the lines and have one control, we are at a huge disadvantage. Our referendum tomorrow. Memo to O/C (a) Average duration of stay of patients in other hospitals reduced from 78.8 days to 30.2. (2) Cases more acute much earlier, more gas poisoning, of new and mixed types - shell shocks more with neuraethenia, hysteroid and concussion, more mental instability, petit mal, post-epileptic automatism, (3) Less stay with us from more rapid return to Australia - would be still less, if received sooner from other wards, other provision for cot cases - if Consultant Board paid a fixed weekly visit and board papers were not delayed. (4) again ask for "sick leave for selected cases to approved places" - would promote comfort and recovery, increase efficiency and carrying power of hospital and lessen expense - at present only available for furlough and cot cases after final boarding and then only once. (5) Statistics of Ward A10 - 70 cases since November - 27 to Weymouth - 27 on furlough - 16 to other wards - 15 cot cases sent out - 17 waiting - 2 to Hurdcott - 18 boarded - 15 kept under treatment - beds 46 - 2 vacant.
Entry.461: With Polak to Lord Roberts' Memorial Workshops, Fulham - round with Major Craig - fine scheme finely carried out.
Entry.462: Jerusalem fallen! What a historic event - in to Ministry of Pensions - get information, pamphlets and introductions - Enquiry ordered into Cambrai surprise - said two Generals sent back? to good jobs - Such is the return for failure - honors if they win - soft bed with billet if they lose - no wonder there is discontent.
Entry.463:
To see Rissien Russell (nerve specialist acting as Consultant) - acting for Milner's Recuperative Homes" - 2 - 20 -30 patients - anterior to Collie - dealing only with discharged men - for two three monthly terms - agrees with me that cases are primarily psychical, no good for further active service - chaotic just now - just get resident M.O.

1917
Entry.464: Write re delay of billiard table at Y.M.C.A. Hut.
Entry.465:
To H.Q. - tell Anderson of the ? unsatisfactory state of Hurdcott - Suggest "time Howse decided whether my Circular was wanted or not" - only 5 minutes' job - Tea at the Buffet with Mrs. Samuel - 5000 meals a day instead of 500 at start - £30 a day taken for cigarettes without matches for 5 days - almost a revolution! Had to stop H.Q. calling and getting boxes by the dozen for friends - the usual selfishness - Dine in the Strand - sounds of air raids - what a sight! Shrapnel bursts over head - only 7 people in the stalls and 31 in the Balcony at the Lycaeum. 

Good old HQ.of theordinary type
Entry.466: Downing and Cooper off "on Transport Duty" - two hours' notice - the usual way. (scarcely ever necessary, frequently more than inconvenient)
Entry.467:
Keeping my boys in for Xmas despite "send on to Weymouth and Hurdcott" - Hurdcott said to be very unsatisfactory - O/C says so - yet sends on (I told Anderson - he promised to look into it) - Harefield, last year said to have been deplorable - now about our size and "drawing" nearly as many British hospitals as us, yet weekly "send on", is only 400 to our 800 - Numerically, how effective we are! - But are we really doing the best for the boys? I don't think so - We have the best hospital and staff, yet we are a passing show. Statistically, we'll come out fine - but curatively, poor - What a world of difference a little foresight and arrangement would make? Evening - usual concert (run from first to last by Dartford people - never missed once - even attendance of those in charge) - but - no nurses - because "their dinner hour" - and "no Matron" - "because no place arranged". O/C no care for this (how different from his predecessor who never missed!) - Recreation left entirely to Orderlies - the hospital still running 2 - 3 times as many through per week - Not the place it was, for patients - nurses and staff - under Powell it was a "Home". Still my patients are not much worse off - I send them quicker to Weymouth (much improved) and sooner to Australia (more boats), and get many otherwise never fully gone into - who would never have the luck and justice to get to Australia as all my shell shocks and nearly all my cardiac cases and gas poisoning cases do. (Col. Bond of Kensington British Officers Hospital wishes he could do the same)

21
Dr McGregor - Neurologist from Michigan visits, - returning to treat these classes of cases at home - give him all information, etc. - well pleased - gives good news re Americans, 600,000 in France to be 1,200,000 by April - counterbalanced by Referendum news "over 200,000 majority "No" in first half of votes - so, certain of defeat. Why? - given my views, regrettable, but explicable, some may think justifiable, - though I do not - Strange - the A fighter - inferior to no other, the only one to say "No" to Conscription - the freest of all - perhaps the best informed, but probably unequal to the altruistic point of view - unaccustomed to the World democratic need and danger from militarism of Russian type - but not to the British seniority type, which he knows only too well. To me, force is no remedy - its only present justification is to rope in the selfish, thoughtless, pleasure-loving and more than satisfied loafers, protected by the fine element here - Evidently they and their sympathisers, with disloyal Hibernian element, the jealous and selfish Labour push and those - a large number I believe - influenced by letters from ill-treated boys here - undertaken, to constitute a majority.

said that Billy Hughes madethe final choice - ...preferred an Australian

Strangely, at this juncture, Birdwood goes out to command an army - and 
Monash
 rather than White (two of my friends and trusty men) reigns in his place. Amongst my patients - M. has a name for looking after his men food, clothes, etc. - will write and give him my view - have I any right? Only the wish to do good - will it do any good? Who can say! Call in at Y.M.C.A. Hut, and tell them the billiard table will soon be up - hurry up the Town Clerk, and suggest ideal site. (in adjoining park)

23
Abortive air raid last night - Mrs. Langland's load of holly and bannerett for Xmas arrives - also Mrs. Samuel's sucking pig - also port and glasses from the Club (Dartford Constitutional Club) for supper.

1917
Dec. 24
Wards being decorated - mostly by the men themselves - the boys send me Xmas card - so I got 50 from Snowden's for them - 
Dartford, a of our Sir Arthur Snowden
- Mess dinner with nurses and staff, but not up to last - Padre's band of carol singers go round.

Dec. 25.
Xmas Day once more - one of Heaven's own - cards from girls and men - walk round the wards - fine feeling of fellowship and service - dine with the boys - splendid, with gifts from Red Cross, message from Birdwood - speeches, songs, toasts. Afternoon tea with sisters, supper with the boys in the wards - toasts, "Our Pals in the Trenches", "The Wacks", "our Sisters", etc. Concert at 7.30 - songs, dances carols, conjuring, etc.

26
All well after the day - arrange for 5 days' leave to visit Maghul, etc. Men's names for the different drafts, (1) Tourists, (2) Dinkums, (3) Super Dinkums, (4) War Babies, (5) Chocolate Soldiers, (6) Hard Thinkers, (7) Neutrals, and (8) Rainbows (after the storm).

Dec. 28 - 3/1/18.
Visit
 Maghul

 training schoolfor M.O's
- near Manchester, under Raws, Myers, etc. - R. full of the psychogenetic origin of dreams, delusions, aurae and neuroses generally - makes a point if other means failing - 500 patients - to be extended and made the main centre in England - staff 8 skilled - send out 100 a month to work - (for details vide paper) - Myers who said "80 sent back to the Front, astonished at my Aire statistics - agrees that for treatment should be sent straight to special hospital. As result of my first visit and talk with
 Professor Alexander
, 
oldVictorian. Prof of Philosophy, Manchester

Food questions becoming acute - to Golders Green - then, as one of Vice Presidents of the London Branch of the Imperial League of Disabled Soldiers and Sailors - preside at meeting to arrange for monster meeting in Albert Hall on 23rd - send Monash reply with 1000 overseas maps of London for his men - "the personal touch" being one of the main desiderata.

21

Of46 patients

from Ordnance

From Red Cross per week

Daily Quantities
 - for 46 patients, almost all "Nerves" and "below weight" - appetite digestion variable - 40 pints of milk, mostly for tea, cocoa, milk foods and extras - eggs as change for patients off food for the day - custard and jelly similarly at dinner and tea. The men who go out can buy extras at Y.M.C.A. (many stay away for afternoon tea) - Massage Department being lessened and reorganised under Johnson's brother (Johnson replaced Murray) - 5 off to Australia -now 2 Masseurs and 6 Masseuses - about 30 patients each. Entry.477: Cot cases off tomorrow - Psychosthemic, Epileptics, "Tics", Asylum cases and all.
Entry.478: Histories of fresh cases - poorer notes with them than ever - is treatment also? - more than scandalous - but - on it goes, much the same as ever - Murdoch and Mrs. Mitchell out to inspect Red Cross (as asked) - show them my Ward, Silence Room, what we get from Red Cross, and practical absence of Recreation Department. M. more than sympathetic - will do good - in all ways - "C.M.G" - and deserves it - keeps up his interest, enthusiasm and go - not many such.
Entry.479: To Y.M.C.A. - rouse them up re delay in Billiard Room.
Entry.480: Air raid - heavy firing - shrapnel, Ward upset - Recurrence about 4 hours later (two pages of Night Reports next morning).
Entry.481: Sugar redced to ½ - also less meat.
Entry.482: From 3 till 7 with Polack re Pensions.
Entry.484: "Goodbye" to more of the boys "back to Australia" - told my name mentioned in S.Africa re sending shell shocks home - to Boscawen's lecture on Pensions - fine, informative, sympathetic address.
Entry.485: Our casualties - Dead 43,000 - Missing 4,000 - Casualties 176,000 - Total 229,000 - Think of it!4% of our total population - and 1% dead!
Entry.486:
Further discussions of Pensions with Polack - as usual fine intentions bluffed in final administrations - it's the bottom more than the top of officialdom that is damnable.



1918
Entry.487: Fine letter from Monash - "the winner of a special decoration is like the man who has drawn the winning ticket in a lottery - the service stripes, the war medals and similar tangible evidences really count for more" - the others all in House's hands! Put Padre - on the Ward work - apparently never enters Padre's head except on Saturday to remind the men of Sunday services - and they won't go without the Sisters, and the Sisters won't go because of the Padre! Afternoon to Australia House re our Pensions - young airman from aerodrome past by, dying after accident "Cheerio" Sister, "it's only for a short time."
Entry.488: To Canadian General Hospital, Taplow - built their own - better than the routine British (Dartford, taken over by us) - beautiful surroundings - better than us in many ways, management included - strike a raid going home.
Entry.489: Many patients upset - we had some 60 shots overhead about 10.15 last night - much more London damage than admitted in the papers - Evening - Padre on McCay - like most else most condemnation says sacrificed at the Canal stunt - men and officers hostile yet - "K.C.M.G." - such is recognition -Another raid.
Entry.490:
40 minutes with Boscawen - promises all assistance - show him our leaflet and comment (send copies) - to H.Q. re delay of shell shock card - see _____ then Anderson, then House - sympathetic, - but nothing done - point out sending cases to general hospitals for 90 days (average) bad all round, value of card as record, and determining proper treatment - tell him also re Pensions - wants report when completed - Tell him of After Care Conference in April - Suggest "Australia be represented". Evening raid signals and shrapnel barrage overhead.
- 
he seems to have never heard of it
Entry.491: Write home explaining why I am still here. "Satan and the All Mighty contending for all that makes life worth living .... etc." - that's why I am here" - doing my little bit of infinite importance to some hundreds who have been in or will see Hell before they become unconscious, dream terrible dreams, lose memory and powers of mind - if I don't - no one will - in some cases at least - paying a price, a heavy one, but fading into nothingness compared with that of the 43000 who will never return - in a crisis such as the world has never seen before - and the end - the overthrow of the wrong - but at such a cost!
Entry.492: Day in Cambridge with Clifford Allbutt - wonderful place and wonderful man - at his age, active, up-to-date, a born manager - no signs of decay - and so hospitable.! (Shows me round including Chamber for Anti Gas campaign)
Entry.493: In re Pensions - Members of Parliament angling to get the National Federation on their side - even their President - To Buffett - wonderful - 36000 1/- meals a week - the best in London - lose on the meals, but make up on the 1000 beds - take £50 a day for cigarettes - bank £400 for the men, but huge breakages, and huge salaried staff.
Entry.494: Boarding - whist drive, etc. - to Y.M.C.A. Hut - asked to lay Foundation Stone tomorrow - into Club to interest them in the Billiard Table.
Entry.495: Boarding all morning - House inspecting 3 - 5.30 - pleased.
Entry.496:
To Y.M.C.A. Hut - at 12 - lunch with Hodge (President of National Federation) at House of Commons - (rationed), discuss Pensions - send him our position from Australia House - to Lady Barrett's 
no relation to the Victorian Lady
Lecture on Midwives - give them the Australian position.
Entry.497: Ten thousand, they say, waiting at Weymouth (might, of course, wait indefinitely if not insisting) The authorities ask the Navy and take "no" for an answer - yet as Col. ____ told me afterwards, by going to Larkin and others, subordinates got rapidly what they asked".) Met Col. White
Entry.498:
Stat.H. O/C- off 
home
 - said "Your ought to have a recognition" and would see about it (so many others said, but ----)

1918
Mch 1
Lunchat Golders Green, - Fine resume from Fearnsides - practically my own views - glad for such corroboration - best man I've met on the question - planning main lines of my report - Keogh retiring from D.M.S. after fine work - says "Red Cross (of which he had been Chief Commissioner) has to do, whatred tapepreventsthe Army from doing". Excellent example and definition.
Entry.499: Write Milner, Rissien Russell and Monash re Pensions - letter from Colliere the same.
Entry.500:
Goodbye to some more of the boys - Maudsley and Ryan round - farcical and unfair - yet all mine pass (I'd kick up a row if they didn't) - Afternoon to Y.M.C.A. Hut - going up at last - frame contractor and workmen - write Y.M.C.A. re caretaker and tables and get the Club interested - House asking when I want to go? - end of this month or some time next? - ? Do I want to? - I would see it through if I could - and will see it further if I can - younger and less ties, and I'd see it through to the end - Now, for the first time, I see chances of being really a driving force without pushing myself in - simple truth to say I have accepted the situation all the time - for the first time in my recollection, simply doing in this war what I have been told, and not directing others - not from fear or failure of power but simply from absence of selfish push - of some use, I feel I have been, but, if I had the place, I do think innumerable things would have been different.

Possibly, I underestimat the visinertiae, the paralysing grip of the machine, but I do think I would have foreseen a little, galvanised a good deal, co-ordinated, put spirit in, humanised many things, and made the machine a little less wooden and looked down upon - oh! the man in the trenches! - I would have persistently tried to do something for him in all his ramifications, helplessness, and hardships - I would have tried to be a brother, an older brother to him, a Councellor, helper, even, at times, a Saviour. There pages written simpy day by day, just as I felt, and saw, disclose my efforts, my views, my regrets, fragmentary, with insufficient information, and, no doubt, many mistakes, but genuine and true so far as they go. Does it matter - for the man I mean? Perhaps less than I think, - for who can guarantee results? Still I do think an extended usefulness for me would have been a better thing for the men - but, if I return, the three most fruitful years of my life - my contribution to the Armageddon ____ far less than many, many others, - and when the great books of this War come to be opened, thank God my name will be found on the only right side of the Great Account - with Sidney Carton "Nothing I have ever done can compare with this." Some day, perchance those who care to remember me, - if then there be any - may read these lines and perhaps thank God too.
Entry.501: With Red Cross Representative, Mrs. Kennedy (very willing and active but overworked) to Swanley Convalescent Home - says "they have never given her even a cup of tea" - extraordinary, but not singular - Then, round Sidcup Hospital for facial restoration by the opposite, a nice brainy Matron - Newlands - of S.A - working a specialty - try to make ward smile by suggesting moustaches, goatees, dundrearys, etc (to hide the scars a little)
Entry.502: In to H.Q. - see House - still "full of Pensions" and their importance - gives free hand for 2 months - may visit Paris for fuller information - wants reports for both Pensions and Restoration - only one at Conference and that one Howse with paper by me (It almost seems as if his attitude has changed because I may be useful to him)
Entry.503:
Lot of fresh cases in, - illustrating (a) 12 months in Command Depot of unsuitable cases, breaking down at once, even
 behind
 the firing line (b) Nerve cases, still coming over without special records and tickets, (c) Such "Green Tickets" to Netley and Denmark Hill, but not to us! - though both Canadians and S.Africans use them for their own hospitals ----, (d) "Wanderings" - up to 173 days in other hospitals before reaching their own Australian - Auxiliary Hospital! (e)Missing the boat through delays - and making further delays: - so they go on - and nothing really done since my return from France.

I can find no justification for this neglect of us





1918
Mch 8
Afternoon - in to see Collie - get Alden Turner's (Chief British official neurologist) address - Major Mitchell (one of the best) out, - get copy of lecture on Vocational Training - with about 100 slides - and given almost daily

Entry.504: Letter from Col. Butler (Supervising Medical Records) for information re shell shocks, etc. in all their relations - too late for practice, but in time for pigeon holing. (Butler is to write the Medical History of the War - what can he make of it?)
Entry.505: In to see Butler - "off to France for 3 weeks" - On to Lord Roberts Workshop - splendid example of England at her best.
Entry.506: Goodbye to more of the boys - off to Weymouth - After lunch to Parliamentary War Pensions Bureau, fine resume by Secretary Garside.
Entry.507: In to see Major Mitchell - gives me the French position - Over the Polytechnic with Studd (J.K. - youngest of the great cricketing family) Then to Col. Stenton, "in charge of Interallied After Care Conference" next May - Find - from our point of view - nothing done - "awaiting Australia's reply" - Colonial Office had sent invitation - no reply - no space Official Presentation, papers all in nubibus- on to meeting London Branch of the National Federation (of which I was a Vice President) - give address on their facilities, making them known, etc.
Entry.508: To Australia House to see Box (Sec.) - place the Conference situation before him - tells me Australia has appointed Fetherston and Manofold and that they are on their way - Meantime, will act if Howse takes the initiative - Down to see Howse --- "not now responsible", but will act as suggested - descriptive sketch to be in by April
Entry.509: with all possible exhibits from Southall - On to Murdoch - fix up interview with Howse - Howse keen on "men coming from Australia unfit for duty" (thus late) - the true meaning of Fetherston's visit - I "must stay till June now." (evidently antagonism between F and H - fight - in which H won)
Entry.510: Cable Australia "Detained, Special Duty, well" - Fix up cot and berth cases - Dine at Authors' Club - Convert Canadian M.O. re "shell shocks".
Entry.511: Feel as if on the upgrade, instead of b2- yet how can finish better? - Perhaps my last work Repatriation may be most serviceable - if I only had a competency so that I might devote myself to nothing else - Afternoon hear Addison on Reconstruction - impresses with broadness of his views, justice and endeavour.
Entry.512: Hard at paper for Interallied After Care Conference.
Entry.513: On the same - see Howseand Murdoch - On to Stanton (Sec. of Conference) -
Entry.515: The big offensive apparently starting - at grips "for the world" - realities v ideals.
Entry.516: In to see the National Federation walking to Albert Hall - great meeting. Hall full. Sit just behind Bottomly of "John Bull" fame)
Entry.517: Line broken on Canadian Front - only "one-third of what they intended" - but what a third. (all say Gough the worst & the worst staff on the whole front)
Entry.518: Still unchecked and advancing - our civilisation in the balance - for the time failing. Afternoon - still retreat - said 750,000 Huns thrown in - leave men returning - Some of our M.Os off - others not - We wonder what Sutherland will do - Whether things look blacker or no, instead volunteering to release a younger man nearer the front.
Entry.519:
Still pressing on to Arras, Albert, Ribecourt, etc. Boarding all morning - awaiting developments all afternoon. What issues at stake! One-third one half of them 1/8 front?- getting exhausted.(we felt it was 2 sides of a piece of tissue paper re getting through, )

Mch. 28
slackening, - or held and punished - if our aeroplanes supreme, what a target - apparently the weather god with them - to-day may decide Amiens or not - if one only knew where our divisions are - Lloyd George calling on America "to quicken up". Afternoon to Polytechnic for statistics - To H.Q. - Howse slackenedoff.
 
I suppose situation too delicate
"No responsibility now F____ is coming". Same with Box ---- Round to Stanton re the Conference - got him to leave it open till April
Entry.520: - With Barnett write 2000 wordpresentation of Australia's position "for approval" - so that we may not be out of it as usual. (quite evident, nil ready, probably nil done in the matter)
Entry.522:
and the killing at its greatest - worshippers killed at 
long range
, etc. - Apparently the Supreme, having disclosed the right, and given brain and heart to understand and achieve, (within limitations) leaves the decision to Man - the cost - representing the value - suspense - confused accounts concealing if not misleading - useless arguments in the Mess - for me - don't care to speak - even go out - then read. (It was the most anxious time of my experience)
Entry.524: - Resurrection Day - think of it, fine account of Appeal by Garvin in "Observer". (we thought the best paper of the time)
Entry.525: Goodbye to Padre Petternwick - one of the best - give him Kipling's message to read to the boys, our champions in Hell's tournament - America offering all her men to Foch - good news beginning.
Entry.526:
Better news still - holding and countering - yesterday Hindenberg was to have been in Paris, but Foch now
guarantees Amiens" - news filtering through - Airmen's glories, motor cars ubiquitious, and infantry fighting, fighting, fighting day and night like flotsam in a maelstrom - the King -to the Front - Poincare at Amiens, Americans where needed "Thou shalt not" as at Verdun "On ne passe pas" - munitioners giving up days and nights, engineers their quarrel, but Ireland "never to have conscription" - Kaiser kneeling in Cologne Cathedral and thanking his Heavenly Pal and killing those on the steps of the Madeleine with a 75 inch gun! even Russian after Death - who would be in Australia now? Afternoon - to Australia House - Australia's summary for Conference typed off - get Box to forward it, "if Stanton asks" - Ring up Stanton - he asks - also Murdoch re space wanted - Hand in my paper on "Better Treatment of war neuroses" - ? 
a Canadian tip
