Gough
 
held responsible for Bullecourt debacle
"retired for 5th Army failure" (none too soon - vide Bullecourt, etc) - but - to what new job? Kellaway and Newton with us "working for F.R.C.S." - as if no special need or call at the Front! - breathing space once more - but what news of casualties, captures, etc. - and Australians once more into the Somme - fine account.
Entry.527: To Australia House - Final draft of Summary for Conference - no alterations - To see Fisher - High Commissioner - "invited to Opening, - and Box and Barnett to discussions.
Entry.528: Both preparing for the next blow - Have we no plans? London under curfew, but no bands to play, no Parliamentary (by M.P.'s) calls to duty - only Lloyd George. (In many ways, the greatest English force, like Clemenceau & Wilson)
Entry.529: Australians near Dernecourt "One of the finest chapters ever written in our history" so even Bean.
Entry.530: Some idea of the work done at War Chest Club for 4 weeks ending
Entry.531:
Meals 159085 purchases at counter and Canteen 45125, Drinks (soft) 33421 Beds, 27608 boots polished, 18675 cloak room deposits, 1176 hair cut, 9402 enquiries, 8000 men for tours, 5647 baths, 4126 billiards, 2790 tickets for concerts, etc. 1940 deposited in Club Bank £35877-9/4.





1918
Entry.532: Held, except round Armentieres, but endurance at its maximum.
Entry.533:
Haig, "Backs to the wall" - "no retirement" - "safety of homes freedom of mankind the issue". Carrie (to Canadians) "To those who fall I say "You will not die, but step into immortality - your mothers will not lament your faith, but be proud to have born such sons. Your names will be revered for ever by your faithful country, and God will take you unto Himself."

Our boys are South - defending Amiens - and poor me! I can wait here can stand it - no longer, but must go in and offer my services in any capacity, anywhere I can be used at W. 43 - am off to H.Q. - Howse out - leave letter offering to go wherever I may be useful!- what a world - amid it all, boiled down, the main need personal preparedness, such foresight as is possible - then one's best work wherever one is - all at once and at their best for the fortunate genius and heroic - few have more than one of these - as Lloyd George, Clemenceau, Wilson, Bonar Law, Geddes, etc. - but, above them all, the man in the firing line!
Entry.535: as King asked - still ebb and flow - terrific fighting - Foch and Co. v Bosch & Co.
Entry.536: Bailleul captured - the Huns 3 to 1 - the end not yet.
Entry.539: Held everywhere down south - not "in Paris, and British swept from the coast."
Entry.541:
was his Day of Doom
Hindenburg now says "August" - To Neurological Hospital for Officers Kensington Gardens - 2000 patients in 3 years - get their men earlier than ours - hence better results, specially in the hysteroid - much same views - more separate treatment possible - never seen any fresh epilepsy or automatism. BonarLaw's Budget "the greatest in history" £7,000,000 a day! Rich the Hun "Circus" airman - brought down by Australians, and buried him.
Entry.542: Brilliant Navy dash at Zeebrugge. Afternoon to buffet - empty - what a change. Oh! that I were 40 instead of 62.
Entry.543: Anzac Day - What a memory - Australia's Birthday amongst the nations.
Entry.544: All in once more - no break through this time - Our boys retake Villers Brettoneux (and save the time - save Amiens - save Paris - save evacuation of coastal ports which the Fleet were ready - on anniversary of Anzac - (glories related elsewhere) - one of the lessons of the solidity, strength and resources of this wonderful island, by the 20th 1000 guns and 5000 machine guns replaced 100,000 men - manufactured stores £500,000,000 - (twice last year's output) in planes, more in a week than in the whole of 1914, etc. - Apparently our boys are counter attack and troops (first time together) under one command - that Command Monash Australian and after a spell.) Small pox in Dartford - superintendent of hospital notifies "Danger from the Thames Bank" - notice put up - that's all - we revaccinate but Dartford "out of bounds" - though station is not and dance people come in and O/C dances with one - what a travesty on commonsense! At times, I fancy I must be "cracked".
Entry.545:
Hun held and a little more than held everywhere - Garven a fine tribute to our boys "Praise above all to the Australians, no praise too high for swift ability and unsurpassed fighting". Haig eulogises them to 
Birdwood
 
B" technically stillleader though reallyMonashCorps Commander 
- thrilling descriptions by some of the boys. Bean'show poor - What a day for the world if this represents the turn of the tide - too good to be true.

Quiet and silent in the Mess - it's too serious and I cannot bear the easy pessimism and disparagement. I still keep cheerful in the Wards, and

Nearly a week no action - but ceaseless artillery and air action - Further successes by our boys - Called in to see 
Griffith
 - treats me as an angry O/C would an opposing private - on two misconceptions, even threatens to court martial me - then simmers down and accepts my statements - an insult for which I have no redress, but showing how officialdom follows and marks me 
Official mind procedures andviews. Took a position against me - quite false - simply hearsay, suspicion - and bullied me - in his power
- See Fetherston - just from Canada.(important, imposing, seeks out things for himself, honest, but "not the man for Galway")
Entry.551:
Usual morning work, history taking, classifying, boarding, planning - is not this more important than a scalpel, or "No. 9?" - They say the returns to Australia men are in a bad way, "the stay-at-homes" prevail and wax fat! -

Thestay at home Medicos reap the harvest - specially bad for the juniors who left all&followed war
Afternoon - In to see Stanton - knows nil re F. or Murdoch's preparation or revision of Summary - Arrange all promptly and in time - Any use? who can say - Tomorrow Lloyd George's worst & latest crisis. I wish him well.
Entry.552:
L.G. beats Asquith 293 to 106. F. comes out to Dartford, O/C absent (says F. knew) - No one knows why F. is here, not even H.Q. - To St.Thomas to see and hear Truby King. Splendid. 
Maurice
 "retired", not "shot" like a private --- for past services and loyalty to Pals and to even better job. It must be an ingrained British official axiom - "profit by success, but not lose by any defeat - one sided and unfair - How different for the outsider, the under-dog, the man in the ranks - No wonder the masses are bitter against militarism and the dominant class.
 
Gen Maurice for public condemnation of Army matters
Entry.553: Lot of "Bulletins" arrived - breezy reading - Hell's rising to the top while Australia talks of "The Cup" "Jack Wren" - Money plentiful and a superficial second hand interest in the War - our reward - the only good and permanent one - the memory and thankfulness of what we have attempted - our great "quest" - not to be paid in earthly coins - after all, reaping what we sow - inconceivably the best. Personally when I return "out of the running". not in the reflex of any work and may be practically poor - but with memory and all the war has taught me.
Entry.554:
To Newton Abbot to see Hurst and Co. - at work in new quarters, - splendid site and environment, intensive immediate teatment by suggestion, until successful, maintained by personal contact and continued supervision - sent immediately to farm work - kept for some time - then to selected Home Service, not removable by any travelling Board or Command Depot - the most true and effective methods I have met - its intensiveness quite recent, its times mine - only better - more systematic and sustained - ignoring psychoanalysis and also my careful history taking. (of value in many ways - and more scientific)
Afternoon - Conference with Aldren Turner, etc. Casesdemonstrated. - all of us more than pleased.
Entry.555:
Further cases demonstrated - the best I have seen specially with stammerers & bent backs.

22-23
Conference read paper. Great interest earnestness& desireto meet all problems, many capital exhibits. F learning all he can hurriedly - asks me to report on Medical side.
Entry.556: Haig again thanks Australians - praised everywhere as the best fighters
Entry.557:
Our Mayflower, the "Kyarra", sunk on way round to Plymouth - carrying galvanised iron. Back to work - reports for Howse and Fetherston - Resume for Butler - Re F. admire his energy, determination, goes everywhere - sees everything, picks up all he can - different in toto from Howse - Canada and N.Z. both better run than we - do things early, although humanely and let it appear - see no control or foresight or consideration in ours - ours under Howse beneath contempt - simply regulation and routine - not worthy the men, the time or the work. How much more could not have been done - At Conference, our Exhibition a disgrace - self intro-

 

1918
Entry.558:
introduced,on me alone fell all that was done for Australia - others must think us mere fighters, not men of plans, views, foresight or breadth - McK's criticism just - none of our H.Q. would have known, or cared, or gone, but for me!
Mine now to do more - something done there - perhaps I may widen, deepen, give a better true inwardness. Keeping eyes and ears open - papers, etc.
Entry.559: Board 10 - send out 11 - a record for A10 - To Kitchener House - its evolution and work - 600 visits there - praised by Keogh - want to send out 20-30 visitors to hospitals to get the men interested - accelerate, not interfere with cure - Send on to see if Murdoch will finance a start in Ward A10.
Entry.560: To Eastbourne Convalescent Camps - ideal (vide report) - 4000 convalescents - no bounds - camaraderie a wise help - catered for psychologically, physically, curatively. Gymkana - 2000 spectators - in the midst of other hospitals. Spend the day there - splendid all round (Lady Wilson wanted to keep our boys (of course some there) as long as possible)
Entry.561: Histories of difficult cases - patient skilled investigation & examination the only way to get all the facts - yet how seldom followed - In the afternoon, to Countess of Darnley's Cobham Hall - one wing for convalescent Officers. (time sympathetic home - Glen Knight O/C toward the end)
Entry.562: Bowls for the men - one billiard table at the Hut - Padre Smith to get more games through the Y.M.C.A., - and loans of books from Dartford Library, etc. - but why not one in official charge of all this?
Entry.563: Still writing report - difficult to condense - war situation grave - Paris only 46-50 miles away from Hun's two salients - has not the right gone down before the wrong before now? Do we deserve to win? Yes - in all ways but one - officialdom, and Galsworthy writes "Officialdom -- is on all our nerves" - a muddle, and not always a good muddle.
Entry.564: Only 8 miles the last 2 days - and signs of being held.
Entry.565: Draw Padre's attention to trips for our boys - letter from Lady Wilson about keeping them a little longer in her hospital - "they are so fine" - also from S. African O/C getting his "direct from the front." Oh! that I were in charge for a month. Sing-songs in the ward - Padre with his portable organ - how they like it - through the favourite songs of the trenches to "Annie Laurie" and "Nearer my God to Thee".
Entry.566: Still held - but 30 miles from Paris - to Tower of London - Howse over in France - Tell Butler some more eye-openers re the war - "which account is he to write - the real or the official." He smiled.
Entry.567: Still held - Ah! "la gloire de la France!" Clemenceau great "no surrender" speech.
Entry.568: Definitely held - but "5 months before America's millions will be decisive" -
Entry.569: clinical evening - Johnson on his massage methods - S. an expert on X-Ray plates - Cases from my ward - nil re records, boarding, histories, co-operation, though much might be said.
Entry.570:
"Endurance all the summer, to the maximum and uttermost", says Garvin - to Tavaner's 
Sir John - at Bexley -
 all agree "the official and the book of regulations are our hobbles - Padre- as others - enthusiastic when he left Australia - now psychasthenic and despondent after months at the Front - little wonder.

10
Hell continuing and to continue - Reply to H.Q., (stopping us altering some one else's diagnosis to "shell shock" - H.Q. never sticks up for us almost encourages anyone to hit us - Rerach much better - been in most of it - fine work - no recognition on the side of the boys - afraid to ask for sick leave for fear of "return to Australia".

Afternoon - finish report, (a) want H.Q. to make and keep staff scientific, (b) establish two general hospitals in England, (c) get patients direct to us, (d) Remodel relationship of auxiliaries, convalesents, , (e) attend to the men's pychology, (f) use exercise, remedial gymnastics, and occupation as much as possible, (g) place recreation





1918
Entry.571:
Education, and the like on organised basis - with illustrations and explanations - gently suggesting that other dominions are doing more than we, and, therefore, are more effective and satisfactory - Suppose I shall be still more persona ingrata, after being persona incognita. What matter if good follows - post report - for Fetherston and Australia - on thin ice but obtain Howse's sanctionas "asked by D.G.M.S.", then all round report for D.M.S. - and shell shock account for War Records So apart from prime 
reason
 "for the men" will be here till the crisis is over - some months more
 
all common sense?
Entry.572: Morning - boarding and classifying. Afternoon - country walk - England in the glory of June - seen no war - heaven compared with the hell in France - Tea at Stone Castle - put Mrs. Smith on to Murdoch for "Tea for the men's visit" and Padre "for visitors" - back with sports for the ward - give out prizes for Whist Drive.
Entry.573:
To see vocational trainer of the Canadians - had their Khaki University for a long time past - occupational work at Buxton - Reception of patients - much better than ours - clinical evenings since 1916, and Medical Bulletin since February - we are behind. In city - met B.A. brother, stroke at Wesley - under the influence - was 13 months in France 
after I boarded him for Australia
 (really a crime on the part of the authorities) - shot in the head and a Mulvaney - such is the Army.
 
really a crime on the part of theauthorities
Entry.574: To send in report to Howse's direct - next throO/C: See Butler again - agrees I "could do things" - to send him our Egyptian report to Ford - also mine to House and Fetherston.
Entry.575: Write report to Fetherston - bowls on the lawn - Arrange picnic for A10
Entry.576: From great offensives to a standstill - final revision of report - Afternoon - see Butler - making great preparations for his history - telling their own tale? any critical spirit? with any refer to want of prevision direct short-comings - hopes deferred? or simply routine duties? - What a different history the mercilessly true one would be! Is there ever such written? The critics see the failures, the neglect, thenarrow vision but they may not know the cause, the difficulties, even the excuse! If I had the official documents to give the official side, I might get nearer the truth, probably the drab commonplace truth of the average man's average performance, - even it might do him justice, though the facts remained true.
Entry.577: Getting ready for our sports meeting, and billy tea - poem from the lady visitors and Sisters to the "Flower Maidens" - 20 prizes from the Red Cross - Padre and his organ, etc. - Selections byBand - illustrated programmes - costume artists - all sorts of sports - Kodaks. Fine afternoon - better than much "treatment".
Entry.578:
having learnt it

America safeguarding her country - Recreations organised. - what we wanted in Egypt, and also here they do at the start! - fundamental "no scars, but war" - what poor, feeble, narrow methods ours! Cannot conceive of my having been a "Red Tab" - sickens one to think of our "Don't do, don't care, don't know" - Send in my report to Fetherston - 2 of main points, no organised , recreational, educational or restorative - no general hospital in England (Canada 4160 beds!) men combed into auxiliaries
incold bloodsimply damnable
 for immediate transfer to camps (tell Howse "necessarily inferior position") - not the best for the men, or for the staff, or consistent with he dignity of Ausralia".) We get a memo from the Registrar three or four times a week "send out". Speech today from O/C "600 a week, or I'll come in, and send them out" - What a position - the men simply numbers, the staff simply classifying clerks, our service reduced to simply an arithmetical addition sum! - and the O/C. obeys his instructions and hustles his staff!
Entry.579:
Three boys to furlough and Y.M.C.A. Hospitality Hut - Boarding all morning.

1918
Entry.580:
Reiach a month's sick leave (rheumatism) - one of the straightest and best - no recognition because won't join the service - aged a lot - yarn with the boys - letters about them - wonderful series - from all strata - will never know who have passed through my hands. Such is life! - is position any criterion of meri? The war says "No" Is recognition worth anything? Not even to face value. Is life a just equation? Not this side Death - What is the thing to do? Just my old motto "el scire semper et agere"- thank heaven, it has been my lot to "ever try to know and do" - amongst the many and the lowly placed so that there has been no inducement to play for self - there are lesser times when I feel envious and sorry I am not in a higher and wider sphere, and wielding wider, if not less personal, influence - but, in my better moods I forget them all and feel more than ever that they are not worth considering - Mitchell Bruce wrote me after the College 
Royal College of Physicians London
had passed me over for the F.R.C.P. (though Osler, Clifford, Allbutt, Mott and himself had brought my claims forward) "the King will surely recognise" - though he has less reason than the College - and knows it even less - though for fairness and family sake, tempted to let the authorities know - it can take its chance - would I change with, say, Ryan - breastful of ribbands, (even Turkish) "C.B." and "Surgeon General?" Not the first letter of my career for the whole alphabet of his ending. Those who should know, may, perhaps, some day discover it from this old Diary, or from some of the boys - Thank heaven I have had the chance to help them, and so often tried. If only the clock of Time could be put back, and give me a few more years.

 
protest against thewaythe College treated its last and, till now, only Australian trained M.R.C.P ... resigned my Membership."
Entry.581:
Boarding - 15 of mine go out - like old friends off "Home" - moulded by iron discipline, broadened by what they've seen and gone through, they never can be the same as before. Out there the current may be too strong for them, but they'll influence it. - Afternoon - visit the Hut - Billiard Room ready - to be opened on Saturday.

 
How many fell by the wayside after discharge in Australia. There too I have done all I could to them as near thebest as possible. - Who can assess - War
Entry.582:
Urgent - In to see D.M.S. - for what? Is he "to go our way", or am I to be silenced - All our men with me - also staff - and good reasons. Another fight and as usual I seem destined to do the fighting - Perhaps in lieu of the fighting line? Less immediate danger! - but - against officialdom - no easy matter. Ah, boys, boys, though unknown and forgotten I'm for you again and all the time. If only I were a medical Monash - "mea culpa" I suppose, - but just as difficult - and the cause just as deserving. And, how many unknown fights do not go on at the Front, unrecognised, - but none the less valuable. Truly recognition is naught - the effort and the way are the things that endure? - not the praise, but the performance.
 
in Dartford - oldhouse of Wolseys

Padre took the boys to stone castle - Arrange lecture on vocational training - into H.Q. - F. takes all from me - says nil - puts it down - not even thanks - always bad manner - then H. asked re Canadian - "should have been through him" - explain - accepted - Re my opinions, (as per report) only comment "a man might think things putrid - nothing to him - but, in so far as affects his jurisdiction, he must know, so as to take action as he thought fit" - wiped off the slate 
:
 
characteristic of the man
 - Getting my report copied - giving one to F. and one to Butler - intended sending all back over a certain age - though Australia might disagree - (Ryan sayed on till the next year)" - then "undertook to get me to France for more information re neuroses, if I gave him explicit places" - otherwise no thanks. Anderson said "very valuable report" - then over to Butler - gave him names of men worth opinions - Syme - Summons, Zwar, Argyle, Reiach, Hurley, Newton Tait, , White, Dunhill, Stawell, Jackson, Trethrowan - also, subjects on which special knowledge - only few put to best use. Scarce one an initiative force, but in the hands of senior officials and the effete machine - also gave him list of reports at end of my Paper to Minister of Defence, and copy of Conference Paper at Inter Allied After Care Conference report - he will ask formally for it, until then private - Apart from these, and the like, what fair weather records - for such, who is responsible? - Is no one responsible? - will not lesson be learnt? Meet Purdy, now O/C. No. 3 A.G.H. and D.S.O. - off to Australia - nil left to get except A.D.M.S. - and Millard occupies ( - all but us created a Sanitary Department at the front)





1918
Entry.583: that interesting to note if any local results of my report - all here frightfully fed up. Bond going back to Command F.A. - H. has made me sign - F. dumb - but something will come - at least I hope so.
Entry.584: Bond says H.Q. "think highly of my report" - let's hope it leads to something - plenty of work though I don't put it down. Boarding about 10 a week and sending out 5 more - To-day intensive suggestion to 5 stammerers 3 cured in a few minutes - other 2 (recent shocks) much better - Going on with notes, arranging work, outings, giving prizes, playing in Whist Drives, forwarding library - Y.M.C.A. Billiards, - Mrs. Smith's teas, gardening - photo films through Murdoch, - cinemas, etc. - so that all my time is not spent in seeing the beauties of England and sipping the delights of London - truly "nihil humani a me alienum" - I find satisfaction, for the time, anywhere, and in anything.
Entry.585: Another boat going - so hard at it - Take 6 histories and board 13.
Entry.586: Consultants down for cases for second boat - get through some 15 men.
Entry.587:
All cases in the ward boarded except 3 - See Stanton and Mitchell re places to visit in France - run into Brig Gen Livey - "our boys saved Amiens, too long in, and too frequent, - many officers, splendid but far too much looking and making for advancement - those who worked for the men black-listed - finest Xmas in France -put the men into better spirits - there things now more looked after"
Another Hospital ship torpedoed - why don't we authoritatively brand the Kaiser as a murderer?
Monash's own doing, so successful that became "the model battle" for instructing officers -have seen the private memo
Entry.588: Australia in more stunts (Hamel) - tails up as never before - always hitting the Hun - recognised by all. ("feeds out of our hand" - - next month the spearhead in the final Advance)
Entry.589: Week end at Camberley - Public school boys of England - training for
Entry.590: Lieutenants their "average duration of life at the front" 10 days. Do any flinch? Not one, and so, the Tommies - as the East end wives & mothers said "He's got to do his dooty"
Entry.591: Clemenceau's surprise visit to our boys.
Entry.592: "German discipline seriously shaken" - Histories and boarding - 15 a week - Afternoon - to opening of Y.M.C.A. Billiard Hut - at last! - Clark to come down and help - Y.M.C.A. "warned off the Red Cross grass (hospitals) yet often doing what red tape now prevents the Red Cross from doing - such are organisations as they mature.
Entry.593: In car sisters from Rouen tell about no General Hospital in England, even in France, so Tommies to ours and 200 Australians to them, though only just over the road" - Nothing done yet with my report - still send our shell shocks to Netley, the Maudsley etc., and kept there - instead of coming direct here - there marked "fit for Dartford" from all sorts of British hospitals after detaining them there for months of "treatment" - We simply a convalescent home - our nurses not recognised by their British as equal to anything else, - and yet generally far their superiors - our H.Q. has no pride - no consideration, no care, - just "let slide" - scandalous - how can we blame people here when our own do these things?
Entry.594: 6 stammerers under intensive treatment (3 from the Maudsley, 37days, 2 months, 3 months!!) - 4 cured in a few minutes and the other 2 much better! - Writing report on cardiac cases for Butler (vide Paper).
Entry.595: Mrs. Hoymanson of Kitchener House down (fine, used by many British NZ & Canada but? by no Australian H. except us?) - will take some of our boys twice a week up to work there. (splendid conception spirit & execution)
Entry.596: Give Butler cardiac report - write King (Paris) re visit to French Neuroses centres. (With his help, arrange places to visit by permission a French
Entry.597: Foch's dramatic blow just in the vulnerable place. Send up 10 of the boys at cost of 20/- to Kitchener House to get interest and right work - follow them and see the result - Fine.
Entry.598:
Two hours with Sir David Ferrier - still quick - alert and with all roused interests. (a pleasure to see the veteran pioneer is well)



1918
Entry.599:
Boarding- 6 stammerers well inside the hour - My men gardening, croquet, wool work, basket making, picnics, concerts in afternoon - To Y.M.C.A. Hut, billiards, etc. - the Americans opening up 3000 bed hospitals near the War Hospital (previously for German prisoners) the other side Dartford - Also another, for the S African, big hospital in Richmond Park - what a site for S. Africa and U.S.A. - but not for us! Compare Southall and Harefield! Who's to blame? Tomorrow 11 more of my boys leave "for Australia" and 15 "for Weymouth" - Pitcher consults me re our "Tube station" position - tell him I am going to put it before Hughes (our "Billy").

We could have had it Green (just near us)fine combination - but - never obtained
Entry.600: Our 16 leaving - Nohing doing - so arrange for more flowers for our garden outside the ward - ask our "flower maidens" to bring us one each (also others) - To a picnic - as usual give out the prizes at Matron's Whist Drive.
Entry.601: In to see Returned Soldiers Imperial League (of which I was Vice-President to the London Branch) - getting rid of Hogge, M.P., because he is trying to get them on political lines - To Aldwych Y.M.C.A. H.Q. to thank Clark - got films and garden tools for ward, and croquet, bowls and tennis for the Hut (Dartford).
Entry.602:
Said "Millard back from Australia, and D.D.M.S. for hospitals -just the man 
not
 for such position - purely departmental and strict in the letter - good for gaol or criminal command - now said to be "seeking to establish General Hospital in England". How it makes one sick this official procedure - just follow the regulations - if H.Q. approves - disregard outside facts and conditions - they have no right to exist, and officially don't exist - never show foresight, keep well in with your superiors, and all you have to do is your routine job in the routine way, and, when the crash comes, just save your skin by being there before the funeral. Oh!human lives, human needs and human deserts, what unnecessary trials and losses are your fate! Does one wonder at the inevitable reflex? Truly "These be thy gods, O Israel" - and these be the names on the Roll of Honour - with a few insistent others! Truly only participation and performance are the only things worth anything - I used to fight - accompanied by the thought that recognition should follow effort - I see desert is its own reward. How this makes one revise one's traditional values, and be more considerate of the world's "Failures" - Send 3 specials into Kitchener Hoiuse - come back ready for basket working, picture frames, and chipworking in the ward - Mrs. coming weekly to supervise - at her own expense - niece of Field Marshall Grenfell - interesting cases of total amnesia in - mild melancholia - bad hysterical paraplexia, etc. - Sending 16 a week to Weymouth - Of the last 147 in 10 weeks - only half a dozen classed higher at Weymouth (probably a mistake) - but must not get Bett's back up - Our garden going on well - photographs again soon - Then can smile at the absence of many official desiderata.
Entry.603:
Billy Hughes down
. Our "Magnoon" sports - Dartford ladies provide food, and plants for garden, the Red Cross the prizes, - Both Padres assist - go off well. (Mia-mia, Blacks, Sundowners, Billy Tea, as well)
Entry.604: Mrs. Bulted down again - delighted at interest and progress - getting other visitors for woolwork and wood for picture frames - Bulloch - "shell shock" - whom I appointed - as assistant must go - "time up" - better here than at anything else - but "must go" - by regulation, probably Smith (Psychasthenic) also, though equally efficient for organising and supervising therapeutic and interesting exercises - will see Howse about it - but - such is officialdom.
Entry.605: Afternoon to American Hospital (which we might have had) - fine men - fine officers - fine arrangements - take in officer patients as well as men - some psychoanalysis. (good complete scheme of inspection )
Entry.606:
Get O/C to agree to keeping on Smith to "supervise occupational and recreational exercise."

13
They have a special 
in charge
 of American Y.M.C.A. - off back to America "to increase



1918
Entry.607:
herstaff to 7000 in France, 1500 in England, and Experts and £20,000,000 for the year's Canteen - why on earth our authorities have no similar affiliation - with us Y.M.CA. "warned off hospitals by the Red Cross" - Y.M.C.A. reserved for camps, (and Padre and I ignore.) 
 the skilled sympathetic personal touch beyond all
 Y.M.C.A. giving us personally bowls, pictures, cricket, indoor games, gramophone, books of songs (£3 a volume) - said that Bishop Long now starting an imitation (sic) of the Canadian Khaki University (mentioned in my reports) Lately got Kitchener House to write to Red Cross for financial help. Murdoch's reply "H.Q. do not advise as the men's stay too short" - so we "not on our own" - Mrs. Bulteel starts 9 - we get the Red Cross boxes condemned, (but do not act until Murdoch approved) - place Smith in charge, get O/C to let him stay, etc., - all personal, unofficial, liable to be disrupted - no system - H.Q. neither knows, nor cares. - Again Canada send more on to Command Depot until well.

We are on tube station on the way there - so, no official care of men on furlough - go where, or how, they please. So I arranged with Red Cross and Y.M.C.A. "men to be twice a week as they leave, placed in wards and men's hands, cards, giving every place and facilities under them in London - got sent to them for "furlough places" - means of transport to Dartford, etc. - all again, personal temporary unofficial - Should be official regular permanent. Oh for insight, provision, consideration at H.Q. - practically none - just as they turned down my home outlines for shell shocks - add the long keeping of fit medicos and orderlies here, and of sick and tired over there - rotten places for hospitals - no G.H. here - no continuity of treatment - long stays in British Hs without supervision and responsibility - our nurses "not equal to acute cases" - send on "now fit for Dartford" - it makes one's blood boil - no inspection - no specials - only a few selected for special work. Boarding up to 70 in an hour and 400 in a day without histories or, often, examination. And yet - nearly everyone at H.Q. promoted or decorated - no children's school or pawn shop would be continued on such lines - yet - all apparently satisfied - why have I not spoken out? I have - and been snubbed ("Mind your own job" said Millard) - I have recommended and no notice taken - I have attempted and in some cases been thwarted, in none followed or extended, and finally I have reported - with what result time will show.

Meantime, to such as I come into personal touch with, I have acted - on the whole not unsucessfully - I have satisfactorily settled the future of some hundreds - I have consistently boarded for Australia until the poking has been approved, and I have never sent one back to duty unless and until I considered he could stand the strain. Had I done more - I am satisfied from Army and Red C. experience I should have become Stellenbosched, or sent back to Australia - as I narrowly escaped in Egypt - and so ceased to work. As it was, I have had my opportunities minimised - but still I have careful full histories of nearly 1000 cases on the best lines, and even further than ever I had in the Melbourne Hospital. This is my reply and hope - my justification - I have preferred to work to revolt - earlier I would have combined the two. Have I been right? Who knows. It has certainly not been from fear. I have even regarded it as self effacement under an omnipotent, careless machine. And yet, much has been done, we might have been worse - but Canada, New Zealand and South Africa, have all managed nearly all better.
As I said to Butler, "will the official history be full and true in references to all their points? No more than the fighting history - there will be suppression that must be the suggestion later - What matter? None, except that the better was possible, but not done. Poor old World, how much better might you not be? Poor old reputation, what a fraud you frequently are! Poor old desert, how you may blush unseen. But - and that is the solace - the work remains and the little extra was done, and produced its little extra result. Here endeth the Lesson.
Entry.608: Newton off to 3 A.G.H. - done good work here - but? more useful where he goes (obtained his FRCS here & whilst hell was loose in France!)
Entry.609:
Boarded 17 - including Bullock - write Clark and Murdoch for carpentry tools, etc.

1918
Entry.610: Completingmy 1000 histories of cases - some work - ? unique in the A.A.M.C. (I started on the best plan I could make. I carried it through)
Entry.611: Second annual sports - good and well carried out - Billy Hughes down - "thinks him too much with the men" - Excellent concert at night - letter from King "Bring letter from Government and all will be arranged." (for visit to French neurological centres)
Entry.612: Preparing for Paris trip - then I suppose "return to Australia" - the only one of my status returning as I left - this extraordinary - unfair - but explicable. Sister with gift from Australia - gives farewell tea to the 17 "returning to Australia" with concert before and after - give them speech and poems. ("The Evacuation", "The Recognition")
Entry.613: To Glasgow to see my brother Percy - mental after strain and fall (died soon after)
Entry.614: In France -Triumphant progress under Monash - ever since
Entry.617: - both Padres gone - fine, with keen and proper view of their possibilities - yet both sent away at once - "no continuity" - just haphazard. The new one begins well - give him my views, American plan and 1000 Overseas City Guides (better than the Y.M.C.A. - sent thousands over to Monash) - who tried to stop the Y.M.C.A. over lapping) - successful - at the end.)
Entry.619: away from home - the boys send to Dartford and give me a present - Millard inspects - surprised and pleased at our ward work - back to London with him in car - give him my views re defects. (He listens, in silence "No one ever was so wise as Lord North looked')
Entry.620: Ward hard at fresh basket and other work - thanks to supply through Mrs. Bulteel - new Padre hard at it. (made one myself in the afternoon)
Entry.621: Australians "still victorious" taking Mt St Quentin "one of the most brilliant achievements in the War" (said Gen. Rawlinson). When the secret history of the men is written, I predict that the forward movement began with Monash and our boys - Monash knighted at the front by the King - Wandsworth nearly full of our wounded officers, but why none in our own - shameful.
Entry.622: Soon off to France on special duty - got clothes, money, etc. - Howse interested and sympathetic in manner - to report - then "off home" about November.
Entry.623: Fixing up every man in the ward prior to going away - illustration of Red Cross red tape - ask for a few carpentry tools thro Mrs. Kennedy (representative), and O/C - O/C approves - Murdoch says "favourable consideration" - then wants to know (a) if we have Educational Room, (b) will I/we call it "Red Cross Room". Meantime, we get what we wantfrom the Y.M.C.A. - Mrs. Bulteel down - about a dozen men on basket making, mat-weaving, etc. (allthis is whilst in Hospital, as approved at the Inter Allied After Care Conference)
Entry.624:
Goodbye to the boys - 3 weeks in France - (vide report).
(Most interesting, most illuminating, promptly reported, Nil done after Armistice") )
Entry.625:
Since return - writing report with appendices - had an hour with Monash - he wants me to write the "History of the Advance since August 8th" - has prepared much of the skeleton - and will take me over the ground - Usual hospital work - cured 4 (2 mutes and 2 stammerers) in half an hour - gave the boys a lecture on my trip.

 
Conan Doyle offered to write it - M. - preferred an Australian - and accidental meeting / asked me. Vide XI "Spearhead" Articles in "The Age" on my return
Entry.626: Case of man 219 days in other hospitals - all sorts of diagnoses - sent by Maudsley to "Queen's Square or Napsbury" - I send on the case to H.Q. as illustrative of "long delays -varied diagnoses and disregard of our own hospitals". (Is there any decent justification?)
Entry.627:
Usual routine - resurrecting some and helping all - all I can do - but no help from H.Q. In these respects our position incomparably the worst of the Dominions - still no special hospital - no General in England - 13000 they say still in British hospitals - no recognition of our

1918
Entry.628:
fitnessto deal primarily with our own men - rotten - unnecessary - an insult to us - and a gross miscarriage of justice to the men. It will all come out - when all is over 
Has it? Will it?
, and the interest has become academic - 3 instances in my own work the last few days - (a) case 219 days elsewhere, (b) case 52 days in Norwich, not a neurological note, yet with amnesia, speech, etc., (c) case relapsing on the way back to the front, and sent to a heart specialist who diagnoses "N.Y.D.N." - (nervous) send them on to H.Q. (The common diagnosis "D.A.H." generally more nervous than cardiac followed the man infuriously all the way to Australia)
Entry.629:
Intent to join the Discharged Soldiers Federation, when I get to Australia, and bring into reciprocal relations with the 
Australian
 Imperial League. (tried, but failed)
Entry.630: Arrange auction of our baskets, etc. at Dartford (one-third to the men - one-third to the Fund, and one-third to pay for material has been our system). found excellent & satisfactory all round)
Entry.631: Show the boys the map of our advance, and read them Rawlinson, etc. on it. (Apparently we started the Advance & were, every day, miles to the east of the rest - Some - the were sucked forward by the local retreat)
Entry.632:
Fine chap over from H.Q. - "influenzal pneumonia 5 days - no treatment - sent down "walking case" from H.Q. - collapses and lived (vide Appendix) - 
I reported it to H.Q. any one punished?
officialdom surely doomed - too ineffective for words - must go. (But, as in the Crimea, it remains, with just a changing face)
Entry.633: To prepare for Millard diagnostic extras for circular re shell shock (just 18 months since I brought it forward - and not sent out until after the Armistice was signed!!). Anyone decorated? The official mind, method, selection, and procedure must go all round - go absolutely, every one is sick beyond expression at its power, persistence and incompetence - a few bright minds in a desert of class - narrowness, want of sympathy and effectiveness.
Entry.634:
Mrs. Bulteel down - Arrange staff etc. for the next 10 days - carpentry, basket and tie making going on well - forward Millard what he wants - Report to be circulated 12 months after first officially reported.

"2-15"
Visit to the front with Monash - in Paris at the Armistice. (one of the events of a life time) (to write the account ofthepast hundred days. Vide my XI articles in The Age, & Monash's book)
Entry.636:
Writing up notes on French visit - board papers - get extracts from newspapers at Australia House -
Kindly placed at my disposal, make a selection
 - select 250 photos of our boys in France - see Jeffries - "to go back to Australia on Dec. 10" - leave private letter with Anderson re returning altogether - sine honore! (just as it was - inferentially just a cog in the machine)
Entry.637: Souvenirs from sisters and boys at Dartford.
Entry.638: Routine ward work - packing - writing - saying goodbye all round.
Entry.639: Boarding cases for the last time - Photos of basket work - So I go back - immeasurably thankful for many things - with the one red and four blue stripes of full service on my sleeve, my outside mark, and, internally, the memory and acceptability of many efforts, the more than compensatory satisfaction of Egypt, England and France, stored in the brain, and the heart warmed by such a vision of comradeship as makes the whole world kin. In continued health and strength when so many others died, or were disabled.
Entry.640:
Last day - Letter from H.Q. "to report at H.Q. at 4" - several letters addressed to me as Colonel - and the office said I had been promoted - so some recognition at last - Round the last time "Au revoir" to all - off with Mackey as typist for my paper on the Great Advance - at H.Q. get £23 for allowances on Special Duty (in France) (within 10d of my claim) Goodbye to Anderson and Millard in a hurry. To Australia House - then Overseas Club - Write 40 P.P.C. cards - "The Strand" for the last time - Dine 2 of the boys at "The Ship" - sleep at Euston.



 

1918
Entry.641: Up at 7 - off - train9.10 - Farewell to London - Liverpool to time. The "Nestor" with Blue Peter up - collect my 7 cases - last lot of men - 300 from Weymouth - only up since 2 a.m. - Out into stream and "off at daybreak". So farewell England, and the War.
Entry.642: On board, comfortable quarters - put up extra star. - Honman returningalso Col:
Entry.643: Bay of Biscay - we all wear American kapok life belts - far the best - sustain for 40 hours - to think John Bull satisfied with his old cork squares.
Entry.644: Start my account of the Advance with Mackey - Number of throat cases, but only in hospital for a day or so.
Entry.646: Now 61 pages of account typed, 15 - nearly finished.
Entry.647: Albany, quarantined on orders from Melbourne - for "Influenza" - an Australian scare on - one really only infectious sore throat - as our troop ships always coming and going - Local lumpers "won't coal unless £1. a day, and £3000 in case of death" - 44 diggers, load 594 tons in 19 hours - a record - with Honman to Quarantine Station - condemn it - the W.A. contingent would have mutinied sooner than go there - Owing to my diagnosing a suspicious case as recurrent trench fever - we get away another let-off. (Vide Honman & my report to S.M.O. Nicholls)
Entry.648:
Portsea - Again quarantined - (2 men with slight pyroxia, the last 2 days) - absurd position - we - the M.O's draw up a statement. Q officers come on board in masks - "to protect themselves or us, which?"- Melbourne being "infected" - whole thing a burlesque and muddle - detained on the boat for a week, though grounds and accommodation on shore - "not to go" so long as anyone "with a temperature" - yet they use unreliable thermometers, and break all recognised rules re inhalations - almost a mutiny - Arrange - sports, etc. to keep the men in good spirits - what a reception for the Anzacs. We pass Fremantle with its fine Quarantine Station - for Albany, with its small and defective one - We pass Adelaide, with its good Quarantine Station, though we have S.A. men on board. We stay off Portsea a week, and let boats leave for New Zealand and Tasmania without sending on our quota - Then, when at the end of the week nothing develops, as was our experience all the way out - we are again made an infected ship at Port Melbourne 
by tying up at an infected pier!
and the men "sent out to Broadmeadows", to again undergo quarantine before the different States will let them home. Is there any wonder they objected strongly and forcibly? The wonder is that they kept inside the regulations. Unfortunately, also, those returning to other States had further trouble, not only in delay for transport, but further quarantine on reaching their home ports.

The account which I gave will be found in the Appendix. For its publication, I was called on for an explanation by H.Q. but no action followed - apparently because, as in the Red Cross exposure, I was dealing with unofficial procedures (those of the Quarantine Department). But surely there was some Army medical responsibility? If so, it was ignored. I again contend that some action should have been taken by it in the interests of the returning men.

anyone punished?
I was hauled over the coals for publicity - but, to the Quarantine & not the Defence Department - so escaped. I was also asked to explain two other ?breaches of the Regulations - sucessfully. In 
Egypt 
- I was there asked to explain & several times in
